PETITION.TITLE: Discrimination against Women
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The Petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that whereas the Government of Australia has signed the United Nations Covenant on Civil and Political Rights which in Article 23 (1) states that ''The family is the natural and fundamental group unit of society and is entitled to the protection by society and the State''. And whereas the terms of the United Nations Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination Against Women would violate the above Article 23 (1).
We humbly pray the Government to refrain from ratifying the Covention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination Against Women; believing that its implementation would result in:
(1) Undue cost to the nation at this time.

(2) ''The elimination of any stereotyped concept of roles of men and women at all levels'' as described in Part of 3 Article 10 (c), being a disruption of traditional parental roles, is likely to result in emotional disturbances of childhood.

(3) The strong encouragements to mothers to join the workforce, with the provision of networks of creches and child care centres as outlined in Article 11 of the convention is likely to result in maternal deprivation and psychological disturbances among children with an increase in childhood psychiatric illnesses.
(4) The sexual role changing as recommended in Part 3 Article 10 (c) is likely to contribute to further marriage insecurity and breakdown.
And we pray you may be conscious of God's sovereign purpose for our nation.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Adermann,Mr Braithwaite,Mr Cadman,Mr Carlton,Mr Cowan,Mr Free,Mr Groom,Mr Hicks,Mr Barry Jones,Mr Lusher and Mr McGauran.

PETITION.TITLE: Discrimination against Women
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia showeth that:

The Universal Declaration of Human Rights affirms the principle of the inadmissibility of discrimination and proclaims that all human beings are born free and equal in dignity and rights and that everyone is entitled to all the rights and freedoms set forth therein, without distinction of any kind including distinction based on sex.

However, extensive discrimination against women continues to exist. It is an obstacle to the participation of women on equal terms with men, in the political , social, economic and cultural life of this country. It hampers the growth of the prosperity of society and the family and makes more difficult the full development of the potentialities of women in the service of this country and of humanity.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Commonwealth Government will act to ratify the convention on the elimination of all forms of discrimination against women.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Cross,Mr Humphreys and Mr Moore.

PETITION.TITLE: South West Tasmania
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned residents of Australia respectfully shows that your petitioners are gravely concerned at hydro-electric or similar development in the South-West Tasmania World Heritage area. This area has been recognised as of national and world importance and therefore is a National responsibility.

Your petitioners therefore humbly call upon the Federal Parliament to ensure all within its power, including the blocking or non-allocation of funds, is done to ensure this area is preserved as wilderness and therefore no road or dam development is allowed. This is a national issue and therefore Tasmanians should not be required to bear severe financial burden if this occurs.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: South West Tasmania
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled: The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that your petitioners are gravely concerned at proposed future hydro-electric developments in South West Tasmania. This area is on the Register of the National Estate and therefore is of national concern.

Your petitioners humbly call upon the Federal Parliament not to allocate funds or allow funds to be raised for development of roads or dams in the South West of Tasmania but rather to provide such funds as would enable the preservation of this area. This is a national issue and therefore Tasmanians should not be made to bear any financial burden resulting from its preservation.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Podiatry Services
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled: The humble petition of the undersigned citizens respectfully showeth:
That your petitioners are gravely concerned at the lack of podiatry service lower fixed income members of the community.

Podiatry is an essential health service especially in preventing greater dependency of older people. It would be much more cost effective to maintain the mobility of older people through adequate and effective services than to force them into premature institutional care.

The fees for repeated podiatry consultations to provide essential ongoing care are well beyond the means of pensioners. Considering that Department of Veterans Affairs' pensioners are entitled to podiatry care, and this scheme is already operating successfully, we strongly urge that this service be extended to cover all pensioners.

We believe this could be best achieved through including podiatry along with the existing concessions on the Health Care Cards. This would enable a flexible system of care through private practice, community health or rehabilitation services. It would also be essential in negotiations with the Podiatry Association to ensure assistance would be available to the housebound and those in institutions.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Office of Child Care
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled: The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That citizens of Western Australia view with great alarm the removal of Director of the Office of Child Care and fear for the future of that office and the children's services programme which it administers.

We believe the Office of Child Care to be inappropriately placed within the Department of Social Security, where children's services are in competition with welfare services for the aged, disabled, and other such groups.

Your Petitioners therefore humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, should take every step as necessary to obtain immediate withdrawal of the Office of Child Care from the Department of Social Security and the establishment of a Children's Commission.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Proposed Airport at Scheyville, New South Wales
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled: The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
1. That an airport in the north-western region (commonly called Scheyville) imposes disastrous economic, environmental and social costs on our community.
2. An airport would destroy 2,000 households and impose upheaval, noise and pollution on one million people presently unaffected.
3. The cost of an airport in the north-western region is greater than the alternatives, whilst fog and close proximity to R.A.A.F. Base Richmond would make operations impractical.
4. It would destroy the historic village of Pitt Town, environmentally important wetlands, and their unique adherent wildlife.
5. Your petitioners reject these proposals and call for endorsement of the MANS Committee findings.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Great Barrier Reef: Oil Exploration
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled: The humble petition of citizens of the Commonwealth submits:
That off-shore oil exploration within the Great Barrier Reef Region constitutes a serious threat to the richest and most varied living system on earth.
Your petitioners request that your Honourable House will:
(1) Prohibit oil exploration within the Great Barrier Reef Region,
(2) Declare the entire Great Barrier Reef Region a Marine Park under the Federal Government's Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Act 1975,
(3) Provide the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority with the staff and resources for effective management of the Region.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: South West Tasmania
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members in the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled: The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that your petitioners are gravely concerned that the taxes of all Australians will be used to finance a dam that would flood the Lower Gordon and Franklin Rivers in South-West Tasmania. Your petitioners declare that the intrinsic values of this area, and the provision of funds from the taxes of all Australians, for the destruction of this area of the National Estate and of world heritage value, does make this a national issue. Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Federal Government take all possible steps, including financial and legal steps and fulfil its responsibilities under the Australian Heritage Act to prevent the destruction of this area of the National Estate.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Slaughter of Marine Mammals
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:
1. Since the Australian Whaling Protection Act, 1980, provides for the banning of importation into Australia of all whale by-products, and
2. The Prime Minister has stated that he and his Government support the International Banning of Whaling,
3. Then consistent with (1) and (2), this Government should immediately legislate to ban the importation of all marine mammal by-products, including the harp seal of Canada, and

4. Through the Australian delegate in the United Nations General Assembly, the Prime Minister should state his Government's support for an International ban on the slaughter of any marine mammal for commercial reasons.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that:
Consistent with Legislation on whaling, this Government should ban the importation of marine mammal by-products, and support an international ban on the slaughter of any marine mammal.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Moreton Island: Sand Mining
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
1. That sand mining on Moreton Island poses a threat to the natural ecology and environment of the Island.

2. That Moreton Island is included on the Register of the Australian Heritage Commission, and the Federal Government is urged and indeed it must, under the Australian Heritage Commission Act 1975 take into consideration the protection of the island.

3. That the Queensland Government has given approval to the sand mining of Moreton Island despite the advice of conservationists and despite the opposition of the majority of electors in the Moreton region.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the House of Representatives will request the Government to refuse export permits covering mineral sands mined on Moreton Island.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Labelling of Cosmetics
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That continued use of animal ingredients in cosmetic products, and the inhumane use of animals in scientific research for cosmetic products is abhorrent and barbaric.

That the Industries Assistance Commission, because of the Commission's terms of reference, seems unable to impose any regulation or recommend any regulation which might restrict the activities of cosmetic companies which produce cosmetics in which animal ingredients have been used, or for which animals were subjected to research.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the House of Representatives will:
Legislate to require comprehensive labelling of perfumes, cosmetics and toilet preparations to indicate:
(1) Whether a product contains any animal derivative. If so, the ingredient and source should be indicated.
(2) Whether the research and development of that product or any of its ingredients involved experimentation on animals.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Popular Theatre Troupe of Queensland
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that Australia Council funding for the Popular Theatre Troupe of Queensland has been entirely cut for 1983.

The Popular Theatre Troupe of Queensland has made an important contribution to the cultural and artistic life of the Australian community for the past eight years taking innovative and original theatre to sections of the community who would not normally attend live theatre performances.
The Popular Theatre Troupe of Queensland is the only theatre company in Australia which consistently presents theatre of social comment and tours nationally every year.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Australian Parliament will resolve to ask the Australia Council to reverse its decision in respect to the Popular Theatre Troupe of Queensland.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Export of Live Animals
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That (a) the export of live animals for slaughter overseas and
(b) the shipment of live horses to Japan sentences such animals to cruel and inhumane treatment in the export process and at the hands of foreign importers.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the House will request the Government to ban the export of live animals for food and allow only carcass trade.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Uranium Enrichment
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
(1) that the Uranium Enrichment Group of Australia (UEGA) has suggested sites in the heavily populated region of South-East Queensland for the development of a uranium enrichment plant;
(2) that the Commonwealth Government has approved, in principle, UEGA's suggestions, without consultation with the residents of the area; and
(3) that UEGA and the Commonwealth Government will conduct feasability studies into the plant, but no confirmation has been made of a study into the safety of the plant.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the House of Representatives condemns the Government for approving, in principle, UEGA's suggestions to establish a uranium enrichment plant in the heavily populated area of South-East Queensland and requires that the Government (1) conducts a poll of all South- East Queensland residents to determine whether they give assent to the plant and (2) conducts a comprehensive and independent study of the safety of the uranium enrichment plant.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Moreton Island: Sand Mining
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
(1) That Moreton Island has been listed on the Register of the National Estate because of its exceptional scientific, ecological, heritage and recreational values; and
(2) That any sand mining of Moreton Island will result in the destruction of the exceptional scientific, ecological, heritage and recreational values of the Island; and

(3) That Moreton Island has been the subject of detailed investigation resulting in the adoption of a Management Plan by the Brisbane City Council the main aims of which are to conserve in its natural state the quality of its scenery and natural environment and to enhance public enjoyment of it for recreation purposes; and
(4) That Moreton Island represents the last significant area of wilderness close to Brisbane; and
(5) That there is an acute deficiency of National Parks within a 150 kilometre radius of Brisbane; and
(6) That Moreton Island contains Aboriginal Relics of immense scientific and cultural importance; and
(7) That the Island represents a major potential tourist resource specifically because of its unspoiled natural scenic attractions; and

(8) That public opinion actively demonstrated over a number of years clearly indicates that most citizens of Brisbane are strongly opposed to any sand mining on the Island, and desire that the whole of Moreton Island with the exception only of existing Townships, Tourist Resort, Airstrips and Lighthouse Reserve should be declared a National Park.
Your Petitioners, therefore, Humbly Pray that the Parliament of Australia will:

(a) accept the wishes of the Petitioners and the citizens of Brisbane generally and take whatever action is necessary and available to it to prevent sand mining of any description taking place on Moreton Island; and

(b) request the Government of the State of Queensland to take immediate action to declare the whole of Moreton Island to be a National Park with the exception only of existing Townships, Tourist Resort, Airstrips and Lighthouse Reserve.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Exploitation of Kangaroos
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled, Parliament House, Canberra, ACT 2600.
We, your petitioners, humbly showeth:

That permitting kangaroos to be commercially exploited when permissible cropping rates are unknown and the means of enforcing controls or protective laws are completely ineffective in this land, is allowing this unique animal to follow the path to rarity or extinction along which all wild animals have gone when subjected to exploitation in similar circumstances.
We Australians, have the right to see kangaroos in reasonable numbers on the landscape: we find the commercial slaughter of the kangaroo to be abhorrent and unjustified.
Commercialization of wildlife should be stopped, particularly as exemplified by the kangaroo industry.
We your petitioners therefore humbly pray that you will:
1. Ban the export of products made from kangaroos.
2. Take action to see that State Governments prohibit the commercial killing of kangaroos.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Postal Commission
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of certain citizens undersigned respectfully showeth:
1. That Australia as a sparsely populated continent requires the maintenance of a high quality postal service as a vital means of communication.
2. That the Australian Postal Service truly meets the needs of all Australians.
3. That any proposal that Australia Post's monopoly power to carry letters for reward be diminished will destroy the concept of the national postal service.

Your petitioners therefore pray: that the powers of the Postal Commission to carry letters for reward should be strengthened to ensure that the national postal service is retained in the interests of all Australians.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Macedonian Language
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned showeth:
(1) That the Macedonian language be used by Government Departments in multi- lingual publications.
(2) That the petitioners urge the introduction of the Macedonian language as a Higher School Certificate (H.S.C.) subject in Secondary schools.
(3) That the petitioners urge the introduction of the Macedonian language in tertiary institutions and that a course be introduced at Monash University in the Department of Slavic Languages.
Your petitioners, therefore, humbly request that Parliament take immediate action to implement the above measures.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Omega Base
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:

1. Omega by sending low frequency signals, penetrating sea water enables hunter -killer submarines to establish their position and to launch a 'first strike' attack. Omega is also used by AWACs, the flying radar stations, and for other military purposes.
2. Omega is an important US military base and a potential nuclear target. A nuclear attack on Omega would have a disastrous effect on Victoria and Melbourne .
3. Omega and other US bases in Australia endanger, rather than protect us. They add a new unnecessary menace to a nuclear arms race that must be stopped, if we are to survive.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Construction of Railway Overpass, Port Augusta, South Australia
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That the railway crossing situated approximately 5 kilometres east of Port Augusta on highway one (the main highway between Adelaide and all northern and western centres of South Australia and continuing through to Western Australia) has once again been the sight of an horrendous accident.
This accident has caused two, possibly three fatalities.

Previous requests have been made by the city council of Port Augusta for the construction of an overpass, so that this section of the highway no longer presents a danger to the motoring public and those involved in driving trains over this crossing.
Permission for construction of this overpass has previously been refused and the situation has now become critical.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Federal Government will reconsider their previous decision and approve construction of an overpass at this fatally dangerous highway crossing to avoid further loss of life.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Mackay Directory Assistance Centre
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives of the Commonwealth of Australia in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Mackay respectfully showeth:
That the intention of Telecom Australia to close the Mackay Directory Assistance Centre will:
downgrade telephone services to Mackay and district.
deprive customers of a personalised reliable telephone service.
reduce job opportunities in the area.
increase the likelihood of the eventual closure of the exchange.
We the undersigned believe that Telecom Australia has a social responsibility to provide a sound, reliable, personalised telephone system.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that your Honourable House will call on the Government to intervene to stop Telecom's proposed closure of the Mackay Directory Assistance Centre.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Television Programs: Captions for the Deaf
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of certain citizens of Australia shows-your petitioners are concerned that Queensland will not benefit from a decision by the Commonwealth Government to make money available for the Australian Broadcasting Commission to develop programs captioned for the deaf.

Your petitioners petition that the large numbers of deaf people resident in Queensland should be included in considerations concerning captioned television and in this regard call on the Government to ensure that the Australian Broadcasting Commission's captioned programs are broadcast in this state as well as in Victoria and New South Wales.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: General Motors-Holden's Pty Ltd
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. We the citizens of the City of Woodville and supported by the citizens of South Australia, being deeply concerned over the threat of closure of the Woodville Plant of General Motors-Holden's, respectfully show:
(1) That the management of General Motors-Holdens has failed over a period of more than two (2) years to give any assurances that the Woodville Plant would continue in operation.
(2) That a recent statement attributed to the GMH Managing Director, quote:-
'The overall objective of our South Australian rationalisation plan has been to eliminate all productive activities on the Woodville site' end of quote.
This statement has not been refuted.
(3) That the elimination of the Woodville Plant will cause enormous social dislocation, hardship and misery to the citizens of Woodville and South Australia.

Your petitioners therefore pray that the Parliament of Australia will condemn this callous disregard for the citizens of Woodville and South Australia, and do all in its power to force General Motors-Holden's to retain its operations at the Woodville Plant.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister for Housing and Construction whether he will indicate how many mortgage payers will have their effective mortgage interest rates increased by up to 2 per cent as a result of the decision announced last week to scrap the general home mortgage interest tax rebate and the special rebate for some first home buyers?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hurford The Hon C.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is, unfortunately, impossible for me to answer that question accurately because the statistics are not available. What I can tell the House is that that particular general rebate referred to by the honourable member, which was introduced in the August Budget, has not been taken advantage of by most pay-as-you-earn wage earners. No adjustment has been made in the pay-as-you -earn scheme. Indeed, any benefits that there will be will still be payable in the coming financial year in the deductions in the amount of benefits that will be available through taxation refunds to taxpayers. A one per cent reduction in interest rates will have far greater effect for the vast majority of Australians than will any general tax rebate. I turn the question back on all those sitting on Opposition benches, particularly on the front bench of the Opposition, the guilty men who are responsible for the $9.6 billion deficit. What would they have done in any economic package that was coming forth at this time?
Opposition members interjecting-

—I would be grateful if the Minister for Communications would inform me of the activities being undertaken in Australia in 1983 to commemorate World Communications Year.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Duffy The Hon M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for his question. A considerable number of activities have been arranged in Australia this year to commemorate 1983 as World Communications Year. A number of those activities have been accredited by the Department of Communications, which is the lead agency in Australia for the activities this year, as warranting official recognition for World Communications Year. The honourable member asked for an outline of the activities. In March this year the Satellite Users Association of Australia conducted a conference, workshop and exhibition around the theme 'Using New Communications Technology'. In the last half of April, the Australian Telecommunications Commission and the Overseas Telecommunications Commission hosted a series of working parties in Australia for the International Telecommunications Union Study Group. That Study Group was dealing with telephone switching and signalling. During May there were numerous activities- the issue of a World Communications Year commemorative stamp; public broadcasting week, which I had the pleasure of opening in Melbourne; and the announcement of the winners of a letter writing competition which was conducted by the Australian Postal Commission. On 17 May, World Telecommunications Day, there was the announcement of the winning entries in the Australian section of an international art competition for young people entitled 'Youth in the Electronic Age'. I should like to add that in presenting the prizes in that competition I found that the art contributions by the young people of Australia were outstanding.

ANSWER.PARA: Aussat will be conducting a science contest on the development of experiments in space which might accompany the launching of Australia's telecommunications satellite in 1985. In June, the Australian Amateur Radio Teleprinter Society will conduct a World Communications Year radio telecommunications contest. From June to July the Royal Melbourne Institute of Technology will conduct an international conference around the theme 'Tertiary Education in the Age of Communications'. From the middle of June through to the beginning of September, the Australian--
Opposition members interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I trust that the Minister can round off his answer fairly quickly and keep it in line with his usual succinct answers.

—In addition to this list of activities-there are many more, but I shall conclude on this basis-the Department of Communications has been involved in communications projects of significance in the Asia-Pacific region generally and is studying ways in which Australia might become involved in further communications projects of benefit to countries of the South Pacific region. It is also publishing the bi-monthly World Communications Bulletin.

—My question is addressed to the Prime Minister. He will recall that in this House last Tuesday he was asked whether Mr Richard Farmer was briefed on the David Combe affair on or about 23 April and he refused to answer on the ground that the whole matter was being considered by a royal commission. As the Prime Minister subsequently announced outside this House that the Chief Minister of the Northern Territory, Mr Everingham, had been briefed in April on Mr Combe' s involvement with the expelled Soviet diplomat, Mr Valeriy Ivanov, will he now inform the House: First, whether he or anyone instructed, authorised or employed by him briefed any other person in relation to this matter; and, secondly, specifically, whether following an approach by Mr Farmer's business partner, Mr Bill Butler, a member of the ministerial staff advisory panel, about a possible conflict of interest if Mr Farmer and Mr Butler entered into a business arrangement with Mr Combe, the Prime Minister personally briefed Mr Farmer about Mr Combe's relationship with Ivanov, on or about the weekend of 23 and 24 April?

—I am pleased to answer the question that has been addressed to me by the right honourable member. The previous Government treated, and this Government is treating, Mr Everingham, the Chief Minister of the Northern Territory, as equivalent to a State Premier. I simply make the observation that that, I believe, put Mr Everingham in a special category. In respect of the other matter raised by the right honourable member, I simply say this: That question, and any other like it, will be considered by the royal commissioner. I am looking forward to the examination of all these matters. I hope that anything I or the Government has done will be examined in full by the Royal Commission on Security and Intelligence Agencies. I repeat that nothing will be done by the Government to prevent a total examination of anything that I have done or the Government has done. I hope that all members of this House will equally look forward to such an examination.

—I ask the Prime Minister: What is the Government's reaction to the South African bombing raid on the Mozambique capital, Maputo, which followed the bombing of the South African Air Force down-town headquarters in Pretoria by African nationalists?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —In answering the question addressed to me by the honourable member for Brisbane I begin by expressing the view, which I believe will be shared by all honourable members of this House, that the Australian Government totally opposes the inhuman policy of apartheid which is practised and pursued by the Government of South Africa. This Government looks forward to the day when that system will be totally dismantled so that all citizens of South Africa will have equal rights irrespective of race.

ANSWER.PARA: This Government is horrified by the loss of lives and the numerous injuries which occurred as a result both of the bombing of the South African Air Force headquarters at Pretoria and the subsequent raids by the South African Air Force on the Mozambique capital, Maputo. The Government condemns unequivocally the indiscriminate use of violence either as a means of seeking to change the political system in South Africa or, equally, as a means of preventing change in that unfortunate country. Nevertheless, I have to say-again I hope this is a view understood and accepted by all members of this House-that this Government understands the frustration that can result in the anti-apartheid movement in South Africa and its resort in that extreme of frustration to actions of an extreme kind. I say to this House and to this nation that as long as the South African Government continues to refuse to negotiate the achievement of a decent, equitable and honourable system which brings about a solution to the problems in that country, unfortunately it is likely that we will see continued resort to acts of violence.

The Australian Government considers that the latest attack on Mozambique by the South African Air Force, like earlier attacks on neighbouring countries by the armed forces of South Africa, does nothing at all to resolve the root causes of the problems in South Africa. I conclude by saying that the Australian Government unequivocally condemns the latest use by South Africa of its Air Force to attack a sovereign neighbouring country.

TALK.START.PARA: —Does the Deputy Prime Minister envisage his Japan-Australia peacekeeping force in Kampuchea operating under the auspices of the United Nations?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think it ought to be noted that I have had a fair bit of publicity on this matter, and that I mentioned that perhaps Japan would be involved. Of course, any peacekeeping force that I or anybody else had in mind would be under the umbrella of the United Nations. As I said the other day, when I discussed this matter with Foreign Minister Sonoda in Japan on 9 July 1981 he welcomed any initiatives by Australia to establish a peacekeeping force. That is the reason that I was anxious to mention that perhaps Japan could give support to the whole concept.

ANSWER.PARA: I am aware that sections of the Press feel that I am anxious to involve Japan in something which is unconstitutional and which cannot be done. Of course, I could not do that nor would such action be acquiesced in by Japan. I say to the honourable gentleman, who had the benefit of having discussions with Mr Son Sann on the same day as I did, that the initiative from Australia was welcomed by Mr Son Sann. It was in the course of the remarks which I made in Bathurst that I mentioned that the dreadful loss of life in Cambodia, to which Mr Son Sann referred, was due to the fact that no initiative had been taken over a long time to guarantee that the combatants would get to the table and perhaps discuss some settlement factors. I think that Japan could help in that. I think it is also worthy of note, as I mentioned last week, that I am the only Minister who has seen Mr Thach, the Vietnamese Foreign Minister.

TALK.START.PARA: —I saw him in New York at the United Nations.
—You saw him outside Vietnam.
—Yes, but I did see him.

—The Leader of the Opposition was not able to go to Vietnam; that was his difficulty. When I saw Foreign Minister Thach in 1980 he also welcomed any initiative. I think this is very important for the Australian nation. He said that he would withdraw his troops from Cambodia on condition that Pol Pot was disarmed. The Leader of the Opposition would know that at that time his Government-I appreciate that he dissociated himself from that policy- still recognised Pol Pot.
—You recognised him first.
—I know, but that was in 1975; we are now talking about five years later when there were three million dead as a result of his actions.
—The honourable gentleman will answer the question and ignore interjections.

—I want to assist in the detail because it is of interest to Australia that there is no further war in the area. It is important that we take initiatives in areas in which we can create peacekeeping operations. I am mindful of the fact that it was suggested that India and other nations might be involved. But the significant point is that nobody has yet taken the initiative. I assure the honourable member that I think the Australian Government will take the initiative and it is about time that it did.

—I direct my question to the Minister for Finance. I refer specifically to the decision not to legislate to override an administrative decision by the Commissioner of Taxation to the effect that the retreading of tyres constitutes manufacture and hence the final product may be subject to a sales tax of 20 per cent. Will the effect of this decision be to increase the cost of a retread tyre to a level comparable with that of a fully imported new tyre? Is it a fact that projected revenue will not be realised because imported new tyres will replace the current Australian retread market? Will this not simply represent a transfer of jobs overseas, creating a further loss of employment opportunities in Australia?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Dawkins The Hon J.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is true that last year the Commissioner of Taxation, as a result of a review of the retreading process, made a ruling that this was a process of manufacture and decided that a sales tax should apply. It is also true that the former Government announced that it would be acting legislatively to override the ruling of the Taxation Commissioner. Of course, that was to join 16 other announced measures which the former Government said it intended to take but had not got around to bringing into the Parliament. In some cases it had not even got around to drafting the legislation. It was one of the matters which confronted the new Government on taking office. When we were apprised of the full details concerning this matter we realised that the former Government had largely misled the people regarding this issue as well as many others during and just before the Federal election campaign.

ANSWER.PARA: The point is that at the same time as the 20 per cent sales tax will apply there will be a removal of the sales tax relating to the ingredients used for retreading-that is, the sales tax which currently is payable in respect of the rubber will not now be payable. The sales tax payable in respect of the machinery which is used in the manufacture will not now be payable. That will mean that the imposition of the 20 per cent sales tax will have a very small effect on the price of retreaded tyres. There will still be a substantial margin between the cost of a retreaded tyre and the cost of a new tyre. The honourable member raised in his question the price comparability between a retreaded tyre and some imported new tyres. The only new imported tyres, the price of which would come anywhere near the price of retreaded tyres, would be those which are factory rejects and which are not suitable for anything other than off-road use. In that sense those tyres are not comparable with retreaded tyres.

I make one other observation: There has been some suggestion that there will be important employment effects as a result of this decision and that those effects will impact particularly on regional areas. When the Government made its decision to abandon the procedure to override the Commissioner's ruling, it was made perfectly clear that the Government would keep under close attention the employment effects of the decision and that, if there were employment effects, which I do not believe will occur but which some people have alleged will occur, then the Government would be prepared to look at the matter again.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs. It is supplementary to the question asked of the Deputy Prime Minister. Why does the Foreign Minister disagree with the Deputy Prime Minister?

—I am not quite sure what the Leader of the Opposition has in mind. The Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Trade is a devoted Catholic and I am an atheist so that is one ground on which we have some differences. He is largely a teetotaller and I enjoy imbibing, as does the honourable member for Moreton, and tonight I will do so, in good company I expect with him, before dinner. Somehow I have a sneaking suspicion that there is something more substantial to the question than that. All I can say is that I listened to the Deputy Prime Minister with considerable interest. Gauging by the discomfort caused for the Leader of the Opposition at one stage, I thought he handled his reply with entertaining attention. I will be in Hanoi on 1 July. I will be talking with the Government authorities there and Mr Thach, among other people. I guess I will be going to places such as Singapore, Bangkok, Kuala Lumpur, Manila and Jakarta, and then back to Hanoi and back again to these other places. I expect this will be a rather long process. In fact, honourable members will be interested to know that I expect to be spending as much time in those places in the course of my career as Minister for Foreign Affairs as the Leader of the Opposition did, when he was Minister for Foreign Affairs, in Los Angeles and New York. In one sense the challenges for him may have been more stimulating and diverting, but then he is much younger than I am-by a year or two. I do not think I have anything further to add.

—I direct my question to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and preface it with a reminder that today women all over a war-weary world are demonstrating their urgent desire for peace and disarmament and an end to nuclear insanity. I ask: What initiatives will his Government take in the attainment of world peace?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hayden The Hon W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am well aware of the concern of women on this issue and particularly the 13 women who are members of the parliamentary Labor Party caucus. This morning they made clear their genuine and praiseworthy concern on this issue-a concern shared not just by women but by all people in the community. We have in mind a number of issues. Shortly, after further consultation with the Prime Minister, Cabinet and my party colleagues, I expect to make a substantial and considered statement on this subject. Of course, I will attend to a considered attitude about whether we will appoint an ambassador for disarmament and arms control matters. But there are a number of matters on which we have already taken action. We protested to the French about their nuclear testing in the Pacific. Only a week ago in Paris we quite firmly stated our opposition to all forms of nuclear testing by all states in all environments and our commitment to work for an early conclusion of a comprehensive test ban treaty. We have stated our intention to raise at the next meeting of the South Pacific Forum a proposal for a south-west Pacific nuclear free zone. We have indicated that we will not stand in the way of a consensus to hold an international conference on the Indian Ocean as a zone of peace. We have indicated our determination to maintain the safeguards regime established under the Treaty on the Non-Proliferation of Nuclear Weapons.

ANSWER.PARA: We intend to establish a peace research and arms control institute and are currently considering the best methods of achieving this. We have embarked upon consultations with the Australian National University for that purpose. The Government also intends to upgrade its capacity for analysis and policy formulation in this highly complex and difficult area within my Department and in other relevant areas of the Government. I note for the record that, on assuming the position of Minister for Foreign Affairs, one of the first sections of my Department that I attended to was that which handles disarmament and nuclear safeguards. I was rather surprised that this key area of responsibility is staffed by two heads of section and seven staff members-scarcely sufficient to carry out the sort of detailed, complex and in many ways legalistically demanding work that is required in that area.

There are other areas of disarmament and arms control in which the Government intends to play a much more active and independent role, such as the conclusion of a treaty for the prohibition of chemical warfare. We will publicly recognise that outer space is the coming area of arms competition between the super-powers and that limits must be set. We will announce our support for a ban on attacks on civilian nuclear facilities. We will review our record of signature and ratification of and reservations to existing disarmament treaties. We will support unequivocally moves in the Committee on Disarmament to set up a working group initially to identify issues for negotiation. We will, of course, participate actively on this issue, including at the United Nations General Assembly which will be coming up in a few months time. Honourable members will understand that in the short period in which we have been in government, and the relatively short period that I have been Minister for Foreign Affairs, we have displayed a concern and an industry about this issue which will not be remitted in any way. We intend to take a number of further initiatives additional to those I have outlined. I repeat that in the weeks ahead, after consultation with the Prime Minister, Cabinet and my parliamentary colleagues, I intend to make a substantial considered statement on this broad issue of great national concern.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs. I want to say that I enjoyed his answer, bearing in mind the debriefing that he gave me of his own recent visit to Paris. To revert to matters of far greater import, the fact is that the Deputy Prime Minister is proposing by his answer today and has proposed a particular peacekeeping force in Kampuchea. Will the Foreign Minister be discussing that type of peacekeeping force referred to by the Deputy Prime Minister in the many travels he has outlined that are ahead of him?

—The Paris debriefing to which the Leader of the Opposition referred consisted of my bursting into his office-second only after a visit to the Prime Minister; I have to have my priorities straight if I am to survive in a difficult environment-on Wednesday last week when I returned from overseas. I acknowledged to him, and anyone in his office who cared to listen, that the little black address book he gave me for Paris was listed full of duds.
—Order! I remind the Minister for Foreign Affairs that this is Question Time and not confession.

—I suppose, to take up the point observed by you, Mr Speaker, and my comments about the Leader of the Opposition, that I at least recognise my age and intend to have the title of my Department changed to External Relations. More seriously, the matters which will be discussed are ones which will evolve from contact with the people in Vietnam. One does not go there with preconceived notions, setting down a fairly rigid program. I rule out nothing and at this point I am prepared to include nothing.

—Is the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations aware of reports of an alarming drop in apprenticeship intakes this year and a similarly disturbing increase in the number of retrenched apprentices? If such developments are occurring, what measures is the Government taking to overcome them?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Willis The Hon R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, I am aware of such reports, and the latest figures available to me show a very disturbing situation indeed. For the year to the end of March 1983 they show a 32 per cent decline in apprenticeship intake on the figures for the previous year. Over the same period the number of apprentices who had been retrenched and remained out of work increased by 50 per cent. These developments of course are of great concern to the Government. I suppose one can understand to some extent the attitude of employers who are faced with difficult times in many cases, with low profitability and declining demand for their goods. Nevertheless, it is extremely regrettable that this situation has developed. I think also that many employers have been rather short-sighted in reducing their apprenticeship intakes or in retrenching apprentices. I believe that they should be looking wherever possible at the longer term, recognising the extreme importance of ensuring that we continue to have training of apprentices in order to maintain a skilled work force so that when economic recovery comes we will have available the requisite number of skilled tradesmen to enable that recovery to continue.

ANSWER.PARA: The Government, whilst calling on employers to take that longer view, has also seen fit to take some steps in the meantime to encourage employers to take that longer view. I am pleased to inform the House of a number of measures which we have implemented as a first step to overcoming these problems. Firstly, to encourage employers to increase significantly their re-employment of retrenched apprentices I have decided to extend the period of assistance provided under the special assistance program. This program presently provides a weekly wage subsidy of between $63.70 and $86.90 a week for up to 17 weeks to employers who hire out-of-trade apprentices. I have decided to increase the period of assistance from the present 17 weeks to 26 weeks to give greater incentive to take on and retain such apprentices. This will increase the maximum amount of that subsidy from $1,477 to $2,260. We have also agreed to allow employers who are in receipt of special assistance program assistance to receive also payments under the Commonwealth Rebate for Apprenticeship Full-time Training Scheme, which provides rebates to employers who release aprentices to undertake full time institutional training. This measure will result in an additional incentive of around $500 for each out-of-trade apprentice recruited.

I have also asked the Public Service Board to allow an increase in staff levels this year in Public Service departments to allow the recruitment of a number of out-of-work private sector apprentices. That is for the year 1982-83; we will certainly be looking at the situation again for 1983-84. In addition, the Government remains committed to supplement apprenticeship intakes by assisting the States to create an extra 2,000 trade based pre-employment course places in tertiary and further education institutions in 1983.

These measures indicate the Government's commitment to safeguard the future supply of tradesmen and to ensure that the necessary skills are available when economic recovery begins. I again implore employers to utilise these programs, to realise that the Government is providing every assistance it can provide in this area. I ask them wherever possible to retain their apprentices and to pick up apprentices who have been retrenched by other employers if they have the capacity in any way to do so.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment had occasion to assess the quality of rehabilitation of sand mined areas on Fraser Island? Can he envisage any circumstance which might result in the lifting of the ban on export licences in respect of such mining operations?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cohen The Hon B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for his question. I have not had a chance to have a look at the rehabilitation work in the last few years. However, I was there, I think in 1979 or 1980. Whilst some of that rehabilitation work is quite good, I think it would be fair to say that people in that area who are holding out hopes that one day sand mining will resume and export licences will be permitted are living with false hopes. The simple fact is that the Whitlam Government initiated the Fraser Island inquiry. The Fraser Government decided to stop permits for the export of mineral sands and that policy continued until the new Government came to office. I can assure the honourable member that that policy will continue.

ANSWER.PARA: I think that, frankly, it would be far better if the people of the Maryborough area forgot about the possibility of mineral sand mining recurring. There are great opportunities for tourism in the whole Fraser Island region. My colleague the Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism, as did I when the shadow Minister, has constantly reiterated the fact that what is required is a proper plan of management for Fraser Island to encourage tourism and not something that could continue to spoil the ecological balance of the area. In my view and in the Government's view that is how future prosperity for the area will come about . I just wish that people would not continue to talk about sand mining there in view of the fact that two governments now have continued to state quite categorically that there will be no export of mineral sands from that area. I, for the life of me, do not see any government-Liberal, Labor, National Party or whatever-ever changing its mind on that issue.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister for Foreign Affairs. In view of the Minister's frequently expressed commitment to independence for New Caledonia , and in the light of the statement by Mr Lemoine, the French Secretary of State for Overseas Departments and Territories, in Noumea on 20 May, will the Minister inform the House of the Government's view of developments in New Caledonia?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hayden The Hon W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are pleased that Mr Lemoine, the Secretary of State for Overseas Departments and Territories, was able to make a statement in Noumea on the 20th instant about future prospects in relation to New Caledonia. When I was in Paris recently at the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development conference I took the opportunity of staying over to speak with Foreign Minister Cheysson and Secretary of State Lemoine of the French Government. We discussed a range of matters because both governments are affiliates of the Socialist Internationale. We were able to establish a mutually productive rapport even on issues where there were some differences, such as nuclear testing in the south- west Pacific. I appreciate the frankness and productiveness of the exchange which took place.

ANSWER.PARA: For some time we have expressed a commitment to independence for New Caledonia, determined according to the wishes of the people of New Caledonia. However, we have acknowledged-I certainly acknowledged it privately and publicly in Paris- that the process is fraught with great difficulties. The socialist Mitterand Government of France has inherited a very complex and difficult situation in New Caledonia. First of all, what was once a Melanesian majority in the indigenous population of New Caledonia has, as a consequence of migration policies undertaken from the early to mid-1950s, been reduced to a minority, albeit a large one, of about 43 per cent to 45 per cent of the population of New Caledonia. This, in itself, creates a situation of some tension, when the future of New Caledonia is discussed, in terms of whether it will have an association with France, some form of self-determination, or independence.

The area of New Caledonia itself has been badly polarised because of these tensions and differences. In that sense Mr Lemoine's statement was, I believe, a helpful contribution. He has proposed that processes for self-determination will be provided later and that among these processes the socialist Government of France is prepared to entertain all proposals, including that of independence. In the meantime, the Government will push ahead with land reform and the provision of full control by local government over local affairs. In the processes towards self-determination, whatever they might be, itinerants will not be allowed to participate in voting procedures. In the meantime there will be an early round-table meeting in Paris to discuss revision of the Territory's statutes. The socialist Government of France has outlined a number of initiatives which are important.

Earlier I mentioned that the French Government has embarked upon a very complex and difficult exercise. Frankly, it has inherited an unfairly difficult situation from previous conservative administrations of France. I believe that nothing better exemplifies this than the fact that, among the Melanesian population, there is only one qualified school teacher, only one officer in the armed services, only one doctor, only one architect, only three engineers, no technicians and no middle class. So the previous conservative administrations of France scarcely made any provision for transition, in order to allow the Melanesians to play a more effective role in the administration of their country .

The final point I want to make is that I have consistently said to the Melanesian independence movement representatives that it is our considered view that, whatever processes take place, and whatever the final determination is on the part of the people of New Caledonia as to its future form of administration, it should be achieved with the good will and support of France, that we will not be party to any violence or conflict and that we believe that the Francophone influence in this region of the world has been a valuable one.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Prime Minister: Did spokesmen for the present Government give an unequivocal undertaking during the election campaign to fund certain public works projects in Tasmania? Did those projects include the Warner Creek Dam, the Craigbourne Dam and the upgrading of the St Helens port facilities? Is it true, as has been reported, that the Government will not now proceed with those projects unless the Tasmanian Government agrees to stop work on the Gordon below Franklin scheme? Will the Government now give a no-strings undertaking to proceed with its election promises for Tasmania? If not, is the Government involved in a blatant form of political blackmail?

—Order! I think probably the honourable member would withdraw the final statement in his question. Such an assertion would have to be the subject of a substantive motion, not an inference in the House.
—I will withdraw the last part of the question.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The position of this Government in regard to its assistance to Tasmania generally and its attitude in regard to the dam in particular has been consistent. We said during the election campaign that when this Government came to office it would be unqualifiedly opposed to the continuation of the building of the dam. We said that we understood the attitudes of those who were adopting a contrary position in Tasmania-that is, that they had a concern not for the dam as a dam but because of two things: Firstly, the future power requirements of Tasmania, and, secondly, the employment possibilities of those who were and would otherwise continue to have been engaged on the building of that dam. I regarded those concerns as legitimate then, as I do now.

ANSWER.PARA: What we said during the campaign is what we are saying now to the Premier of Tasmania. We have undertaken to examine, with the Government of Tasmania, its future needs. The current position clearly is that Tasmania has far more power than it needs and there is no immediate need to start on any alternative power projects. But it is sensible to talk about what its future requirements will be and my Government stands ready to do that.

In regard to those people currently employed upon the building of the dam, we have made it clear that we would, in consultation with the Premier of Tasmania, examine other projects-a range of them that I mentioned before the election-as examples of what could be done. We have said that the important thing is that together the Tasmanian Government and ours sit down and work out what particular projects are most likely to provide employment as quickly as possible and in a way which will provide lasting benefits to the people of Tasmania. That was our position in the election campaign. It remains the position of this Government. I say to the House that I am very glad-I am not trying to score any points from this fact-that the Premier of Tasmania is coming here to talk with us later on this week. I welcome the attitude of the Premier of Tasmania in coming here with his officials. We will aim to have constructive talks with him so that, together , we will be able to assist in meeting those legitimate needs, that is, future power requirements and alternative undertakings and projects in Tasmania, without prejudice on our part. We say we will list those projects which look suitable and we will listen to what the Tasmanian Premier has to say. Together we will see what alternative projects we can undertake so that there will be no loss of employment and so that, in the end result, projects undertaken with the assistance of the Government will be economically sane and not involve, as I have said so many times before, the ecological obscenity involved in a continuation of the existing dam project.

TALK.START.PARA: —I address my question to the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs. Will the Minister give an undertaking to honour the commitments of the previous Government to Aboriginals in the fields of sport, recreation and culture which were announced by the former Minister just prior to the election?

—I thank the honourable gentleman for his question. I am not quite cognisant with the extent of the commitments given by my predecessor in the field of culture because that was not particularly an area in which members of the Opposition excelled. In terms of sport and recreation, however, there were quite considerable--
—I ask the Minister to face the House. It is really rather difficult for honourable members to hear.

—I will speak slowly and clearly. I will spell it out and then honourable members opposite might be able to comprehend. Quite a number of specific promises were made by my predecessor in the field of sport and recreation. Although they did not represent our particular preferences or priorities, they did raise a reasonable level of expectation amongst the Aboriginal communities which were to be the recipients. In all cases I have indicated that those promises will be honoured.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macphee The Hon I.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I seek leave to make a personal explanation.
—Does the honourable member claim to have been misrepresented?
—I do, Mr Speaker.
—The honourable member may proceed.

—The Sandringham-Brighton Advertiser of 4 May published a letter from Mr Bruce Ruxton, the Victorian President of the Returned Services League of Australia. In that letter, Mr Ruxton made one of his periodic attacks upon me with his customary misrepresentation of my words or actions. Mr Ruxton normally confines his attacks on me to his column in that scurrilous journal, the Toorak Times. There, his bigoted and racist ravings are only read by the fascist fringe --
—Order! The honourable member should proceed to where he has been misrepresented and his rebuttal of those misrepresentations.

—As usual, Mr Ruxton's comments were lengthy and contained much colourful language. I will deal, however, only with those passages which caused me particular concern and I will ask the newspaper to publish this statement in full.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Ruxton based his comments on a speech which I made to this House on 6 May 1982. On the basis of that speech he asserted, firstly, that I sought to 'remove the Queen from the oath of allegiance and let migrants keep their former nationalities'. I have never advocated the removal of the Queen from the oath or affirmation. Queen Elizabeth is our Head of State and oaths and affirmations of allegiance are made to her as such. The only change I suggested was to reverse the order of the two concepts covered by the oath and affirmation, as the wording then stood. New citizens were required to 'renounce all other allegiances' before pledging loyalty to Australia through our sovereign. Over one million persons in Australia were entitled to become citizens but declined to do so because they thought they were being asked to renounce their entire heritage. After careful study and advice, I suggested that the positive act of pledging loyalty to our sovereign precede a specific renunciation of all other loyalties to countries, but worded so as to make it clear that no one was being asked to reject their cultural heritage. My suggestion was finally adopted by the Government and I expect more eligible people to become citizens now that the emotional barrier has been removed.
Secondly, Mr Ruxton asserted that I wanted to:

. . . let migrants keep their former nationality-that would be the greatest absurdity ever to come from the mouth of a Minister. Imagine: Migrants would be citizens of this country as well as citizens of their country of origin. What other country on earth would put up with that?

A great many countries of the world would put up with that. The United Kingdom is an example. Perhaps the greatest absurdity belongs to Mr Ruxton, especially as I have always advocated the direct opposite of what he alleges. Australia has never sanctioned dual nationality, and I have always been adamant that we should not follow the plentiful examples of European and other countries in that regard . Thirdly, Mr Ruxton also asserted that:
a recommendation by Mr Macphee meant that English would be downgraded as the national lauguage and that Australia would become a multi-lingual society.
My exact words in that speech were:
English is Australia's national language and therefore the essential language of communication in our multicultural society.

I have never advocated that English should be downgraded as the national language, and I defy anyone to scan all of my speeches to find any such proposition. English is not only our national language but, thanks to the influence of the United States of America--

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member is rather lengthening his explanation. He is granted indulgence to say where he has been misrepresented, not to point out the virtues of his attitudes.
—Thank you, Mr Speaker. I shall go on to the fourth misrepresentation . Mr Ruxton stated:

SPEECH.PARA: It was Mr Macphee who tabled the proposed changes to the Citizenship Act that would affect the life of every Australian and their children and their children' s children forever.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-The Government has made the following decisions in respect of Medicare. Medicare will commence on 1 February 1984. The payment of medical benefits will be administered by the Health Insurance Commission, which currently runs Medibank Private. Medibank Private will be able to offer the same range of additional private cover as the other private health funds will be offering. This is to cover private treatment in public hospitals, private hospital treatment and ancillary cover for items such as treatment by dentists, physiotherapists and chiropodists.

SPEECH.PARA: The Department of Health will retain overall responsibility for detection and investigation of doctor fraud and overservicing, using information supplied by Medicare, and overall policy direction. The establishment and running costs of these operational arrangements in the first five months will be $81.2m. Full year recurrent costs will be $66.2m.

Medicare is a major social program of this Government. It will ensure basic medical and hospital cover for all Australians and will not leave two million Australians without any health cover, as the current inadequate private insurance system does. The Government has chosen the Health Insurance Commission to run Medicare because it is the only health fund with a nation- wide network of cash payment centres that will provide quick and efficient service to the public. By using the Health Insurance Commission we will avoid the waste and duplication involved in having 70 different private funds making Medicare payments. The Health Insurance Commission has a proven record in health insurance, including the successful implementation of Medibank in 1975. By having one paying agency Medicare can ensure confidentiality of patient records and can provide better controls to prevent fraudulent payments and better information for the detection of medifraud.

The Government is concerned at the potential employment consequences of this decision and is adopting several measures to ensure that no current health fund staff are disadvantaged. The Health Insurance Commission has been requested to offer preference in clerical employment to current fund staff. Discussions have already commenced between my Department and the Department of Employment and Industrial Relations on the matter of employment preference. We will be discussing the changeover to Medicare with the trade unions involved in the private health insurance industry. I have begun discussions also with the State Health Ministers on their offering employment preference in the clerical areas of the State health systems. These measures, combined with the 20 per cent annual turnover in fund staff, will minimise the net employment effect of Medicare.

We welcome the commitment of the private funds to Medicare, as exemplified by their bid to run it. Though it has not been possible to accept their offer we believe that co-operation between the funds and government will ensure an improved, cheaper health insurance cover and will guarantee the interests of their employees.

Staff currently employed in direct billing activities within the Department of Health will all be offered continuity of employment in the Health Insurance Commission. There will be no geographical relocation of staff employed in the regional processing centres of the Health Department. I am also aware that there are local health funds in some regions which are significant local employers. I have requested the Health Insurance Commission to enter into discussions with these regional funds to ensure that the service provided to local communities is continued. This is the first step in the restoration of a simple, equitable and cost efficient health plan for all Australians. I present the following paper:

TALK.START.PARA: —Two weeks ago in the House, on a matter of public importance, I raised the possibility of the Government making a decision to centralise the processing of health insurance claims under Medicare. The Minister for Health (Dr Blewett) claimed that I was merely rumour mongering. He heaped opprobrium on me for having had the temerity to raise such a matter. Today this Minister and this Government have signed the sack notices for those 5,000 people . Everything I said in this House two weeks ago has come to pass. The Minister has come up with no arguments which deny any of the propositions I put at that time. He suggested that his action in centralising all the activities of paying the medical benefits under Medicare will not have a major disemploying effect, although he admits there will be a disemploying effect. He has given reasons for this mad act of socialist centralisation, which is totally unnecessary. The reasons are wholly spurious.

SPEECH.PARA: I will go through the reasons in turn. He said that the business had to be given to Medibank and taken away from the people who already do this job perfectly satisfactorily. He said it had to be put with Medibank because it is the only health fund with a nation-wide network of cash payment centres. The fact is that the private funds between them, with Medibank Private, have a much wider network than Medibank can possibly offer. Indeed, the Minister's proposal will require the doubling up of Medibank outlets. So, the private funds already have a better network of cash payment centres for the public.

Secondly, the Minister said that the proposal will avoid the waste and duplication of 70 different private funds. This waste and duplication, if it is to be called that, currently provides insurance at a lower management cost than is provided by Medibank Private. I ought to know because I was responsible for running Medibank Private as Minister for Health. Waste and duplication to this Government is what we call competition between private operators. Competition reduces costs; government monopoly increases costs. There is no suggestion at all that this idea of waste and duplication has any merit.

The third reason given is that Medibank has a record of successful implementation-of Medibank-in 1975. One ought to listen to and talk to some of the branch managers of Medibank Private and find out how difficult it is for them to build up their business in some areas because of the difficulty which customers had in earlier introductions of systems by Medibank. So, that excuse does not hold any water either. The Minister said that there will be one paying agency. This is nonsense because, under Medicare, instead of people going to the one fund for their basic and supplementary cover, they will have to go to two points. The Minister said this one paying agency would ensure confidentiality, presumably over and above the confidentiality one gets with private funds. Not even the security committee of this Government's Cabinet can ensure confidentiality. Therefore, I wonder how on earth Medibank Private will ensure confidentiality any better than those private operators who have been doing this kind of business for scores of years. He said that there will be better controls to prevent fraudulent payments. What evidence is there of that? Is there any evidence that government-run enterprises are any better at preventing fraudulent payments than private enterprise? I really challenge that. There is no evidence whatsoever. The Minister said that there will be better information for the detection of medifraud. This information can be equally required of the private funds under a contract to do the business as subcontractor which they are perfectly prepared to enter into. A condition of that contract could be that the necessary information is provided to counter medifraud.

In admitting that people will have to be sacked under this proposal, the Minister said that steps will be taken to ensure that no current health fund staff will be disadvantaged.
