It is just not possible for the Minister to come into this House and say that no current health fund staff will be disadvantaged when thousands of them, not tens or hundreds, will lose their jobs . They will be sacked. He said that the Health Insurance Commission, that is, Medibank Private, will give preference to employing current health funds' staff. That may well be but the Health Insurance Commission will be recruiting new staff while the funds are still in full operation. I note he said that Medicare will now start on 1 February and not 1 January.

One side issue relating to this matter is that the additional cost of $4 a week for insurance, which was announced in the statement by the Treasurer (Mr Keating ) the other night, will continue for another month. In other words, not for a short period but for an extra month-right up to 1 February 1984-under this Government the costs of health care for Australians will rise by $4 a week. This goes against the claim in the policy speech of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) that nine out of 10 Australians would pay less for health care, and against the things that were said at the National Economic Summit Conference, and also included in the communique, about the commitment of this Government to reducing these kinds of costs in the interests of trying to moderate wage demands. On this count also members of the Government have shown themselves to be a pack of turncoats. They have turned their back on the very people they claim to represent. In so doing they have also threatened their accord, their Summit and their application before the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission.

On the most optimistic figures there will still be a net loss of 3,200 jobs. There will be 5,000-odd jobs at risk because of location problems. Not all of the jobs offered by Medibank Private will be available anywhere near the locations of those people currently working in the wide network of private health insurance funds. Under the signature of this Minister, under this Labor Government which was elected with a promise of improving employment opportunities, at this moment 5,000 people are under threat of the sack and there is not the slightest hope that for 3,200 of them a job will be provided within Medibank Private. That is the fact of the matter and it is an absolute disgrace. The Minister said that the State Health Ministers will be asked to give preference in clerical employment to current funds' staff. What on earth is this worth? This Minister, the former Opposition shadow Minister for health, spent the last two or three years bemoaning the tight situation of State Health Ministers and State Health departments. He criticised the previous Goverment for financial stringency which, he said, had caused the State Health Ministers to reduce their budgets and staff. Since he came to office he has not given them any more money. Now he is suggesting that they should give preferential treatment to those being thrown out of work in the private health funds. Where on earth will this preferential treatment lead these people? I presume it will lead them from one dole queue to another.

The Minister's statement about the private health funds welcoming Medicare, by the very fact that they put in an offer to run it on a sub-contract basis, is absolute cant. It is unbelievable that he should include something like that in his statement. What use are the costings? In the short time that I have known of the costs I have not had an opportunity to examine them against the offers made by the private funds, but I do know that offers made by private funds under some form of offer or tender system and subject to contract on a fixed price basis are worth 10 times or 100 times an offer made by a government instrumentality. Once the purchasers of the service, that is the Australian people, have signed up they will have no fixed price contract and no certainty whatsoever that the prices will be kept within what were stated. When one is in the hands of a government monopoly one has absolutely no control whatever over the future direction of those costs. One is not in a position to sack that monopoly when the cost estimates are not maintained. Anything that the Minister might say about the cost implications of this in this House are not worth a crumpet.

In Australia 8,500 people work for private health insurance funds. Over 5,000 of these jobs are at risk at this instant by the statement of the Minister, who is a member of this disemploying Government. In Victoria, which will have an opportunity to pass judgment on this situation on Saturday, 2,350 people are employed in private health insurance funds. There are 1,400 of these jobs currently at risk. In the Melbourne metropolitan area alone about 2,000 people are employed, of which 1,200 are at risk this week following the actions of this Government. The people in the electorate of Bruce will pass judgment on this situation on Saturday because they will have an early opportunity to do so. We in the Opposition will do everything within our power to bring this matter to their attention.

I pointed out during discussion of a matter of public importance two weeks ago that there was no possible reason, beyond some blind socialist objective, to centralise and to squeeze out private enterprise. There was no conceivable reason to enter into this act of madness. There was no reason to threaten the jobs of 5,000 people in this industry. There was no reason to ensure that over 3 ,000 of them would absolutely lose their jobs even if the location problems were solved. There was no conceivable reason, beyond a determination which is now surfacing within this Government to proceed with socialist ideology against any practical considerations. I find it frankly unbelievable that this is being done in the present employment climate and that the Labor Government, with the ideals that it professes to hold, would put forward measures like this to extend the dole queues by 5,000 people.

The Opposition will not let this matter rest. We will do everything we can to try to save the jobs of these people. We will do everything we can when the legislation comes in to try to ensure that the matter is subcontracted to private enterprise and to the private funds. We will speak to senators who are independent to enlist their support for these people who are threatened with losing their jobs. We will not let this matter rest. This decision must certainly dog this new Minister for Health throughout the whole of his ministerial career. It is a matter of the utmost seriousness of a most practical kind. It is not something on which one can sit back in a ministerial office and make a decision with one's colleagues. It is not something which involves only the movement of paper. TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

This Bill provides for an amendment to the Wheat Marketing Act 1979 to give effect to decisions taken by the Government in the context of its expenditure review. The effect of the amendment will be to terminate from 1 July 1983 the scheme whereby the Australian Wheat Board is reimbursed for the additional costs involved in borrowing from the domestic capital market compared with the Rural Credits Department of the Reserve Bank of Australia. The scheme was introduced to compensate the Board for the Government's decision to compel it to borrow from the higher cost domestic market. The Bill therefore provides that from 1 July 1983 there will be no liability for the Commonwealth to make any payments under the scheme.

In consideration of the termination of the scheme, the Government will seek the approval of Loan Council to permit the Board to borrow overseas in 1983-84 and subsequent years subject to the following conditions. The Board would be free to borrow 50 per cent of its prospective net borrowing requirements overseas but would require the agreement of the Treasurer (Mr Keating) and me to borrow more than 50 per cent from overseas sources. The criteria for our approval in the latter case will take into account both the prospective monetary situation on the one hand and the prospective borrowing requirements and borrowing costs of the Wheat Board on the other. Within the annual limit the Board would be free to determine the currencies, timing, size and term of individual borrowings, subject to its giving the Government prior notification of the size and timing of borrowings.

The Bill, therefore, also provides for the Board's powers in relation to borrowing and the issue of securities, to be exercisable both within and outside Australia. These new arrangements should enable the Board to borrow from lower cost markets such that there should be no increase in the cost of borrowing to the Board from the termination of the interest subsidy. Not only are current interest rates generally lower overseas but also, as wheat is often traded in foreign currencies, the Board would be able to hedge the risks of currency fluctuations by borrowing in the same currencies as those in which it makes sales. I am sure that the Board and wheat growers would welcome the increase in commercial freedom of the Board.

Time will be limited in this debate; however, I would like to make just a few other comments that may be of assistance to the Opposition. The legislation is extremely simple. One sentence is inserted so that the Australian Wheat Board may exercise its powers within and outside Australia. Another sentence is inserted to remove the interest rate subsidy. The Opposition should fully understand this because it was the former Government that cut the interest rate subsidy by one per cent in the Committee of Review of Government Functions-that is, the so-called razor gang-exercise. At that time the reaction of the wheat industry was understandably hostile. This action was a blatant breach of the 1979 Wheat Marketing Act. Also, growers had been guaranteed that the Treasury would pick up the difference between the commercial rate of interest and the rate charged by the Rural Credits Department of the Reserve Bank of Australia. That decision was justified by the then Government, and the National Party in particular, and no trade-off was offered. The situation regarding the margin between the rural credit interest rate and commercial interest rates in 1981 was 2.4 per cent. Today it is 0.5 per cent. In taking this action we are offering a trade-off that will have the potential to benefit the wheat industry by tens of millions of dollars.

The Australian Wheatgrowers Federation has been calling for this reform for 18 months. The National Farmers Federation does not oppose it. In fact, in a statement released last week it praised the move. I have a telex from the Australian Wheat Board which again welcomes the move that it be allowed to borrow overseas. Maybe I should read that telex. It states:

The flexibility of marketing Australia's wheat will be improved following last night's statement by the Commonwealth Treasurer that the Government is seeking Loan Council approval for the Australian Wheat Board to borrow up to 50 per cent of its financial requirements off- shore. He also indicated that the Wheat Board may be empowered to borrow beyond the 50 per cent level if circumstances are appropriate.

In past years the AWB has been permitted to raise up to 2 billion dollars from Australian financial sources to fund the initial payment to growers of the guaranteed minimum price for wheat. The Acting General Manager of the Board, Mr M. Connell, said that the offshore borrowing facility will be a major step forward in improving the Board's commercial independence and flexibility. He stressed that any efficiencies gained for the wheat industry will be passed on to growers.
Mr Connell indicated that the AWB is well prepared to take advantage of the power to borrow offshore.
And, as honourable members will recognise:
A previously approved pilot borrowing program for 200 million dollars is currently being put in place by an Australian Wheat Board team which is overseas .

The Treasurer's announcements are in line with submissions advanced by the Australian wheat industry over a period of time. Last year the AWB made reference to the issue in a submission to the Industries Assistance Commission inquiry into the Australian wheat industry. Mr Connell said that the AWB welcomed the initiatives which have been announced.
I commend the Bill to honourable members.

TALK.START.PARA: —In regard to the economic statement that has been put down by the Treasurer (Mr Keating), the associated ministerial papers and the motion to take note of the papers, I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That all words after 'That' be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:
the House is of the opinion that the Treasurer's statement places an unfair burden on the vast majority of Australian families while failing to address Australia's fundamental economic problems.

The Bills and the economic statement before the House do nothing to reassure Australians that this Government has any clear perception of a program for recovery and reconstruction. The mini-Budget solves nothing, it only raises questions. It is not just an anti-climax, it is bitterly disappointing. It is, sadly, just another example of the increasingly notorious Hawkespeak. The Government was elected on a promise to build community confidence and hope. It promised so much. It has unfortunately given so little. It promised a blueprint for recovery. It promised jobs for the unemployed. It promised that its prices and incomes policy would lead to responsible wage demands, better industrial relations and lower inflation. It promised a better deal for all sections of the community, not just narrow interest groups. It promised that the diversionary crises that were so prominent in the Whitlam era would never return.

The Australian people took a gamble. They put their trust in the Australian Labor Party. In particular, middle Australia put its trust in Labor. In return for that trust, what has this Government done? It has introduced a mini-Budget which takes $8 a week from the average Australian family and which is a direct assault on middle class families. In return for their votes Labor has slugged them. It has taken away the home loan rebate. It has taken away the medical insurance rebate. It has means tested pensions for the over-70s. It has raised the floor for concessional tax rebates. Labor seduced middle Australia with promises of 'immediate . . . tax cuts'. There are to be no tax cuts. Instead, $8 a week has been snatched away. Labor promised middle Australia that it would not take away the home loan interest rebate. It said that it would retain the tax rebate for home loan payments. That was what Labor said in its housing program, but now, two and a half months later, that rebate has gone. So many families, struggling to pay off a home loan, have been suddenly presented with what amounts to an unexpected bill. Everyone on the Government benches must know someone who is in that situation. Why do they not care? Why should families suddenly lose the health insurance rebate? Why should it go at a time when they are struggling?

While families have been hit, the weakest sector of the community, the elderly, has also suffered. The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) promised in his policy speech that he would not take money out of the weekly pay packet or the pensioner's cheque yet that is exactly what he has done. Old people have planned their lives around their pensions. They trusted Labor, believing that pensions would not be means tested. Many of them voted Labor thinking that Labor would help, not hurt, but on Friday morning they learnt that they had been cheated. Everyone on the Government benches will know pensioners such as these. How will the Government explain this cruel, cheap trick to them? Middle Australia helped put Labor into power. It has paid a very high price. The unemployed also looked to Labor for help. What have they received? The Government has done a deal with the unions which will throw another 100,000 Australians onto the dole queue.

This is a government which set itself high objectives and built up high hopes. It is already falling short of its objectives and it has shattered those hopes. The excuse of the Treasurer is that the Government has not yet had time to look at the options. Can this be because it has bungled almost every other aspect of governing Australia, or is the economy just too hard? Whatever the reasons may be, Labor's social values and priorities are now perfectly clear. They are not directed to providing permanent, secure jobs. As I have said before, one of the merits of the so-called Economic Summit was the clear acceptance by all participants of the causes of our economic problems. The Summit did not condemn the policies of the previous Government with the irrational hysteria that we often hear from the other side of the House. It did not descend to the party political debate which has for too long characterised economic discussion in Australia. Indeed, its analysis was largely consistent with the perceptions of the previous Government.

There is in the community an acceptance of three major factors. First, Australia has inevitably been seriously affected by the protracted downturn in the international economy. Second, Australia has endured one of the worst droughts in its history. The 14 per cent decline in gross farm product for the December quarter of 1982 shows quite clearly the devastating impact of the tragedy. Third, real wage rates in Australia have risen dramatically at a time when real wages in other countries have risen only modestly and have in some cases declined. In the calendar year 1982 average weekly earnings rose by nearly 15 per cent. According to the Treasurer, average weekly ordinary time earnings for full time adult workers were still 2 per cent higher in real terms in the March quarter of 1983 than they were a year earlier. As a result, Australia's cost structure is considerably higher than is the cost structure elsewhere. That has made our industries less competitive. It has made them less profitable and in many cases unprofitable. It has meant that to survive industries have had to shed labour at an alarming rate. Devaluation is the external acceptance of the problem. Massive wage increases have boosted Australia's inflation rate at a time when inflation rates in most other industrialised countries have been falling.

It is against that background, one understood and recognised by almost all Australians, that the Government has taken its economic decisions. The Government's measures must be judged against a number of yardsticks. They must bring down inflation. They must bring down interest rates. They must encourage investment. They must make our industries more competitive and profitable. They must generate economic growth. They must, at the end of the day, generate many more permanent and secure jobs. They must give Australia and Australians a sense of confidence in their future, a belief that they can each continue the task of building this nation. These are lofty goals. No industrialised nation has found them easy to achieve, but some are indeed succeeding.

The reality is that Australia needs an annual 5 per cent growth in gross domestic product over the next three years if unemployment is to be significantly reduced. This is to be compared with an average non-farm GDP growth of 2.8 per cent in the last decade. So we do not underestimate the task. Difficult and unpopular decisions have to be taken and, because they are unpopular, persistence and political fortitude are needed to ensure that decisions taken in the interests of the whole community are not cast aside because of the opposition of narrow and selfish interest groups. So the broad strategy needed to achieve these goals is clear. First, the Government must ensure that wage levels reflect the capacity of the economy to pay. If wages are too high businesses will be unable to compete. Their costs will rise, their order books will decline and their profits will shrink. They will stop investing . They will stop employing. That equation is simple enough, yet the union leadership and the Government of this nation refuse to recognise it. Secondly, the Government's monetary and fiscal policies must ensure that the private sector, the engine of economic growth, has access to funds for investment; that it is not crowded out of any financial markets by big spending governments. There is absolutely no doubt that business will need these funds at the lowest possible interest rates for this is the only way to create the new investment, the only way to generate new jobs.

Positive signs exist which give us some hope for a recovery. Good rains in the last two months over much of Australia have brought relief to many farmers. The prospects for a rural recovery are now much better. To maximise the opportunities, farmers must have access to funds so that they can invest quickly . What is more, there are at last some signs of economic recovery in the United States and, to some extent, in Europe and Japan. Industrial production increased by 2.1 per cent in the United States in April, the highest increase in almost eight years. Industrial production has also grown by varying degrees in many of the major European countries. Over recent months, the inflation rates of most Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development countries have come down, in some cases quite dramatically. Nominal interest rates have also fallen. I am not making any predictions about future international trends for such predictions are hazardous in the extreme. Some concern is still felt about the size of the United States deficit. There is some concern that interest rates in the United States will not reduce further. Threats of trade wars still hang over the world. But while there have been signs, since the election, that the Government recognises much of what is said, its mini-Budget and its wages policy fail to meet the economic and social challenges before Australia.

The Government was, to its credit, going some way down the road to Damascus. It has now turned back and headed instead towards Babel, towards an edifice sure to collapse in a surfeit of rhetoric. The Treasurer's statement of last Thursday is convincing evidence that it has no idea how to address Australia's problems. I quote from the editorial of the Australian Financial Review last Friday, which states:

Rather than being a deeply considered statement, the Keating speech has to be considered only a ragbag of bits and pieces which reflect no coherent policy except a desire to be seen to be doing something about cutting back on the Budget deficit, while not actually doing very much.

The statement has done nothing for the economy. It does nothing to address the problem of the Budget deficit. The Treasurer assured us that a Budget deficit approaching $10 billion is 'not on'. Let me remind the House that such a deficit would have been abhorrent to the Opposition. We would not have let that happen. The Government, the Treasurer and the Opposition all know that the estimate of a $9.6 billion deficit for 1983-84 is one of the most fraudulent and one of the most politically inspired estimates in Australia's economic history. The Prime Minister has reacted to the so-called $9.6 billion fraud by throwing his hands in the air in fake moral outrage and by throwing his promises out of the window in economic outrage. What Australia wants is not drama. It does not want drama at all. It wants decisions and deeds. In discussing the deficit the Treasurer rightly pointed out that if fiscal policy is too expansionary, particularly at a time when recovery is in sight, it will place increased pressure on interest rates and, of course, on the balance of payments. He went on to say that any direct increases in employment from excessive government stimulus:
. . . would be offset-perhaps more than offset-by indirect falls in employment as private sector decisions were curtailed.

That is the Treasurer, evidently on the road to Damascus. But let us look at the figures and we will find that he has turned back. The net outcome of the mini- Budget is savings of only $27m to $28m. What the Treasurer did not shout to the nation was that his Medicare scheme will cost the Budget an additional $400m next year. That is not a figure dreamed up by the Opposition. That is the Treasurer's own estimate. If we make the charitable assumptions that Medicare will cost no more than that, an assumption which all but the most avid Labor supporter must doubt, then the Government's razor has saved just $27m or $28m. The Government cannot have it both ways. Either its $10 billion deficit overstates the true situation, in which case its passionate condemnation of the previous Government's alleged deficit is groundless and fraudulent, or its pruning exercise is hopelessly and dangerously inadequate. This is yet another example of so-called Hawkespeak. There are people on the Government benches who know the dangers of excessive economic stimulation but equally there are a large number of Ministers and Government back benchers who favour a strongly expansionary policy. The greater danger to Australia is that the expansionists will win the day. Labor's election program stated:
The principal thrust of Labor's economic strategy will be to . . . embrace the policies of expansion.

The fact is that a massive deficit would do irretrievable damage to the Australian economy. It would destroy the prospects for recovery. It would exacerbate inflation. It could drive up interest rates and the Government would snatch resources from a private sector hungry to invest-and it would open floodgates to massive wage increases. Obviously the Treasurer realises these realities. Why does the mini-Budget not reflect them? The mini-Budget gives us a clear indication that this is in fact a big spending government. But it shows a great deal more. It underlines the folly of the Government's wages policy. The Government now tells us that an immediate return to full quarterly wage indexation and a 2.2 per cent catch-up is consistent with its prices and incomes policy; it is consistent with its deal with the unions. That is what the Australian Council of Trade Unions is now demanding; that is what the Government will accept. We now know what the prices and incomes policy really is. To quote the business editor of the Age, it is:
A callous fraud on the unemployed.
I wholeheartedly agree with the Prime Minister's statement last December when he said:
There is nothing intrinsically important in a prices and incomes policy.

There certainly is not. It seems largely irrelevant-irrelevant above all to the interests of the unemployed. It is simply a document which says that the Government will agree to the demands of the ACTU executive. At first we were led to believe that it was a document which would guarantee wage restraint. The new Government and the unions said that during the election campaign. They said it at the National Economic Summit Conference. Then we learned that it unequivocally meant a return to full wage indexation next year but that catch-up would not take place until the economy could afford it. Next we heard that the Government would agree to a 3 per cent to 4 per cent wage increase this year. That concession was immediately grasped by the ACTU. It said that what the Government really meant was that there would be a return to full quarterly wage indexation this year. That is not where it ends, not by a long way. Suddenly, the ACTU says the economy has the capacitiy to pay for a catch-up. It wants a 2. 2 per cent increase for the March quarter this year. Is that consistent with wage restraint? Is that what employers want in order to compete internationally, in order to restore profitability, in order to create more jobs? The Prime Minister and the Treasurer say that this is consistent with the prices and incomes policy. I do not deny that. Any increase is consistent with that meaningless document.

We must not forget to mention the special cases. With them, payments are allowed beyond the demands of the ACTU executive. The prices and incomes policy says that there will be 'no extra claims except where special and extraordinary circumstances exist'. These special circumstances existed recently in the building industry. Building unions were granted increased allowances, which will push up cost in the industry and threaten jobs. I ask the House what was so special about those demands. The answer is simply that the union was taking industrial action in support of them. Therefore, every time unions take industrial action their demands will be a special case. Every time the Government will capitulate.

Mr Dolan's recent statement that the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission would put itself out of business if it did not grant the unions' demands was fully consistent with the so-called prices and incomes accord because if the unions took action, having lost their case before the Commission, the Government could buy peace by saying it was a special case. At the Summit the ACTU restated 'its unequivocal commitment to a centralised system of wage fixation'. That all seems a long time ago, for there is no special case for the unemployed. There is no so-called special case for their families or their futures. They foot the bill for the prices and incomes policy and they know it. The Prime Minister, the Government and the ACTU also know it. But clearly, they do not care. By abandoning the wage pause, the Government has done a deal with the unions rather than with the unemployed and it knows its deal will throw more out of work-100,000 more Australians will lose their jobs as a result of this Government's wages policy.

There is no economic or social case for an immediate return to full indexation and the Government knows it. The Government's defence seems to be that this is the only industrially realistic approach. The excuse is just not supported by the facts. The latest opinion poll on the need for a wages pause shows that 70 per cent of all Australians support its extension. Those people are not all members of the Liberal or National parties. They are not all employers or professional people. This opinion poll confirms that Australian people recognise the reality that continued wage restraint now is the only way to protect their living standards in the future; that we cannot distribute wealth before it is created. The poll confirms the view that all Australians realise that one person 's wage increase is the job of another Australian man or women; that Australians are willing to make sacrifices to give a fellow Australian the dignity of a job; and that the true measure of so-called consensus is the degree to which those in jobs are willing to make sacrifices for the unemployed. Does the Labor Party not have this kind of faith in the average Australian worker? Does it disagree with Sir Arvi Parbo who, at the Summit, said:
I believe that the Australian people would understand the problem and be willing to endure longer if the reason were properly explained to them.

Does the Labor Party not believe that it is the responsibility of the Government to protect the rights of all Australians, including the vulnerable and unorganised groups? The Treasurer said that to expect continued sacrifice from the employed to help the unemployed would be, to quote Samuel Johnson, 'a triumph of hope over experience'. We need not remind him that that is taken out of context. I would prefer to quote a much more relevant expert on the Australian economy, the late Sir Keith Campbell. At the Summit, he said:
If we genuinely care about the jobless and genuinely wish to incur discipline and sacrifice, we need to put together a scenario D.

That is, he advocated greater wage restraint than that advocated in all the scenarios considered by the Government. Even the New South Wales Premier, if we can still refer to him by that title-let us call him the Federal President of the Australian Labor Party, for he has not yet stood down from that position- said at the Summit that the Arbitration Commission needs 'to take account of the economy's capacity to pay'. Why is it then that the Government has abandoned these virtual truisms? It clearly does not care. It does not care about the unemployed, or about our industries. In essence, it does not care about Australia. The least the Australian people expect from governments is leadership . What has this Government done? It has allowed the ACTU to take the initiative in submissions to the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. The Government and the Australian people are now on the defensive. We are in the position of responding to a sectional claim. Bluntly put, that is just ineptness.

By encouraging excessive wages, the Government is doing nothing to ease the squeeze on business profits. This is in spite of the fact that the share of profits in gross domestic product has fallen to historically low levels. Yet the Government is doing nothing to encourage the resurgence in the private sector. It is the private sector which is vital to the provision of sustainable jobs. The Government has forgotten that the private sector directly employs 75 per cent of the Australian work force. It is the private sector which will provide 75 to 80 per cent of permanent new jobs. The private sector generates the economic growth which supports permanent employment in the public sector. It is the private sector which generates the economic growth to provide welfare payments.

TALK.START.PARA: —What evidence have you got for that?

—It is the private sector which the honourable member for Burke is dedicated to destroy. He seeks the destruction of the engine of economic growth in this country. Let us never forget that the level of public welfare which he espouses is directly dependent on private sector growth. Yet the honourable member for Burke would not only forget it, he would work by dint of dishonest intellectual argument to show the very antithesis. It is the private sector which must generate the export revenue necessary to sustain and improve our standard of living. Yet what has the Government done to encourage private enterprise?
—Nothing!

—Precisely. It has done absolutely nothing. Why has it done nothing? The answer is that it does not care; it does not care because it does not understand the needs of the private sector. If it cannot understand its needs, it cannot understand the needs of the economy. Let us take the example of small business, which employs around 70 per cent of the private sector work force. Clearly, there cannot be a recovery in Australia if there is no recovery in the small business sector. Yet what has this Government done? It promises to withdraw the investment allowance. In a time of high real interest rates this investment allowance is a key factor in generating investment and jobs. It breaks its promise to lower the tax burden on small business. It accedes to wage demands which it knows small business cannot absorb. It knows that wages are 50 per cent to 70 per cent of the total costs of small business. Therefore, it is not just the unemployed who will be victims of this Government's lack of compassion and understanding. It will also be all the bankrupt businesses.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us take the further example of manufacting, large or small. Manufacturing is most vulnerable to the chill winds of international competition. In 1982 the cost of employing a worker in the motor industry rose by over 25 per cent, including higher wages, shorter working hours and things such as workers compensation. Manufacturing just cannot afford a catch-up; neither can it afford an immediate return to full wage indexation. When will this Government and militant union leaders face these facts? From an industry policy point of view, the only measures which can work are those which make us cost-competitive with the rest of the world. That is axiomatic. The Government's determination to destroy the wages pause and another 100,000 jobs has made its job creation scheme necessary. Gone will be the financially responsible jobs created by savings from the wages pause. Gone will be the jobs created by wage restraint. What has already been put in its place? Seventy thousand jobs of only six months duration; jobs without any security, jobs without any durability, jobs without hope.

So the price of abandoning permanent jobs in favour of temporary jobs is extraordinarily high indeed. The typical Australian family, according to the Australian Taxpayers Association, will lose $8 a week. The Victorian Taxpayers Association puts the figure at $9 a week. Yet by simply maintaining the wages pause, more jobs would have been created than will be created by this mini- Budget, and middle Australia would have been spared this hardship. Families would not have lost their home loan interest rebates. Families would not have lost their health insurance tax rebates. Farmers would not have been hit by harder depreciation provisions at a time when nearly all of them are struggling to overcome the devastation of the drought. The elderly, the weakest sector in our community, would not have had their lives plunged into uncertainty by new means test provisions for pensions. The people of the Northern Territory and South Australia would not have to watch helplessly as the Alice Springs-Darwin railway is, in effect, abandoned. Even the Labor Premier of South Australia has condemned this decision.

So it comes down to this: This Government is just plain unreliable. If it had taken the permanent job route, the Government would not have had to abandon its mandate from the people, to abandon its election promises. It promised immediate tax cuts. Now it is taking at least eight bucks a week away from families. It promised to maintain the housing loan interest rebate, and now that has gone. It promised to cut taxes immediately. That has not happened. It promised that it would not means test pensions. Now it has done that. It promised to keep the Alice Springs-Darwin railway. Now it has destroyed any chance of its completion. It promised that the burden of hard economic decisions would be shared by all the community. Now the farmers are being told to pay for one-third of the savings of the mini-Budget. It is an absolute shame, and it is vintage Hawkespeak, as I have mentioned previously-say one thing and do another.

The Prime Minister says that he never tells a lie. What he does is tell half the truth. The Prime Minister hardly needs to be reminded, I suppose, in that context again that he promised-I shall read it-'no fistful of dollars to be snatched back after the election'. Now, he has done it, and the Australian people must be wondering who will be next for the chopping block. Compassion for those in need has been debased by a government making a desperate bid for power. People over the age of 70 must be wondering why they have been singled out to suffer. The Treasurer says that it is because the Government has not had time to look at other options. What kind of a reason is that for imposing this unfair share of the burden on the elderly?

This mini-Budget has a number of other features which will also do great harm to this country. First, by taking money away from families, it is encouraging further wage demands. The previous Government, in its last Budget, gave a typical family benefits worth $17 to $18 a week. One of the objectives of that Budget was to encourage wage restraint. Families had more in their pockets; they would demand less from the work place. These measures were introduced partly at the behest of the ACTU. The success of the wages pause was evidence of the success of that strategy. But this mini-Budget does the reverse; it reduces the living standards of most families. Many will be looking for compensation, obviously, in the form of wage increases. That will encourage still more unemployment. But we have long since given up looking to the Labor Party as the party which cares about the jobless. The Labor Party does not want to know about the need for the private sector to make profits. It will throw aside the nexus between profits and jobs. It does not want to know the harsh economic reality in our economy: That if one is not making profits, one cannot keep people in work; and if one does not create the climate for those profits to be made, one is exacerbating the unemployment situation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why don't you go on to something new?

—The honourable member will come out with the same old tired line. He will give us the socialist dogma that was out of date before it was even written into his party's platform. What about the dividend rebate? That is something that the honourable member would not want to know about because it relates to the private sector, again, and to Australians having a direct stake in their future. The mini-Budget has abolished the tax rebate on dividend income. That tax rebate, introduced in the last Budget, was designed to encourage Australians to take a greater share of their own economic development, to encourage them, as I have said, to buy a stake in the future of Australia. It was also a measure directed against the double taxation of company profits. But now the Government has abolished that concession. Here we go again, 'Let's hit them'. It is some accountant's form of leprosy to the other side, not something that will generate jobs. By abolishing this concession, profits will be taxed twice. Company tax must be paid; and then tax on dividends. But more importantly, the opportunity to involve more and more Australians in the development of their own country will be lost.

SPEECH.PARA: What about housing? The mini-Budget redirects and misdirects housing resources. It takes away the assistance to meet interest payments. As the Housing Industry Association said at the Summit:
For home buyers, the bottom line is interest rates.

It reduces the Government's flexibility to phase out assistance to home buyers if the need diminishes. It takes money away from the private housing sector to transfer it to public housing. It does nothing to help those in greatest need. What does the Government do? It abolishes a housing package which was warmly welcomed, not merely by the housing industry. But it decides to bring in some new measures and, apart from the relief that it alleges that this will give to first home buyers, this is allegedly going to stimulate the economy by people immediately placing orders and making contracts for new homes. What the Government overlooked was that this new scheme is not going to start until 1 October, so what happens to the economic stimulus? Does everyone have to wait until 1 October? Not thinking through the consequences of its actions seems to be symptomatic of so many decisions taken by this Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is temporarily inoperative.
—Temporarily inoperative; that sounds to be the case with what is alleged to be the truth from time to time on the other side.
—A houses pause.

—As the Leader of the National Party said, it is a houses pause. If that is the case, I would say: 'Take your filthy pause off most Australians'. Many people have bought homes on the basis that they will benefit from the home loan interest rate rebate scheme. Remember, during the election campaign Labor promised to retain the scheme. Many people must have thought Labor would be true to its word, but again it has broken its promises and again families will suffer . It will be a great hardship on families particularly-more vintage Hawkespeak.

SPEECH.PARA: Many weeks ago, when I became the Leader of the Opposition, I said that I would praise and support the Government when it acted wisely and with common sense. There have not been too many opportunities to do that and little in this mini- Budget falls into that category, but one decision does, and that is the decision to sell 49 per cent of Aussat Pty Ltd. I welcome the Treasurer's decision to transfer resources from the public to the private sector and more fully to use the money to help those in need. I hope this is only a first step. I look forward to future decisions of this kind, although I fear we will be waiting a long time for similar decisions.

I began my address by listing a number of fundamental economic objectives. In conclusion I return to them and measure this Government's policies against those yardsticks. The Government must endeavour to bring down inflation. Its wages policy and its policy speech commitment to expansionary monetary and fiscal policies give little hope it will succeed. The Government must endeavour to bring down interest rates. Its policies could well drive real interest rates up. The Government must encourage investment. Its wages policy, its commitment to expansionary monetary and fiscal policies and its hostility to foreign investment will not do that. The Government must endeavour to make our industries more competitive and more profitable. Again, its subservience to the wage demands of the union leadership will have the reverse effect. What is required of this Government, what is required for the Australian people, are national solutions, not the promotion of sectional interests or subservience to those sectional interests that are so often put before the Government with the purchase and leverage that quite clearly they have on it. At the end of the day the actions of this Government must encourage the creation of more permanent jobs. While this Government's job creation schemes will create temporary jobs, its deal with the unions, so much preferred to a deal with the unemployed, will throw 100,000 more Australians out of full time work.

TALK.START.PARA: —Disgraceful.

—Absolutely. The Government's economic strategy, for all its rhetoric , for all its promises of recovery and reconstruction, does not address the fundamental challenges before Australia. What is more, it was given the trust of Australians and, in particular, the trust of middle Australia. At a stroke that trust has been destroyed. Promises have been cynically tossed aside. Middle Australia has not been helped, it has been sent a bill-$8 a week for an average family and very much more for some. So this, in the third month of this Government, is already a record of shame.
—Mr Deputy Speaker, I second the amendment and reserve my right to speak.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a positive pleasure to have the opportunity of following the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Peacock) in speaking in this debate. I think his period in that office may prove to be quite transitory. He was given by the Government an hour to reply-mercifully he took only 45 minutes. He might have been better served if he had confined his remarks to 20 minutes because at least then the speech could have had the appearance of coherence and tight structure. His speech failed to note that this Government has been in office only since 11 March this year. We were elected on 5 March. We have been in office for only a period of nine weeks. How absurd and how hypocritical it is for the Leader of the Opposition to talk about unemployment and blame us for doing little about it. We have between 700, 000 and 800,000 unemployed-a figure which grew steadily under the seven miserable years of the Fraser Government. Two of its luminaries are now on the Opposition front bench-the Leader of the Opposition and the Deputy Leader of the Opposition, the most hapless Treasurer this Commonwealth ever had.

SPEECH.PARA: How hypocritical too for the Leader of the Opposition to claim that the mini- Budget was an affront against the private sector of the economy. I remind him that the spirit of consensus that developed during the National Economic Summit Conference has remained with us. The mini-Budget has been endorsed by such disparate elements of the economy as the Australian Council of Trade Unions and the Confederation of Australian Industry. Let me quote what the Confederation of Australian Industry-the spokespeople for the private sector of the economy-said about the mini-Budget.
Opposition members interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —In the circumstances it is more representative than this discredited Opposition. On 19 May, under the heading 'Government's Economic Statement', it said--
—We don't want to hear it.
—Yes, members of the Opposition do not want to hear it, but they are going to have to listen. These are the words of the Confederation of Australian Industry, not mine:

SPEECH.PARA: Although it imposes additional sacrifices on some sections of the private sector, the Confederation of Australian Industry believes that, in broad terms, the Government's Economic Statement is responsible.

An initial assessment suggests that the Economic Statement is a constructive and genuine attempt to simultaneously fight the twin evils of inflation and unemployment, and contain the increase in the Budget deficit, while also providing some stimulus to economic recovery.
