I interpolate that these are not our words, these are the words of the CAI leadership:

Introduction of the means-test in principle for social welfare payments is in line with CAI recommendations, although CAI believes that this approach should be extended beyond old-age pensioners and assistance for acquisition of family dwellingss.

CAI is concerned, however, of outside implications of the major changes in taxation of retirement benefits. This could adversely affect not only individuals who entered existing retirement schemes in good faith, but also discourage the contribution to private investment capital formulation by an important segment of the private sector.

That is being looked at at the moment by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) and the Minister for Finance (Mr Dawkins). I expect additional information very soon. I thought it was so extraordinary to find the Leader of the Opposition saying, as part of his gimcrack rhetoric, that 'the Government was making a desperate bid for power'. I had the illusion that we were in power, that we had actually won. We have been treated to some extraordinary examples of wit today, but with more of an aldermanic than a Voltairean quality. The spirit of the Summit is still with us. I simply remind honourable members of how significant that Summit Conference was. The primary aim of it really was to bind up the wounds--

TALK.START.PARA: —Tell us about the mini-Budget.

—The Leader of the Opposition barely referred to the mini-Budget. His speech was a general and very ill-informed ramble about government policy. He did not refer to the other elements in the cognate debate. He did not mention the Economic Planning Advisory Council Bill, which is a very important result of the Summit. EPAC will perpetuate many of the things which the Summit is--
—Stick around; there will be some more.

—Well, I am glad to hear that somebody else is going to draw attention to it because EPAC is a very important element of ensuring that that consensus that was brought about at the Summit Conference continues over the next few years. We are going to have another mini-Summit in August on Australia' s technological future, just as there was one on the housing sector in late April. In August we will be holding a meeting at which a number of groups not represented at the Summit will have an opportunity to make a contribution to deciding how Australia can lift its economic game.
—Are you going to invite me?

—No, you lack the intellectual qualities. That excludes you straightaway. First, the universities, colleges of advanced education and the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation will be represented . The professions will be broadly represented and also very significant areas in technology based industry. All these groups are, in the spirit of the Summit, anxious to ensure that the spirit of consensus which we have had since April continues. Honourable members will remember that the reason Australia is in this desperate economic position is the economic vandalism of honourable members sitting opposite over a very long period. There have been seven years of decline . When the Liberal Party came to office at the end of 1975, Australia ranked number 11 of member nations in the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development in terms of income. By the time it left office Australia ranked number 16.

SPEECH.PARA: The Leader of the Opposition had the hide to keep talking about the need for Australian industry to become competitive. He spoke as though the non- competitive nature of Australian industry was entirely related to wage rates and nothing else. It is absolutely fraudulent to say that. The tragedy of Australian industry is that from a structural point of view it was never designed to be competitive. It was designed simply to provide for Australian domestic markets and nothing else. That is one of our tragedies. When we look at heavy industry, the commanding heights of the Australian economy, in coal, copper, aluminium uranium, motor manufacturing, food processing, computers, drugs, chemicals, plastics, petrol and advertising, what do they all have in common? They are all overwhelmingly under foreign control. Because they are overwhelmingly under foreign control it is absurd to think that it will be possible for Australian industry to compete internationally. It is not designed to do that.

It takes a very fertile imagination to conceive of the Ford company in Australia or even the Mazda company in Australia competing with Ford in the United States of America or Mazda in Japan. They are not designed to do that. Liberal and National Party members have been in office for 30 of the last 33 years. They have to take the responsibility for our failure to develop an industry which can aim at international markets. One cannot imagine Hoechst Australia being intended to compete with Hoechst in West Germany or Philips in Australia competing with Philips in Holland. That is not what they are about. It is absolutely hypocritical of the Leader of the Opposition to insist that wage factors are the only consideration. High wage rates are destructive when linked with low productivity and high unit cost in areas which normally would have some potential exports. But the essential factor on the non-competitive nature of an industry is not wage levels alone, but the structural deficiencies of the industry that is, being inward looking, foreign owned and essentially defensive in its nature.

We have heard again the tired old cliche which simply states that one man's wage rise is another man's job. This is a dangerous half truth, essentially based on the acceptance of the concept of a static economy. If there is a static economy and a factor on the wages side of the equation is added, something may have to be lopped off the employment side. But if we move in the direction of a dynamic economy those factors do not arise. Sweden, for example, has far higher wage rates than we do, with an industrial working week of 30.2 hours. But we cannot say, as a result of that: 'Oh well, Sweden has dealt itself out of the game. There is no way that Sweden can possibly make any contribution to the international economy'. Sweden, with its population of only 8.3 million-barely half of ours-with its limited raw materials, a short industrial working week of 30.2 hours and higher wages nevertheless has a gross domestic product which is 54.5 per cent higher per capita than Australia's. It has succeeded in penetrating world markets because it has used its skills to the highest level and because Swedish quality is traditional throughout the world. The previous Government, after seven years of industrial vandalism, simply turned Australia into a combination of an industrial hospital and an industrial museum. No wonder so few of our industries are designed to compete. That is another tragedy.

Honourable members opposite have had the crust to criticise when they recognise that the nature of the mini-Budget is to try to overcome some of the fraudulent things that they put in the August 1982 Budget. I think it was impudent for the Leader of the Opposition to respond in the way he did. The Budget in August last year was brought down for one purpose only: To provide an easy shift to an early election. It was quite obvious when we came to office in March that all the important and difficult decisions had been delayed. After August last year and after the then Prime Minister's retirement from the field because of ill health the previous Government slept. It was flying on automatic pilot in its last few months. It is quite obvious that if it had been re-elected it would have introduced a mini-Budget perhaps even more severe than this one. There were obvious measures of redistribution in this mini-Budget.

TALK.START.PARA: —Will it be more severe in August?

—Wait and see. This Government has a strong commitment to make all sectors of the economy healthier. We believe that the private sector has performed poorly in recent years. Although the previous Government claimed to speak on behalf of the private sector it has very little to be proud of. It has a very feeble record. I believe that the results next weekend in the Bruce by- election in the home city of the Leader of the Opposition will demonstrate that the people of Australia have accepted the mini-Budget in the spirit in which it is offered. There has been an amazing degree of support. Certainly, people have been hurt. The claim was made that average families will have to pay more each week. There is a general recognition of that, but there is also a recognition that the economic vandals who put our economy in its present state were members of the Government thrown out on 5 March. There is also a broad recognition that the community will have to make sacrifices. We want to make sure that those sacrifices are equitably based. We attempted to establish equity instead of slugging the poor, the defenceless and the people at the lowest end of the socio -economic pyramid. That is why I believe that the electors of Bruce will support the Government on Friday because they recognise--
—The election is on Saturday.

—Next Friday is the last time we can talk about it; Saturday is polling day. It will be a dramatic endorsement of what has been done by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the Treasurer. We have had seven lean years. I believe that the Hawke Government has begun a decade at least of very significant growth in Australia.
—Order! The honourable gentleman's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have much pleasure in seconding the amendment moved by the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Peacock) and having the opportunity to talk on the economic statement delivered by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) last Thursday night. That statement is truly a document for all seasons. It both criticises the alleged fiscal irresponsibility of the former Government in the last Budget and, at the same time, talks approvingly of the fiscal stimulus contained in that Budget. It laments the size of the prospective deficit for next year; yet the net effects of the fiscal decisions announced last Thursday night do nothing to change that deficit. The statement asserts that the Government will not indulge in wholesale policy reversals; yet it achieves the greatest reversal of all by repudiating the very expansionary economic policy on which the Australian Labor Party was elected. It professes concern about the effect of a bigger Budget deficit on interest rates; yet it announces a major expansion of State and semi-government borrowings which will have precisely the same effect on those interest rates as a larger deficit. Finally, the statement was delivered against a background of the allegedly horrendous fiscal inheritance of the Government; yet it is silent both on the very growth and activity forecasts which underpin that charge against the former Government and on the key question of what the forecast deficit for 1983-84 has become following the statement.

SPEECH.PARA: This is the first comprehensive statement of economic policy delivered to this Parliament on behalf of the new Government. It is, therefore, by any measure a statement of singular importance as a guide not only to the Government's thinking on economic policy but also as a guide to the type of economic debate and analysis which will take place both in this Parliament and throughout the Australian community over the next three years. It is one thing for the Government to call together a National Economic Summit Conference, to provide that meeting with a welter of material and analysis about the Australian economy and to produce a communique from that Conference which, as the events of recent weeks in the wages area have sharply illustrated, can be all things to all men, but it is entirely another thing for the Government to account to the Parliament both for its economic policies and economic behaviour. This statement has attracted, and deservedly so, a high degree of interest and scrutiny not only from the Opposition but also from the entire Australian community, not just in the sense that the statement is one which affects all of us in different ways but also because we are all rightly concerned about the present condition and future direction of the Australian economy.

There can be no argument that the Government faces a daunting task in the management of the Australian economy over the next three years. The lot of economic managers in the world at the present time has been rarely more difficult. To the extent that the Government honestly and effectively confronts and deals with the economic problems facing Australia, it will have our support. In common with virtually every country in the Western industrialised world, Australia is currently experiencing stagnant economic growth, low output and high unemployment. Our inflation rate is uncomfortably higher than that of our major trading partners. Our major objective, but not our only objective, must remain that of reducing Australia's inflation rate to the level of or even desirably lower than the inflation rates of our major trading partners. In addition, Australia still experiences the consequences of the catastrophic drought of the last few years. Although that drought has largely broken, its effects will be felt for perhaps years into the future not only by farmers but also by non-farm producers whose incomes have been affected by the drought.

Although there are sharply divergent views as to causation, I think it is common ground now that the effects of the international recession and the drought have been greatly compounded in Australia by the wages explosion of 1981 -82. It is against this background and as a response to these problems that I believe this economic statement can best be judged. The Government at long last has apparently accepted the severe impact of the international recession upon the Australian economy. At last it has abandoned its rhetoric of years past that Australia's economic problems were almost the exclusive fault of the former Government and owed very little indeed to international economic conditions. This is hardly surprising in view of the facts. The more recent survey of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development shows that the average gross national products of member countries for 1982 fell by 0.5 per cent. Naturally, Australia's gross national products also fell, with the drought, in our case, making things infinitely worse.

One of the most striking features of the whole statement of the Treasurer was the extent to which he has either endorsed the former Government's analysis of the economy, and the causes of our present difficulties as put forward during the election campaign, or repudiated the economic platform on which his party was elected. The Treasurer and some of his colleagues appear to have derived more pleasure since the statement was delivered from media claims that the statement implements policies of the former Government than they have from the extent to which it implements the stated policy of the Australian Labor Party. Not only has this statement repudiated former policies of the Labor Party and confirmed in many respects the former Government's analysis of our economic ills but also, even more importantly, it has illustrated the fundamental hypocrisy of the Labor Party's attack on the former Government's economic performance.

If the Hawke Government really believed, as the Treasurer said last Thursday night, that the former Liberal Government went beyond the limits of fiscal responsibility in increasing commitments to outlays and tax expenditures and reducing taxation through last year, why did it not do something positive about this alleged recklessness in last Thursday night's statement? Why did not the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) arrest the alleged economic vandalism of which he and his Ministers have spoken with increasing shrillness in recent days? Why did they not have the courage, if they really believed those allegations, to increase personal taxation in last Thursday night's mini-Budget and thus put into reverse the changes that were announced in the last Budget? The Treasurer knows, as well as I do, that the real fiscal stimulus of the last Budget was contained in the personal taxation reductions which he admits will have a full- year effect of about $3,000m in 1983-84. I will tell honourable members why they did not do that. They did not do it because when the last Budget was brought down the Labor Party argued that our taxation reductions did not go far enough. The former Leader of the Opposition (Mr Hayden) said they were mean.

The present Prime Minister ran around the country demanding a deficit this financial year 50 per cent higher than we are likely to have and the equivalent of 4 per cent to 5 per cent of gross domestic product. He told us to throw away our calculators. He told us to forget about the size of the deficit. He wanted a deficit this year of $6,500m, without a care in the world as to the implications of that size of deficit for next year's budgetary problem. The true position is that in Opposition the Labor Party called for a much more expansionary Budget last year than the former Governement was willing to bring down. Not one member of the Australian Labor Party was opposed to the size of last year's Budget deficit. Again, in the election campaign, the Labor Party made promises to the tune of $4,000m, derided the unwillingness of the coalition to offer further taxation cuts and ignored our warnings that the economy could not afford what Labor had offered during that election campaign.

The deterioration in the Budget position for next year, about which the Prime Minister and his colleagues have so piously wrung their hands in recent weeks, overwhelmingly has been due to the sharp deterioration in the economy which occurred during the latter half of last year and which the former Government fully acknowledged and disclosed. The final proof that the Government accepts this analysis is the fact it has taken no action in his mini-Budget to overturn the major thrust of last year's Budget. It simply cannot have it both ways. It cannot now say that last year's Budget was reckless and irresponsible yet, by its very inaction, do virtually nothing to change it. It cannot, as the Treasurer piously does at page 15 of his statement, claim that the full year cost of the taxation concessions in last year's Budget amounting to around $3, 000m was suddenly discovered when the Labor Party was elected to power. This fact was fully disclosed in the Budget Papers last year and spelt out in great detail. In fact a significant part of the present Prime Minister's speech on the Budget last year was devoted to the full year effect of the tax concessions announced in that Budget. Despite this acknowledg- ment, he committed himself to another $4,000m of spending during the election campaign and having won office, now has the effrontery, along with his colleagues, to say: 'We never realised it was going to cost so much next year'.

The major fiscal policy announcements in last Thursday night's statement, with the exception of the changed housing arrangements, leave virtually untouched the measures introduced by the former Government in the last Budget. When allowance is made, as my colleague the Leader of the Opposition pointed out, for the impact in 1983-84 of the Budget cost of operating Medicare of approximately $ 400m, the projected Budget savings in that year from last Thursday night's package is virtually zero. It would appear that the net yield from the Hawke Government's assault upon the alleged vandalism of the last Budget is no more than $28m or a farcical 0.005 per cent of total Budget outlays.

I suspect that the Treasurer is really privately rather happy with the fiscal stimulus contained in last year's Budget. I think he is fairly pleased with the effect that last year's Budget is having on the economy at present and I suspect that he rather believes that the fiscal balance in last year's Budget was probably about right. He notes rather approvingly in his statement that one of the reasons the Government expects some improvement in economic activity next financial year is in fact that very same fiscal stimulus.

Indeed, the Treasurer at page 9 of his statement has nominated six reasons why he expects there to be some improvement in economic activity next financial year . Five of these reasons are in no way derived from the economic policies or actions of the present Government. I make no particular point of that except to put it down for the record. The final reason and of fundamental importance is the question of future moderation of income claims. Of course, that is a matter of fierce contention. However, one thing is clear. Such moderation as has occurred to date in income claims has been largely the result of the former Government's initiative in introducing the wage pause and not because of the prices and incomes accord sponsored by the present Government.

As the Leader of the Opposition has already pointed out, last Thursday night's statement is largely irrelevant to the issue of unemployment. The real economic battleground as far as unemployment is concerned is the area of wages policy. What happens to wage increases in Australia over the next 12 months will have an impact on levels of unemployment many times greater than the total impact of the Treasurer's statement of last Thursday night. I do not say that in denigration of the statement but it is an obvious declaration of fact that the real ambit and the real battleground on which the question of unemployment is to be resolved is outside the ambit of last Thursday night's statement. We must therefore keep that statement in perspective. As an exercise in job creation and as an exercise in reducing unemployment, the statement is largely meaningless and irrelevant. The point needs to be made again and made clearly: The evidence presented by the Government to the National Economic Summit Conference showed beyond argument that the longer the wage pause continued the greater would be the improvement in the employment situation, the sharper the fall in inflation and the faster the rate of economic growth.

The Government's response to this statement of fact and to the Opposition's continued support for the wage pause, and also the support of many respected industrialists, is to say that it is industrially unreal to try to maintain the wage pause at least until the end of this year. In taking such a stance the Government not only puts industrial harmony ahead of the interests of the unemployed but also underestimates, as the Leader of the Opposition pointed out, the willingness of those in work to accept sacrifices in helping those out of work. A recent public opinion survey revealed that approximately 70 per cent of those interviewed supported the maintenance of the wage pause at least until the end of 1983.

Despite its acknowledgments about the importance of profitability in the private sector, the Government seems unwilling to take the final leap and acknowledge that in present economic conditions the only way profitability can be rebuilt and the growth in unemployment checked is for those in work to accept nothing short of a real reduction in income. The restoration of private sector profitability is not something merely to be mentioned when representatives of the business community are present; it lies at the very heart of the solution to our unemployment problem. It cannot be painlessly achieved. Any objective analysis of the Australian economy over the past 20 years will show very clearly that as real wages have risen business profitability has declined and as business profitability has declined unemployment has risen. In the 1950s and 1960s there was a relatively constant share of profits to gross domestic product of around 17 per cent. There was also a relatively constant but consistently low level of unemployment. But between 1972 and 1975 the profit share of business fell dramatically and unemployment rose. It was not until the late 1970s that the profit share started to rise again, returning to a level of about 15 per cent. As a result, in an 18-month period towards the end of the 1970s, something like 250,000 additional jobs were created. However, with the recent wage explosion, the profits share has again fallen drastically and is now less than 13 per cent-an historical low. As the Leader of the Opposition has already pointed out, the Treasurer's statement last Thursday night added to the already long list of broken promises of the Hawke Labor Government. I am sure the overwhelming majority of the Australian people would wish that the existing health care arrangements remain unaltered and many hundreds of thousands of those people will bitterly resent the Government's premature termination of the health insurance rebate despite the explicit promises from the Prime Minister that it would be left untouched until the new Medicare arrangements came into force. This surely will become one of the more notorious of the many broken promises of this Prime Minister.

This statement, and those supporting it, contain some truly astonishing contradictions, inconsistencies and omissions. The Minister for Housing and Construction (Mr Hurford) says that the single most important thing which can be done to stimulate greater housing activity is to reduce interest rates. Yet the major policy decision of the Government announced last Thursday night in the area of housing was to announce an effective increase in interest rates of about 1 1/2 per cent through the abolition of the taxation rebate. What inconsistency can exceed that? Here again both the Minister for Housing and Construction and the Prime Minister have recently adopted, and I welcome it, an argument of the former Government that higher deficits lead to higher interest rates. Yet in the very statement we are debating the Treasurer has announced that at the next Loan Council meeting the Commonwealth will encourage the States and their semi- government authorities to borrow much larger sums. He has virtually guaranteed a blow-out in the borrowing demands of the States and their semi-government authorities.

This must put greater pressure on financial markets and must therefore, using the very argument of the Prime Minister only last weekend and of his Housing Minister this morning, exert upward pressure on interest rates because it is the total public sector borrowing requirement and not just the Budget deficit component of that requirement which competes with private sector demand for loanable funds in our financial market. A $1,000m addition to the semi-goverment borrowing program will have precisely the same interest rate effect as a $1,000m addition to the Budget deficit. It will be no answer, as I anticipate the Government may well argue, that semi-government authorities will be given greater freedom to borrow overseas. Quite apart from the exchange risk considerations, which are very important in themselves, greater overseas borrowing by semi-government authorities adds directly to the domestic money supply. If in fact the Government intends-as it says it will, and I hope it does -to run a firm monetary policy, it will need to sell more government paper to soak up the additional liquidity created by these increased overseas borrowings. This, in turn, will bring us back to square one and exert further upward pressure on interest rates.

On the subject of monetary policy, I believe that some of the Treasurer's comments in last Thursday night's statement were downright deceptive and dishonest. The Treasurer knows full well that when the former Government left office the growth in M3 for the 12 months to February was 10.6 per cent, which was within the target range announced in the previous Budget. The fact, as he says, that the target was virtually out of reach by March is due largely to the sins of omission on his part during that month. The truth is that M3 rose dramatically, from February's 10.6 per cent to 12.4 per cent for the 12 months ended March 1983-by far the largest rise for something like seven or eight years . One has to go back to the 1972-75 period to find a jump as high as that. The bulk of the March rise was due to the massive capital inflow which followed the March devaluation. If the Treasurer denies this, let him have a look at what the Treasury had to say on page 20 of its own economic round-up for April. It said:

The devaluation produced an immediate and marked turnaround in private sector foreign exchange transactions. This considerably eased domestic liquidity conditions and most short term rates fell sharply immediately after the devaluation.
Despite this, the Treasury points out:
The non-bank take-up of Commonwealth Government securities had only a minor overall influence on liquidity conditions in March.

The present Government simply did not sell enough government securities during that period. The real truth is that in the two and a half months this Government has been in office it has allowed the money supply to grow quite rapidly because it has wanted to procure for political reasons reductions in interest rates. It now belatedly realises that this is not appropriate and has made a thoroughly welcome decision to hold a large bond tender of $1,500m. The only problem is that nobody has got around to telling the Minister for Housing and Construction that there has been a change in the Government's policy. It is therefore quite discreditable of the Treasurer to seek to excuse his own monetary laxity by attacking the former Government on this score.

It is astonishing that a statement of this importance, from a government which prides itself on access to relevant information and open government, should make no reference to the latest forecasts of economic growth available to the Government. This incredible omission assumes greater importance in the light of the debate we have had in recent weeks about the projected size of next year's deficit. It is an indisputable fact that the level of economic growth next financial year will have a profound effect on the size of that year's deficit. The entirely speculative and much used figure of $9.6m was based upon a growth forecast for the next year of a mere 0.5 per cent, yet the Government's favoured scenario, scenario A, as presented to the National Economic Summit Conference, assumes growth of 2.7 per cent in that year. At the weekend there were Press reports to the effect that next year the Government expected growth to be much higher, around 4 per cent. Why, then, did the Treasurer not mention a growth figure in his statement? He would have received one; I know that. Why will he not make it in public? His refusal to make it public only confirms the view I have had for a long time-that he wishes to perpetuate the myth that $9.6 billion was ever a realistic bench-mark against which the performance of the Government, in achieving what ultimately proves to be the deficit for next year, can be judged. It is open to the Treasurer to reply to this. I hope that he does.

The Treasurer has no credentials to issue challenges to the Opposition about alternative economic policy. Despite this being the first major economic statement of the Hawke Labor Government to this Parliament, the Ministers involved have given a totally incomplete account of themselves. They have not provided a growth forecast, they have not provided a deficit forecast and they have not provided an inflation forecast. They have repudiated the economic policy on which they were elected but they cannot decide whether last year's Budget was either good or bad. They are indulging in irresponsible, speculative comments about future movements in interest rates. The Minister for Housing and Construction is particularly vulnerable on this count. He has no grounds on which to justify his wild predictions that housing interest rates are about to fall. I do not believe that anybody, particularly the electors of Bruce, will be deluded by that sort of totally misleading, totally deceptive and totally unfounded political prediction.

The Government will waste $400m of taxpayers' money next year through the needless introduction of the new Medicare arrangements. I believe the Government would have been better advised to apply any gross savings in last Thursday night 's exercise towards a reduction in the size of the Budget deficit. As is usual with Labor governments, this economic statement diverts money from the private sector to the public sector. It is a statement on social policy rather than a statement on the economy. By having no overall economic impact, this statement raises real concerns about the future. Government Ministers tell us that further measures will be taken in the Budget. That remains to be seen. The fact is that the failure of the statement to alter the deficit means that Australia faces at Budget time either a huge rise in taxes and a big cut in spending programs or an excessive reliance on monetary policy which would push up interest rates-that is , of course, if the Government really does care about the size of the deficit. On all of the facts, it demonstrably does not.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown Mr R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: -The measures that the House is considering at present represent the most recent part of a program which the Government has undertaken since it was elected on 5 March to bring about a reversal in the type of situation which had developed in Australia and to get Australia moving again. The House is having a cognate debate on the economic statement on the state of the economy, the housing policy initiatives which have been announced, the Community Employment Bill introduced by the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations (Mr Willis) and a Bill to establish an Economic Planning Advisory Council. One would be forgiven for believing, as a result of the contribution made by the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard), the former Treasurer in the former Government, with all the evidence that should have been available to the former Government and to those who acted as the architects for its economic policies, that they would have at least learnt that not only their approach was wrong but also their understanding was deficient, the policies that they attempted to put into place were ill-devised and ill-designed to meet the challenges that Australia faced during those years, and that the policies the former Government put into effect were responsible for exacerbating the situation that Australia was experiencing.

SPEECH.PARA: It is not possible, of course, to go through all the individual issues that were raised by the honourable member for Bennelong, who preceded me in this debate. But the honourable member did say, in part, that the present Government was repudiating the economic policies on which it was elected. I think what we need to do is to consider the essential elements of the economic policies upon which this Government was elected. Let us not lose sight of those essential elements when we are looking at the possibility of some form of modification being built into the general approach of this Government as a result of the quite disastrous economic and budgetary position which this Government inherited .

I remind the honourable member for Bennelong and honourable members generally of something of which I reminded them on the most recent occasion on which I spoke in a debate in this House. I refer to the fact that the present Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) in the week preceding the election on 5 March made it perfectly clear, spelt out to the Australian people in very clear terms that if the reality proved to be that both the former Treasurer and the former Prime Minister had distorted and misrepresented the truth, if it became apparent that the Australian community and the then Opposition had been less than well advised by the former Government and if, in the light of that and the decisions made at the National Economic Summit Conference it became apparent to the new Government that some modifications of its policies was necessary, those modifications would be made. Let us make no mistake about it, that was more than adequately spelt out. The Australian people, before they cast their vote on 5 March, knew that if the situation we inherited proved to be other than what we had been given to understand it would be, some modification may be necessary.

On previous occasions I have indicated that it may well be necessary for us to document the development of all of those circumstances which finally brought us to the point where we did become informed of the type of fiscal position the Hawke Labor Government was going to inherit. When did we become informed of that ? When finally was that advice available to the new Government? This did not occur in the week prior to the election on 5 March; not even on 5 March itself when the Australian people were casting their vote, showing their overwhelming and massive support for the Hawke Labor Government. We did not even know at that time the significance, the ultimate reality, of the disastrous fiscal position into which the previous Government had led this Parliament and this nation. We did not know that until the week following the election.

How fortuitous it was that even the former Treasurer himself did not know until a quarter to six in the evening of the day preceding the election that the Budget deficit for the next year was going to be $9.6 billion. How fortuitous it was not only for the Treasurer but also perhaps for the Department of the Treasury and the Secretary to the Treasury that that information suddenly became known in the dying hours of the last day before 5 March. But what had been the circumstances which preceded this? On about 7 March, a couple of days after the election had been held, two similar articles-one in the Newcastle Herald by a correspondent Jane Eyre and the other in the Sydney Morning Herald by that newspapers' correspondent Jenni Hewett-referred to Mr Howard's February statement that the estimated deficit for 1983-84 would be higher than this year' s deficit, which at that time was being spoken of as being in the vicinity of $4 billion. The former Treasurer in his February statement said:
. . . some estimates have put it as high as $6 billion.
He said 'some estimates', and I ask honourable members to keep those words in mind as I read the statements which follow that one. Jane Eyre's article continued:
At the same time (i.e. in late February), Mr Howard asserted that under Labor-
If a Labor government were to come into power-
that next year's deficit could be as high as $10 billion.
Of course, the then Treasurer had been well and sufficiently advised at that time-late February--

TALK.START.PARA: —Oh, no.

—Oh, yes indeed. In early February the former Treasurer knew that the projected deficit for next year was at least $8 billion. What was the former Treasurer's knowledge and understanding at the time he used the figure of $6 billion that was used during the election campaign? On Channel 9's Sunday program on 13 March the former Treasurer in the former Government admitted that he knew the deficit for next year would start at around $8 billion long before he used the figure of $6 billion during the election campaign. If my contribution to this debate is to be disputed, let me quote the actual words that were used by the former Treasurer. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: I was given some indication of a very general kind in the early part of this year that the deficit for next year might approach double what it was looking like being for this year.

At that time it was looking like being $4 billion for this year. If we double that figure we get an amount of $8 billion. So that was known early this year. The former Treasurer received an informal note from the Treasury before the election was called informing him that the 1983-84 deficit would begin--

TALK.START.PARA: —That is not right. I'll show you the minute.

—I will stand corrected. I am quoting from a newspaper report. If in fact that informal note did not indicate to the former Treasurer that the 1983-84 deficit would begin at around double the $4 billion forecast as the outcome for this financial year, I will be quite happy to be corrected. I would not deliberately misrepresent the position.

SPEECH.PARA: In the week following the election the former Treasurer admitted that the $6 billion deficit figure for 1983-84 that he had used during the campaign-of course, as we became aware, that was an underestimate of $3.6 billion of the figure that was being presented by the Treasury in the last week prior to the election-was his own figure and was not based on Treasury advice. In the first days of the week following the Federal election on 5 March he was confronted during, I think, about a 35-minute Press conference and was quoted as saying then:
I don't accept that I just made it up.
That was the figure of $6 billion-
I think that somebody who has been Treasurer for five years is entitled . . . to give some order of magnitude based upon one's own understanding.

How does that stand with the suggestion that was made initially by the former Treasurer that some estimates have put it as high as $6 billion? There were not some estimates; there was one estimate-it was the former Treasurer's estimate. But the estimate that he made was not even based on the advice he received from the Department of the Treasury. He grabbed it out of the air, knowing the danger of releasing, immediately before the election, a projected deficit figure that was in the vicinity of $8 billion or $9 billion. He revealed that he had first found out about the $9 billion figure five days before the election. The elections were to be held on the Saturday and on the Monday before he was advised by the Treasury that the projected deficit for 1983-84 would be in the vicinity of $9 billion. The final figure, $9.6 billion, was not disclosed until the very convenient hour of a quarter to six on Friday of that week. I am not blaming the former Treasurer for that.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am very pleased to hear that.

—The honourable gentleman received the information. What I am concerned about-and I make no apologies for referring to it-is the fortuitous time at which that information was provided to him. I repeat, on the Monday prior to the election the former Treasurer was advised that the 1983-84 deficit would be in the vicinity of $9 billion. The former Treasurer has revealed that the $9.6 billion figure was confirmed in a phone call at a quarter to six on Friday, 4 March, the evening before the election.
—How many times are you going to use these notes, Bob?

—I will probably use them for at least the next three years. That incredible performance, the falsification and concealment perpetrated by the former Government, the former Prime Minister and the former Treasurer, has given me sufficient running in this place for the next three years. But I will give the former Treasurer some credit. I understand-it has been stated as well in the media-that such was his concern about the significance of that information that either he or his office, on two occasions after the Monday of the week prior to the Federal election, sought advice from the office of the former Prime Minister, the Right Honourable John Malcolm Fraser, the former member for Wannon. In effect, the former Treasurer asked the former Prime Minister: 'Will we divulge this important information to the Australian people so that, when they vote next Saturday, they will be as well informed as they can be about the fiscal position that the next Government will inherit? Should we advise the Australian people; should we take the Australian people into our confidence; or should we conceal this information?' What was the answer given by the former member for Wannon, the former Prime Minister, the Right Honourable John Malcolm Fraser, on both occasions, the advice that came back to the Treasurer's office was: 'Do not reveal the information'.

TALKER.NAME: Mr ANTHONY
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —This is the second occasion on which the Australian people have had an opportunity to gauge the sort of leadership that this nation will get from the Hawke Government . The first was the occasion of the National Economic Summit Conference, when we witnessed a very clever exercise, the outcome of which was the sabotaging of the wages pause, the continuation of which was absolutely necessary if we were to handle our economic problems. Instead, the Government produced a prices and incomes accord which has turned out to be nothing more than what the unions want to interpret it as. Every day that agreement seems to be falling further into tatters. A mini-Budget has been brought down, one that opts for the easy, opportunist approach to the very serious problems that face this nation. It does not provide the strong, resolute, determined leadership that the difficult circumstances of the day demand.

SPEECH.PARA: Apparently, the Australian Labor Party believes that it can treat the Australian people as fools. That is the only conclusion that one can come to after its performance at the Summit and the introduction of this mini-Budget. Promise after promise has been broken. Minister after Minister has blundered. The Government has see-sawed from inaction to panic. As it stumbles from one day to the next, from one disaster to the next, it snaps back at anybody who seeks to question its activities, its bungling and complete incompetence. Any sort of consistency on the part of this Government is very difficult to find. That is not very surprising when the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) does not consult his colleagues and, in turn, they do not consult their colleagues. In fact, the Caucus has become practically a social club of the Parliament.

But there has been one shred of consistency. I refer to the repeated claim by this Government that all its failures are the fault of the previous Government. Time after time we have heard the Prime Minister claim, in this House and outside of it, that the cause of all the Governments troubles is the 'terrible deficit' that it inherited from the former Liberal-National Party Government. The Government has fabricated this exercise as an excuse to cover up its own inadequacies and deceit. It knows that both the former Prime Minister and I, when we brought in the wages pause last year, did so because of the difficult circumstances facing this country in 1983. The people of Australia know that, during the campaign, the former Prime Minister, the former Treasurer and I repeatedly emphasised the economic problems facing this country. There was no cover-up concerning just how difficult were the circumstances. The Government knows that the impact of the world recession, the collapse of prices for export commodities, the excessive wage demands and the effects of the drought had produced circumstances that were very difficult indeed. Australians knew it, the Australian Labor Party knew it, and even the drover's dog would have known it. There would have been no surprise about that whatever. Despite this, the present Prime Minister and his colleagues went into the election campaign making promises that they knew were irresponsible and could not be kept. That was a gigantic betrayal of the Australian people and the Australian people will not forget it.

I have no doubt that well before the election campaign the Labor Party made a conscious decision to use that tactic. It must have known that the Australian economy could not meet the cost of such promises as it was dishing out and trumpeting, during the campaign. Yet it went ahead, planning after the election if it won, to find a way out. That way out is its reference to a projected deficit of $9.6 billion for 1983-84. That figure is far too high, the Government says. I fully agree, as do my colleagues. We feel that such a level of deficit would be disastrous, but a projected deficit is just that-projected. The deficit for 1983-84 will be what the Government makes it. It will be the response of the Government to the highly serious economic circumstances that Australia faces today.

Clearly, it would have been cut if the Liberal and National parties had stayed in government. For example, in 1976, when the Government faced a deficit forecast of $4.8 billion, inherited from the Whitlam Government, it cut the projected deficit by $2.6 billion or almost 50 per cent. In 1978, when the deficit forward estimate was $6 billion, the Government cut that figure by more than $3 billion, or more than 50 per cent. So there is nothing magical about a Budget forecast of $9.6 billion for 1983-84. It can be cut or, at least could be , if the Government wanted to cut it. That is the real point.

The exercise in deception in which the Government has engaged concerning the deficit has, I believe, two aims. The first is to allow the Labor Party to weasel out of its election promises. The second is to condition the Australian people to accepting massive deficits and massive government spending. The Prime Minister and the Treasurer (Mr Keating) hope that if they set up a $10 billion deficit as an aunt sally and then knock it down, Australians will be much more ready to accept an $8 billion deficit-still a massive deficit but less, of course, than the imaginary figure that somebody is supposed to be so worried about. The Prime Minister and the Treasurer hope that if Australians accept an $ 8 billion deficit for 1983-84, they will accept similar deficits in the following years. The Prime Minister and the Treasurer and their colleagues are in fact laying the groundwork for an explosion in public sector spending on a scale never before seen in this country. The dangers the nation faces because of this exercise in deception were clearly spelt out in a column by the business editor, Mr Terry McCrann, in the Age on 13 May. I quote the opening paragraphs in full, because I believe they are relevant and important. Mr McCrann wrote:

It is surprising how suddenly and completely the issues of the size of Government and the problems of funding large public sector deficits have faded from the debate over economic policy. But their disappearance from the public debating arena does not mean they have ceased to exist. Far from it. In fact, Australia is undergoing an expansion in the size of Government in the economy to rival that of the Whitlam years. Indeed, on a more pessimistic scenario, the expansion could exceed that of the Whitlam years.

It is possible to project that by the end of the Hawke years-on a worst-case basis-spending by Governments and public authorities could approach 50 per cent of gross domestic product. This would compare with around 31 per cent at the beginning and around 38 per cent at the end of the Whitlam era. Furthermore, this new growth in Government will be accompanied by a veritable explosion in public sector deficits which far, far exceeds that of the Whitlam years. And, of course, they will have to be funded either by borrowing, discretionary tax rises -from a higher tax base than in 1973-or printing money. Indeed, again on a worst -case basis, the public sector deficits over the three years to 1984-85-which includes this year largely passed-could exceed a staggering $45,000m.

TALK.START.PARA: —How much?

—An amount of $45,000m. This is what Mr Terry McCrann, business editor of the Age, wrote. In that quotation, Mr McCrann referred at one stage to the end of the Hawke years. Clearly he was referring to the term of the present Government. But I am sure that if the forecasts come true-and we are firmly heading down that trail now-the Australian people will not be able to get to the polls quickly enough to remove this Government from office.

SPEECH.PARA: Last week's statement by the Treasurer confirms both the trend of those forecasts and my own fears that this Government is trying to condition Australians to accept large deficits. The result of all the Government's cost cutting was, as the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) said on 19 May, a 'massive anti-climax'. All we get is a total net saving for 1983-84 of less than $430m-an amount roughly equal to the no doubt understated cost of introducing Medicare. This economic statement was only a cosmetic gesture of support for lower deficits. The Government seems to believe that with this gesture behind it, it can get on, unobstructed, with a massive program of Government spending. We saw last week the Government lay the foundations for a new round of higher inflation, higher taxation and pressure on interest rates. We have seen it give its blessing to the pay rise that the Australian Council of Trade Unions will be seeking from the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. We have seen it back away from promise after promise on everything from lower taxes, the cost of fuel, the future of the steel industry and the funding of the Darwin to Alice Springs railway. In this statement specifically we have seen broken election promises on the health insurance rebate and on the housing interest rebate. This Government is digging its own grave and it is digging it with the shovel of deceit. The tragedy is that if it is allowed to go on, it will drag Australia and Australians down with it. I believe that all Australian should be alerted to the deception that the Labor Party is trying to put over in this mini-Budget.

I want tonight to discuss another aspect of the statement made by the Treasurer last week. I refer to the Government's claim that the measures it announced meant equality of sacrifice for Australians. That claim is as bankrupt as the rhetoric of national reconciliation that the Labor Party used in the election campaign. It is as empty as the concern for the unemployed that it expressed during the National Economic Summit Conference. The fact is that the major share of the sacrifice will fall on country people. Overall, the amount may not be large. But the fact is that one-third of the total net savings the Government hopes to make will come from the rural community. Most country people are only now looking ahead with some hope after years of drought. Many, tragically, are now suffering from floods instead. International prices for most of our agricultural products are low, some disastrously low. Net farm incomes are the lowest they have been for over two decades and rural indebtedness is at record levels. Yet, on top of these problems, the Government plans to increase the costs faced by the rural community and to abandon programs which would have made its future much more secure. The Government has already broken its promises in regard to cutting fuel prices. It now proposes to increase the cost of petrol in the country-not in the cities. The cost of air travel, phone costs, postal charges, all so important to country people, especially those in isolated areas, are set to rise. The imaginative and forward looking Bicentennial Water Resources Program has been dumped at a time when the drought should have highlighted to everyone how important it is to try to help shore up our farms, those great renewable resources producing much of our vital export income. Communities from Kalgoorlie to Gladstone will suffer because of the water resources decision. It means an end to the feasibility studies into additional River Murray water storage and the possibility of diverting water from our coastal rivers to the west. These are all great schemes that could help the jobless and give the nation lasting benefits at the same time. It means an end to the Split Rock Dam project in New South Wales, to the Awoonga Dam project in Queensland, to the rehabilitation of the Kalgoorlie goldfields pipeline, to the Adelaide and iron triangle filtration scheme and to a score of other vital projects. (Extension of time granted).

I thank the House for its indulgence. Some $70m was set aside for the water resources program for 1983-84. That program has been abandoned. I could not think of a more worthy program to try to give employment opportunities and still do something very lasting for this country than that sort of program. Now the Government claims credit because it plans to spend $20m for employment generation programs in country towns on water supply schemes. It is ridiculous to suggest that band-aid schemes such as that will have any long term impact on water supply security. We have to get to the basis of it with major programs; the other follows. On top of that, the Treasurer has put into question the level of funding for the existing water resources program.

The Government has also made changes to the tax averaging provisions for primary producers. I would be very surprised if the abolition of the in-out provision yields the sort of revenue the Government seems to expect, or is the special privilege that members of the Government try to present it as. The increase in the interest rates on income equalisation deposits will be welcome- that is something. On depreciation, primary producers have been deprived of the benefits of a shorter depreciation period that now exists for manufacturers, miners and others who purchase equipment. Why have the primary producers been singled out and put in the worst position? In the past, because of their export significance, they were always given a favoured position and encouraged; but now , because of a Labor Government, obvious discrimination is emerging. Overall, the mini-Budget will cost country people around $140m directly, on top of the share they will have to meet on the cost of changes to pension and superannuation arrangements and the abolition of the previous Government's assistance to home buyers.

This Labor Government has demonstrated yet again the total disdain of the Labor Party for the rural community. If there could ever have been any doubt about this, it must have been dispelled by the Labor Government's action to cancel the construction of the Alice Springs to Darwin railway or at least make it virtually impossible. That is a clear election promise broken. Its excuses are hollow because it knows the Northern Territory cannot afford to pay the $100m that would be needed over the next three years alone to meet its 40 per cent share of the costs of such construction. The blatant cynicism of the Labor Party in that area alone ought to be enough to ensure that the new member for the Northern Territory (Mr Reeves) serves only one term in this Parliament. Country people, whether on the farm, in the towns or provincial cities, from all walks of life, have suffered harshly from the effects of the drought and the recession in a way that few other Australians have. The Government now asks them to suffer further and to suffer more than their fellow Australians in metropolitan areas.

No mention is made in the economic statement of Labor's promise to help the sugar industry. There is no mention of action to complete the tuberculosis and brucellosis eradication campaign in northern Australia. If action is not taken, all the work of years will be to no avail. Nothing could be so counter- productive as doing nothing in that area. It is clear from this statement that the Labor Government is running true to form. It is showing again that it believes that country people really do not matter. Country people are of no interest or concern to the Labor Party, so it forgets them. It has shown itself incapable of realising that our great primary industries are a vital foundation of the economic success of the whole nation and of the prosperity of its people. If there is to be genuine, firm leadership given in this country, there has to be some fairness and courage. Those are the points which I have demonstrated today.
