TALK.START.PARA: —At the outset, I will put the whole matter of the economic statement of the Treasurer (Mr Keating) into its proper perspective. It must be seen in the perspective of seven long years of Fraser and Fraserism. It must be seen in the perspective of the economic mess this Government inherited at the end of all those years of economic mismanagement. It must be seen in the perspective of our inheritance from the previous Government of the highest unemployment in Australia for 50 years. It must be seen in the perspective of our inheritance of the highest interest rates on record. It must be seen in the perspective of an inflation rate only marginally lower than it was seven years ago when the Fraser Government began to lock this nation into its disastrous fight inflation first policies. It must be seen in the perspective of the highest Budget deficit ever imposed on this nation in our history-a deficit of a magnitude unparalleled, the size of which was so dishonestly concealed from the people of Australia during the recent election campaign. That is the perspective and that is our inheritance.

SPEECH.PARA: That is the legacy which the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Peacock), the Deputy of the Opposition (Mr Howard) and the Leader of the National Party (Mr Anthony) have left for this Government and this nation to clean up. It is that task, the most difficult and awesome economic task ever presented to any incoming government in Australia's history, which the Treasurer's statement last Thursday is designed to tackle. We heard today from the Leader of the Opposition and his Deputy, the former Treasurer, the architect of economic disaster in this country , some of the greatest humbug and hypocrisy ever uttered in this House.

I referred to the previous Treasurer, the Deputy Leader of the Liberal Party, as the architect of the economic disaster that we inherited. But let me make this point: I have, in a way, some sort of respect for the previous Treasurer, the now Deputy Leader of the Opposition, for the rather manful way in which he has been prepared to embrace the responsibility for the deception which was practised on this country in the election period from 3 February to 5 March. I think he is to be congratulated-not for the deception, because, of course, we have condemned him for that-but for the manful way in which since that time he has been prepared, almost solely, to incur the wrath of the Australian electorate and to accept the responsibility for that deception.

But a very interesting question concerns the state of knowledge of the Leader of the Opposition, the then holder of a very senior portfolio in the previous Government. He did not hold some lowly portfolio. He held a very senior economic responsibility, the portfolio for industry and commerce. The people of Australia and all members of this House now know, certainly, that the previous Treasurer knew of the deception. It is known that the previous Prime Minister knew of the deception. It is known that the previous Minister for Finance, Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle, knew of the deception. What has not been answered is whether the now Leader of the Opposition, the then Minister for Industry and Commerce, knew of the deception. Did he know, as did the then Treasurer, the then Prime Minister and the then Minister for Finance? Did the Leader of the Opposition know, or was he not really a senior member of the Cabinet? Was he just the tea boy, who went and got the cream puffs for the other members of the Cabinet? Did he or did he not know?

This is a very important question because the state of knowledge of the Treasurer and the manful way in which he has accepted responsibility for the deception, quite clearly cost him the possibility of the leadership of the Opposition. He did not welch. He manfully accepted responsibility for the fact that he knew that the people of Australia were being deceived; that the incoming deficit for 1983-84 was, in fact, not going to be the $6 billion deficit that was trumpeted around the country. He knew that it would be much more than that. Certainly, in the last week before the election, he knew that it would be of the order of $9.6 billion.

The central question that has to be asked-I suggest that it ought to be asked by every member of the Liberal Party-is whether the then Minister for Industry and Commerce, the Leader of the Opposition, knew. If he knew-I suggest that that is the only reasonable deduction that any intelligent person can make-he has the leadership of the Liberal Party by default and, in a sense, by the courage of the present Deputy Leader of the Liberal Party. It is about time that the present Leader of the Liberal Party showed the courage and the manliness that has been exhibited by his current deputy.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is he starting to worry you?

—No, I want him to stay there. He will make a perfect Leader of the Opposition for the very many years we shall continue to be in government. Those members of the Liberal Party who have allowed themselves to be deceived by this lack of courage on the part of the current Leader of the Opposition should ask, as every other thinking Australian is now asking: Did Mr Peacock share the knowledge of the deceit practised by the then Treasurer, by the then Prime Minister and by the then Minister for Finance, or was there some magical fence of lack of knowledge that was suddenly lowered around the Prime Minister and the Treasurer and the Minister for Finance which excluded the then Minister for Industry and Commerce? I suggest that any intelligent and honourable member of this House will know what the answer to that question is. Did the then Minister for Industry and Commerce know, or did he not? The answer, I suggest, is yes, he did know; and it is a travesty of justice that the now Deputy Leader of the Opposition should have been in the position where he sacrificed the possibility of leadership of the Liberal Party because of that fact.

SPEECH.PARA: Criticism has been offered this day by the Leader of the Opposition, the Deputy Leader of the Opposition and the Leader of the National Party-the three most important members of the Opposition, although there must be some doubt in their minds as to the ranking after number one. Given the electoral performance of the National Party recently vis-a-vis the Liberal Party, I suggest that the Leader of the National Party has very good reason to suggest that he is very much more important in the ranking than the Deputy Leader of the Liberal Party. But we have heard from the three of them today. Let there be no mistake that every criticism that they have had to offer is not a criticism of this Government or of the Treasurer's statement but is, in fact, from their very own mouths, an indictment of their own seven sorry years.

The Treasurer's statement last Thursday night has very specific aims. It helps us to fight unemployment and inflation at the same time. That is what it is all about. We have been able to implement our election commitments to job creation and to housing while making very substantial progress in bringing under control the unprecedented budgetary problems left by the previous Government. As a result of last Thursday's measures, there are now improved prospects for private sector recovery proceeding over the next few years without being threatened by rising interest rates. There are improved prospects for the long term unemployed , especially young people, men and women, in rural and urban areas, finding their way back into jobs. There are improved prospects for the many Australians, especially young Australians, who were locked out of adequate housing by the policies of the Liberal Government, finding the shelter that earlier generations of Australians properly regarded as their birthright.

I have been interested to hear the Opposition's objections to some of our measures and to the overall thrust of our statement. Not content with the results of their fiscal vandalism last year, the Liberals are doing their best to frustrate the reconstruction of the Australian economy. But that is exactly what one would expect from them. The Liberals' current attitude is consistent with their long sorry record of seeking short term political advantage at the expense of the Australian economy and at the expense of the interests of the Australian people. Their attitude now, as they get in the way while we clean up the mess which they left, is consistent with the political opportunism and the electoral deceit that the Australian people have come to expect of them.

The Opposition has accused us of breaking election promises. Most Australians have been impressed by the extent to which we have been able to implement our program on job creation and housing and in other areas in the light of the disastrous budgetary inheritance which was concealed from us and from the Australian people until after the elections. Above all, we have kept faith with our fundamental promises of responsible expansionary fiscal policies and, more generally, good government. The Liberal Party told the Australian people during the election campaign that Australia, under Liberal policies, was headed towards a $6 billion deficit in 1983-84. The Australian Labor Party, like many Australians, took the Liberals at their word and proposed a number of programs to stimulate the economy and to assist groups of Australians who had been damaged most by the recession.

Remembering the Liberals' record of electoral deceit, during the campaign I did caution that our proposals would need to be modified if it turned out that Messrs Fraser, Howard and Peacock and their colleagues had in fact been lying about the deficit. I was advised by the Secretary to the Treasury on the day after the election that the continuation of Liberal policies would generate a $9 .6 billion deficit in 1983-84. The Liberals had deliberately and cynically withheld from the Australian people information that was vital to intelligent assessments of the economic policies presented during the election campaign. We all know that the Liberals were prepared to corrupt the Australian electoral process for their own perceived cynical electoral ends.

The Liberals' deceit did not end when they were dismissed by the Australian people on 5 March. The Leader of the Opposition sought to contest the advice of the Secretary to the Treasury-that if their fiscal policies had continued without correction, next year's Budget deficit would have totalled $9.6 billion. The figures of the Secretary to the Treasury were not related to departments' first bids; they were firm forward estimates of the cost of existing policies. The Leader of the Opposition knows it. His deputy knows it. The fraud and the political inspiration about these figures is all on their side of the House.

The former Treasurer, Mr Howard, has asked why my Government did not simply reverse last year's tax cuts if we were so concerned about the deficit caused by his policies. I have no doubt that the former Treasurer would have had few qualms about reversing the cuts. That, after all, has been par for the course for the Liberals. That is standard Liberal Party practice. We were able to face some of the harder choices, and so far we have been able to avoid the increase in income tax rates that would have been so attractive and so consistent in form for the former Government. In 1975 we heard the Liberals' promises-honourable members will remember them-to reduce unemployment, to reduce inflation, and to maintain Medibank. All the people will remember the promises of 1975. Two years later, in 1977, we had the fistful of dollars, handed out before the election and snatched back only months afterwards. So that was 1975; that was 1977. Then we come to 1980. In 1980 there was the unmitigated lie about the resources boom without limit, which encouraged the wages explosion of 1981 and which ushered in the disastrous unemployment explosion of the last two years.

Time after time, election after election, the Liberals betrayed the trust of the Australian people. They lied harder than ever in this year's campaign, but by now they have lost all credibility with the Australian people. Since March we have learnt that the Liberals' lies about the Budget deficit were the culmination of a year-long strategy of deceit. Last year the Liberals handed out concession after concession in the lead-up to what was going to be the September election that was stopped by the report of the Costigan Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union. They carefully arranged then that the Bills they were piling up would be presented to the Australian people in 1983-84.

We, in this new Government, have had to implement our policies in the wake of this financial irresponsibility. But that is only part of the inheritance of seven years of Liberal rule that we have had to start to correct. For seven years the Liberals systematically removed from Australia's taxation and expenditure policies any semblance of equity. The Australian people can be gratified that that era ended on 5 March. The new Government elected on that day is determined to keep faith with the Australian people. The Australian people expect responsible economic policies directed at economic recovery and, most urgently-for the duration of the present recession-protection of Australians in greatest need.

The job creation and housing policies announced last Thursday implement our election undertakings in these areas. By the second half of the next financial year our Community Employment Program will be operating at a rate designed to generate 70,000 jobs for six months each in a full year. They will be useful jobs on projects developed in consultation with community groups. They will include the jobs on local roads promised during the campaign. By next year we expect that our wider economic policies will be taking hold, providing employment for increasing numbers of Australians, particularly young Australians . Inevitably some Australians will find it harder than others to take advantage of the new opportunities that will be opening up. Our Community Employment Program will be designed to provide the greatest help to our fellow Australians who are least likely to be taken back into employment in the early stages of economic recovery.

Our housing policies are designed to meet urgent housing needs at the same time as they restore the contribution of housing construction to employment and to economic activity. The policies of our predecessors led to a huge slump in the housing industry all over Australia. The two rebate schemes introduced by the Liberal Government last year provide useful benefits for the recipients but they were poorly directed from the points of view both of housing needs and of the need to stimulate construction activity. Housing commencements for the current financial year are likely to be down to the level of 106,000. Consistently with our general concern to place the burden of fiscal restraint only on Australians in a relatively good position to accept it, the March rebate scheme will be continued for families with moderate or low incomes who have qualified for it. The policies announced on Thursday night by my colleague the Treasurer (Mr Keating) are directed specifically to bring new home owners into the housing market as well as to meeting the most acute needs through the increased provision of public housing.

Our consultations with the housing industry give us confidence that our policies will lift housing activity towards an annual rate of 130,000 to 135,000 commencements in the second half of next financial year, compared with 106,000 in 1982-83. This strong recovery in housing activity will be a major component of our program for national economic recovery. In those circumstances is it any wonder that the Housing Industry Association-the body best equipped to talk to the Australian community, to make judgment about the programs of government-came out immediately after Thursday night's statement and gave unqualified approval to the program of this Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —And the permanent building societies.

—And the permanent building societies as well. If we are going to talk about the broad range of endorsement of all our programs I suggest it is relevant to make judgment upon the fact that the Confederation of Australian Industry, the umbrella employer organisation, has welcomed our statement of last Thursday night. On the other side of industry the Australian Council of Trade Unions-the organised trade union movement-has overall, with certain qualifications in regard to superannuation, welcomed the statement, as has the overall employers' body. So we have the trade union movement, the overall employers' body, the Housing Industry Association, the insurance industry and the superannuation industry welcoming the statement. Is it possible that everyone is out of step except our little Andrew, except our little Johnnie and except our little Dougie?

SPEECH.PARA: Our overriding commitment to the Australian people is to promote national economic recovery. We did not promise an instant solution to the economic problems that have accumulated in recent years. We informed the Australian people that it would take years of economic stability and growth to generate new jobs in acceptable numbers. The long term perspective that the Government has brought to the task of national economic recovery has required us, as a responsible government, to maintain a high degree of discipline with respect to expenditure priorities. If we had been concerned only with the next six months or the next year we might have implemented all our programs immediately while leaving poorly directed Liberal programs in place. This would have encouraged the continuation of the high inflation of recent years. It would also have placed pressure on financial markets as renewed confidence lifted private investment over the next two years. Higher interest rates would then have threatened the recovery before it had delivered the employment growth which we have undertaken to encourage. We quite deliberately rejected that approach. The National Economic Summit Conference called upon the Government to fight inflation and unemployment simultaneously. This meant that we were bound to accompany the implementation of our highest priority programs with measures to bring the Budget deficit under control.

My Government's approach to fiscal policy is distinguished from its predecessor 's approach more than anything else by our long term perspective. We are aiming to provide of the order of half a million additional jobs for Australians over the next three years. This requires a long period of economic stability and sustained economic growth. We are as much concerned with the budgetary outlook in 1984-85 and in 1985-86 as we are with the year immediately ahead. Expenditure savings in the later years are as important as savings in 1983-84, given the Liberals' legacy of large structural Budget deficits stretching well into the future. It is a major achievement of the Treasurer's statement that it will reduce the Budget deficits for 1984-85 and 1985-86, each by around $1.5 billion, from levels that would follow from the continuation of the policies that we inherited.

We are carrying this longer view of economic policy well beyond the Budget into all aspects of the nation's economic management. We know that we could generate short term reductions in interest rates through temporarily promoting rapid monetary growth, as the Liberals sought to do immediately after the last election. But such an approach would lead to sharply increasing rates and the truncation of growth when balance of payments and inflationary pressures inevitably led to its reversal. We are seeking lasting reductions in interest rates by holding government demands on financial markets within manageable limits and by holding monetary growth on a steady course.

We are carrying this longer view of economic policy well beyond the Budget into all aspects of the nation's economic management. We know that we could generate short term reductions in interest rates through temporarily promoting rapid monetary growth, as the Liberals sought to do immediately before the last election. But such an approach would lead to sharply high rates and the truncation of growth when balance of payments and inflationary pressures inevitably led to its reversal. We are seeking lasting reductions in interest rates by holding government demands on financial markets within manageable limits, and by holding monetary growth on a steady course. Accordingly, the large bond tender announced by the Treasurer on Thursday night is designed to offset part of the monetary impact of capital inflow over the past month, and to finance the on-going Budget deficit in a non-inflationary manner.

The same long term perspective guides our wages policy. We have been urged by some of our friends in business to seek the greatest restraint in wages that short term conditions would allow. We accept these urgings to the point of acknowledging that wage increases this year on anything like the scale of recent years would kill economic recovery almost as soon as it had begun. But we seek to avoid the opposite danger as well. We see no advantage in asking for such a high degree of restraint now that it is impossible to secure any co-operation and restraint from the trade union movement in 1984 and 1985. All honourable members of this House will recall the industrial chaos, the spiralling wages and prices, that followed the Liberal Government's abandonment of wage indexation in mid-1981. There is no threat of that happening this year. But the institutions and traditions of the Australian labour market are likely to produce exactly this result as recovery accelerates next year, unless we are able to restore confidence in a centralised system of wage fixing in 1983. This is why the Government since its early days in office has spoken of a wage increase of the order of 3 per cent to 4 per cent this year. Such an increase is consistent with the recovery of economic activity and employment. Above all, we judge it to be consistent with the continuation of moderation in wage claims in 1984 and 1985.

The Leader of the Opposition spoke at length on the need for a continuation of the wage pause to the end of this year. He spoke of the 25 per cent increase in the cost of employing a worker in manufacturing industry in 1982. I remind the Leader of the Opposition that his party was in government in 1982 when that occurred. Under our policies, we are expecting wage increases of 3 per cent or 4 per cent in 1983. The Leader of the Opposition is quoted in this morning's Canberra Times as saying that his party has no wages policy. That is the policy the Liberals had two years ago, when manufacturing wages rose by a quarter within a year. The Opposition's wages policy is a fantasy. The Leader of the Opposition says that Budget cuts would not have been necessary if there were no wage increases this year. INTERJECT.PARA: I ask the Opposition: Would it have failed to address the crisis in welfare housing, or of young families excluded from home ownership by the policies of recent years? SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fife The Hon W.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before the suspension of the sitting for dinner, the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) was waxing eloquent in defence of his Government's economic package.
—We thought it was rather good.

—I say to the honourable member that during his speech the Prime Minister said that most Australians are impressed by the way in which his Government is striving to keep the promises made by the Australian Labor Party before the last election. Let me say that hundreds of thousands of adversely affected Australians are not impressed, particularly those Australians who are paying off a home loan. They heard the promise of the Prime Minister before the last election that the Labor Party, when in government, would retain the tax rebate schemes. That, of course, becomes the most recent promise broken by this Government.

SPEECH.PARA: Last week in this House, following the economic statement by the Treasurer (Mr Keating), the Minister for Housing and Construction (Mr Hurford) announced with a great fanfare what he described as the Government's new initiatives in housing . While he concentrated on new measures he glossed over what was being taken away. Also, he made very little reference to some of the very real and positive achievements of the former Government, particularly in the area of home ownership. In summary, what this Government has done is to transfer housing assistance from people buying their own home to those who will rent government housing. At the same time the Government has reduced in total its financial commitment to all housing in Australia. This is an important point to note because the Government, in its rhetoric, has tried to lead Australians to believe that more funds are going to housing. This is a gigantic hoax because the opposite is the case.

Before I get down to the details of the Minister's statement, let me put the First Home Ownership Assistance Scheme in its proper context. In contrast with the Labor philosophy, the Liberal Party and the National Party of Australia are committed to the highest practical level of private home ownership in Australia. Our record in government has demonstrated this and has demonstrated the success of our policies to help Australians own their own home. By 1947, in the closing years of a Labor government, the Australian household ownership rate was 58 per cent. By 1971 the figure had risen to 68 per cent. In 1976, after another Labor Government, the rate had dropped to 66 per cent. By 1981 our policies had increased home ownership back to 68 per cent. Home ownership is the prime aspiration of most Australian families. This Government, despite the new scheme which it has introduced, has reduced in total home ownership assistance. It will stand condemned for that in the eyes of most Australians. The new Government has ripped apart and mostly discarded the elements of the former Government's 1982 home purchase assistance measures.

In March 1982 the former Government introduced the Home Deposit Assistance Scheme which was designed to assist low and middle income earners to bridge the deposit gap with a maximum cash grant of $3,500. At the same time a tax rebate, reducible over five years, was introduced for all new and recent home purchasers . In August 1982 these measures were enhanced with a tax rebate, applicable to all interest payments over 10 per cent, for all home purchasers. The cost of the two tax rebate schemes and home deposit assistance was estimated to be over $ 550m in a full year, therefore providing a very significant degree of assistance to home buyers. Also in March 1982 the banks agreed to lend an extra $400m for housing over the next 12 months. I submit that our policies are working. Indeed, the big jump in home lending this year is proof that the former Government's policy in this area was the right one for Australian families. The stronger lending by banks and building societies clearly demonstrates the correctness of the policies which were put in place last year. It demonstrates how they are working to help Australian home buyers. Lending by banks is up by around 35 per cent over the period last year to a record level. Building societies have shown a 50 per cent increase in the March quarter over the December quarter. The building society figure represents the highest quarterly level since March 1981.

On the basis of these figures, the present Government should have thought again and not tossed out the 1982 initiatives. In particular, the decision by the Government to terminate the general tax rebate for home purchasers is a callous blow to middle Australia, particularly many young Australians who have purchased a home in the last few years. Families and individuals who have already committed themselves to home purchase will not be able to take advantage of the new First Home Ownership Assistance Scheme and now they have had the tax rebate taken away. Many potential home buyers will receive no assistance at all as the new scheme is to be means tested. The Government's decision to remove assistance by way of the general tax rebate is effectively an increase in tax, totalling $ 185m a year, for those people who currently are paying off their homes. That was the estimated full cost of the general tax rebates. In fact, many home buyers will now pay extra tax of around $300 a year. Looked at in another way, the general housing tax rebate of the former Government effectively reduced interest rates for most home purchasers by between one per cent and 2 per cent. The Government, by its action in terminating this rebate, has therefore increased interest rates for home purchasers. This action makes a mockery of what the Minister for Housing and Construction had to say in his statement last week. He said:

Let me make it clear from the beginning that there is nothing that would more guarantee the recovery of the housing industry than a reduction in interest rates. We will move forward in a way designed to achieve this goal.

This rhetoric does not match the Government's actions. The Minister's words were empty, just like the Government's election policies. I wish to refer also to the special tax rebate for those purchasers which was introduced in March 1982 by the former Government. It needs to be made clear that this initiative has been largely scrapped. The Government has decided that there will be no new entrants to this scheme and it will now become means tested in respect of those are currently eligible. The Labor Party, in its pre-eclection promises, committed itself largely to retaining both the housing tax rebates introduced by the former Government. It has now broken yet another promise. Current home purchasers who voted Labor now have great cause for regret. I note that the First Home Owner Assistance Scheme will benefit potential home purchasers on lower incomes. However, I point out to the House that it only replaces the former Government's Home Deposit Assistance Scheme, a similar type of scheme directed at the same group of income earners but without the incentive to save for the deposit, such savings being themselves extra funds for housing in that they were placed with institutions that lent for housing.

Indeed, as I said before with the removal of the general tax rebate for housing and the phasing out of the March 1982 rebate scheme, net assistance to home purchasers has been reduced. On the Government's figures this reduction is of the order of $250m in a full year. This is a disgraceful attack on home ownership in Australia. There is also a further point that needs to be made about the Government's new First Home Ownership Assistance Scheme. This new scheme will not come into operation until at least 1 October and possibly later. Already there are signs in the industry that some home buyers are delaying their purchase and delaying the signing of contracts. Indeed, I note in the newspaper today a report that the Housing Industry Association has already expressed concern about this. It appears that the Government has caused a partial hiatus in industry activity by announcing the new scheme well in advance of its commencement. The Minister for Housing and Construction is also reported in a morning newspaper as suggesting that people should buy now and not wait for the new scheme. What a strange thing to announce a new scheme and then to suggest that people should not take advantage of it.

The Government obviously did not give much thought to this matter. The Minister has tied himself up in knots in trying to escape his real responsibilities. Of course, home ownership assistance was not the only subject dealt with by the Government last week. Further funds have been provided for public housing. I do not intend to criticise the Government for its plans to increase funding for public housing but I reject the Minister's rhetoric of criticism of the former Government's public housing activities. Public housing assistance should relate directly to the level of need and should not be at the expense of meeting the goal of home ownership.

At times of difficult economic circumstances there is a higher need for public housing and this was recognised by the former Government. In the 1982-83 Budget the former Government allocated to the States $333m for welfare housing programs -a 27 per cent increase on the previous year. As an additional measure State governments were also permitted to nominate additional funds for welfare housing from their normal Loan Council program. Again, in recognition of special need, the former Government was able to allocate a further $100m for welfare housing programs from the Budget savings made possible by its wages pause initiative, an initiative that was much maligned by the Labor Party. This welfare housing assistance was designed to help those Australians whose economic circumstances mean that they will never be able to own their own home or those who because of temporary economic circumstances cannot achieve home ownership at this stage. The new Government now proposes an increase on what we achieved. The Government of the day sets its priorities with the use of taxpayers' funds. I have no argument with this except to point out that public housing should be targeted carefully to those in need.

The third major matter dealt with by the Minister relates to new housing commencements. The Minister has promised that the Government's package will lift housing commencements by 22,000 next financial year. Housing commencements will rise next financial year in any event to a certain degree. The Government should very carefully watch that further stimulatory measures are not counter- productive in that they may lead to increases in housing costs and therefore prices. This would be a disaster, particularly for young Australians looking to buy their first homes. I understand from newspaper reports that the Minister has been warned by his Department about this possibility. I raised this matter as a plea to the Minister to monitor his Government's decisions to ensure that they do not lead to cost and price escalation in the housing industry.

In summary, the Government has reduced net assistance for housing in Australia by drastically cutting home ownership assistance. The new First Home Ownership Assistance Scheme does not make up for what the Government has taken away. ( Extension of time granted). The Government admits this in the figures provided in the attachment to the Treasurer's statement but, of course, this is glossed over in the Minister's speech and in media handouts. On top of this, the overall Budget strategy being adopted by this Government must inevitably result in higher interest rates than would otherwise be the case. This will additionally penalise all home purchasers and prevent many potential home buyers from realising their aspirations.
The Government's housing statement is a sham. I foreshadow that when the statement is brought on, in respect of the motion 'That the House take note of the paper' I will move:
That all words after 'That' be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:

the House is of the opinion that, whilst the Government's stated aim of further assisting the housing industry is to be supported, the Government should be condemned for taking action contrary to this aim and particularly condemned for its reduction in assistance to current home purchasers by effectively increasing their interest payment burden, and for its overall reduction in housing assistance.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beazley The Hon K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take this opportunity to reply to a couple of the points that have been made in debate by honourable members from the Opposition side. I refer not so much to the speech that we have just heard because the honourable member for Farrer (Mr Fife) expressed himself in the modulated and moderate terms that one would expect of a former Minister for Aviation who served in that portfolio with some distinction. Nevertheless he was completely wrong save for one point. There is a clear point of difference between the two parties, the Opposition and the Government, on the question of priorities in the housing area. Our priority is to get the maximum possible number of houses built for employment and social purposes. Our policy is to favour those who are without houses at the moment to ensure that they are capable of getting houses.

SPEECH.PARA: The previous Government's record on which the honourable member sought to stand was one, until the last Budget coincidentally, of continual reductions in the amounts of funds devoted to public housing and one that, whilst it fluctuated a bit over time saw a steady decline in home ownership in Australia. The proposals of the Government in this mini-Budget, which will be carried through into the main Budget, is to reverse that trend. However, I would rather speak about the points that were made in debate a little earlier in the evening by the Leader of the National Party of Australia (Mr Anthony). He raises misrepresentation to an art form. There is practically nothing else that he does here that he raises to the level of an art form because his contributions on most matters are usually crude, and his performance tonight was no exception.

I start with one particular point that has been reiterated by him and also by previous speakers and that concerns the question as to whether this Government is meeting its election commitments. What I want to point out about that last election campaign, before it dims completely from people's memories, is that it was one of those very rare occasions in Australian political history where politics is played pretty hard and fast. That the leader of the Australian Labor Party having become disturbed about rumours and reports that were apparently emanating from Government sources that the situation in which the country could find itself financially would be much worse than anybody expected had the courage, not after the election-not to walk in later saying 'Gee, look, we have been presented with this terrible deficit and there is really nothing much we can do about it except repudiate our promises'-but before the poll to say: 'If these rumours are correct, if the situation we will confront is anything like one could predict by deducing certain facts from statements being made by the Treasurer and others, then obviously we will have to review our election promises to make certain that the real priorities are the priorities which get met. We will have to trim our sails to the circumstances in which we find ourselves'. Those statements, unlike the repudiation of policies and promises by the previous Government after successive election victories in the late 1970s, were made a week in advance of the election. The electorate was put on notice that if anything like the situation that subsequently did emerge, emerged, the Government would consider itself bound to assign priorities in its election promises. We began to assign those priorities in the mini-Budget brought down last week.

Of course, a number of other matters will be dealt with both on the revenue raising side and on the expenditure side in the 1983-84 Budget. I do not think any one could have listened to the speech by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) the other night and failed to be impressed by the determination of this side of the House that when it comes to implementing the priorities that were established during the course of the election campaign the policy of this Government will be to advance the interests of those in this country least able effectively to assist themselves and most punished by the way in which the economy has developed over the last few years.

The Leader of the National Party has, as I said a little earlier, lifted misrepresentation to an art form. He has done that across the board in this place over the last couple of weeks. He has done it on security matters, having constantly harped in Question Time and in speeches about this matter, trying to imply some impropriety in the Labor Party's handling of security matters since it came to office. However, he has been sitting on a major security scandal associated with the leaks of material to the National Times. Those leaks can have occurred only during a period when he sat on the defence and intelligence committee of the previous Government. If anybody is to be answerable for those performances, it is the Leader of the National Party. Whatever may have happened over the last few weeks pales into insignificance when compared with the compromise of Australian intelligence agencies and the compromise of Australian relationships with important neighbours and allies that occurred as a result of the ineptitude of members of that security commitee of the previous Government. In my view it is a matter which has not had sufficient airing in this House.

Of course, that was not his theme this evening; his theme was to misrepresent the position of this Government on both its overall economic management and its rural policy. The Leader of the National Party waxed eloquent on the fateful consequences to this country of a continuing Budget deficit of the proportions with which we are now confronted. He brought out the Business Review Weekly-he gets handed a free issue on the aeroplanes as he leaves Canberra-to demonstrate the lack of wisdom of the course which he suggests is about to be pursued. He excoriated this Government for allegedly attempting to convince the Australian public that a Budget deficit which never would have occurred will occur because of the expenditure priorities of this Government and that really he would have had absolutely no problem dealing with that had he still been in a position to deal with it-as he did when he cut the deficit from $6 billion to $3 billion in 1978-79.

He made those statements in his 20 minute speech, but not once did he cite an example of an area where an expenditure cut might be made or an area of the community from which revenue might be raised to allow a reduction of that $9.6 billion. Not once did he put forward a proposition in that regard. Instead, he went through a variety of proposals-proposals on which this Government has been prepared to bite the bullet and in regard to which the former Treasurer wished to bite the bullet but had it snatched away from his jaws by his colleagues in the previous Parliament. In fact, the Leader of the National Party presumed to criticise every single aspect of the proposed expenditure reductions that were included in the statement brought down at the end of last week.

He went on from that to say that the statement amounted to a persecution of the rural interest in this country. Nothing could be further from the truth but I think we will see repeats in this Parliament of the experience of the Whitlam Labor Government when dealing with members of the then Country Party, now the National Party. Every job creation scheme proposed will be ridiculed but a red hot track will be beaten by individual members of the National Party to the back door of the office of the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations (Mr Willis). They will do their very best to ensure that their electorates benefit, and they themselves benefit politically, from the various schemes of assistance that will flow through to local government in both city and country areas. I see that one of the new National Party members is grinning away at me on this point. I expect with great confidence that that is exactly how he will be behaving over the next few months. But he will come into this place to heap abuse on those schemes.

Far from bearing the brunt of expenditure reductions, as the Leader of the National Party claimed, rural people will be among the greatest beneficiaries of these changes. The Australian Wheat Board has been given the facility to borrow overseas. This will result in hundreds of millions of dollars being paid to farmers rather than being used to cover high interest bills. The Board has been asking for this facility for 18 months and has welcomed this announcement. In the field of tax averaging and income equalisation, the Government has removed rorts, inequalities and inefficiencies of the kind the Leader of the National Party loves to defend. The new income stabilisation scheme will pay a rate of interest two percentage points above the two year bond rate. The old tax related returns produced anomalies whereby the richest farmers gained the greatest benefits, with an effective interest rate of 25 per cent. The majority of farmers will be better off as a result of the new scheme and the rip-offs of the wealthy few will be eliminated. The petroleum products freight subsidy scheme will involve only $2m to $3m. The Leader of the National Party should be aware that fuel represents less than 10 per cent of farm costs and is a tax deductible expense.

The indirect effects of this economic statement will greatly favour primary producers who, it must be remembered, have already benefited greatly from the devaluation. The effective control of interest rates and inflation which will be developed as a result of actions such as those we are considering will greatly advantage all primary producers. The net result of the statement will be a boost to rural incomes, not the disaster predicted by the Leader of the National Party . The Leader of the National Party further claimed that rural dwellers were carrying one third of the burden of the cost cutting involved in the economic statement. He has shown his poor arithmetic with this claim. He made some extreme statements of cost allocation and by some poor work with his sums he arrived at a sum of one third of the total of net revenue savings to the Government, but that is not an indication of costs to the rural people. By way of changes to the ability of the Australian Wheat Board to seek overseas loans, as I said, country people will come out of this very considerably better off. So they should; they have had to bear much of the brunt of the burden of the terrible drought over the last four years. This mini-Budget has gone to meet their real needs. It will ensure that those real needs will continue to be met, by eliminating from the process some of the rorts which have benefited only wealthy farmers and those who have not had to live on the margin.

I want to refer briefly to a matter in this mini-Budget which has has some impact on my portfolio, to allay some of the concern expressed in the community about aspects of it and to explain it a little further. Even though it does not come strictly within the area of my Department it obviously has an effect on the aviation industry. It is the imposition of an excise of 2c a litre on aviation fuels from 1 July, which will increase excise revenue by about $15m in 1983-84. I just point out a couple of things about that. This increase, which is the first since 1977, has been implemented in lieu of navigation charge increases this year. There will be no air navigation charge increases this year. One does not have to go far in general aviation to find out where in fact the objection lies to the way in which people in this area have been charged in years past. The principal objection lies in the fact that those people are obliged to meet essentially very heavy fixed charges no matter how infrequently they use their aircraft. I hope that by this measure we will start to manoeuvre that aspect of the way in which we cost recover in the aviation program in the direction of usage rather than the mere possession of an aircraft. I think this will be a decision which in the long term, if it is continued, will considerably benefit the industry.

My time to speak in this debate is running out, but I point out that, even with what I admit is a very substantial increase in excise on aviation fuels, we will recover less costs than were recovered last year and last year the cost recovery program fell by a factor of about 5 per cent. So we are sensitive to the needs of the aviation industry. This is a decision taken in the light of those needs. It is a decision which I think in the long run, even though it will hurt in the immediate future, will be very much welcomed by all sectors of the industry, particularly those least able to bear the cost recovery program.

SPEECH.PARA: That all words after 'That' be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:
'whilst not declining to give the Bill a second reading, the House-

(1) is of the opinion that the Government should acknowledge that permanent jobs will only be created when economic recovery occurs and should do its utmost to implement policies consistent with the following extracts from the National Economic Summit Communique:

This Government recognises the crucial importance of wage restraint in current economic circumstances, but it is the responsibility of the national Government to provide the environment and the leadership to attain appropriate wage outcomes, as this Government has done.

The Summit ought to have been educative of all people interested in the costs faced by Australian Industry, the competitiveness of industry and its capacity to trade around the world. It certainly ought to have left, as it did leave, to the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission the mechanism and the formula for an appropriate wages outcome against that background. I would like to make a number of specific comments on the Community Employment Bill, but they must be seen against the background of the foreshadowed amendment because we are just playing at the margin with this legislation. First of all, the Bill seeks to provide temporary employment for less than 10 per cent of the unemployed. Secondly, it does so in a manner and by criteria very similar to those adopted by the previous Government when distributing the $300m saved from the wages pause in respect of Commonwealth employees. Thirdly, I have no doubt that the Fraser Government, had it still been in office in August, would have introduced a similar program to this.

TALK.START.PARA: —Oh!
—I can assure the Minister that that would have been so. Let me say in addition--
—Absolute rubbish.

—The Minister says:'Rubbish'. Let me say that in making that observation I am not carping but am pointing out that we recognise the marginal significance of the program. However, we recognise that it is important that economic recovery should be achieved by broader economic means than are reflected in this Bill.

SPEECH.PARA: The program in this Bill had its genesis in the wages pause program of the Fraser Government which the then Opposition roundly and wrongly condemned. The State Labor governments, the present Government's State colleagues, supported the proposition because they knew it made economic sense and because they knew it helped marginally in job creation. We saw it as a modest contribution towards employing some people and we see this Bill in the same light, but as no more than that. We therefore support the Bill but we draw the Government's attention to the broader economic issues which impinge upon unemployment. I really do not suppose that the Government needs to have its attention drawn to those issues because, after all, in speech after speech at the National Economic Summit Conference the theme was 'jobs, jobs, jobs'. There was a call for a reduction in costs, particularly those costs which we have the power to control; that is, wages. That was seen as the means by which we could achieve the best circumstances in which to take advantage of the world economic recovery when it comes and thereby provide jobs. The Bill establishes the Community Employment Program with the intention of generating a level of activity in 1983-84 consistent with our objective to provide in a full year . . . up to 70,000 full time jobs for an average duration of six months.

If the wages policy falls down, will we have a level of activity that is consistent with that objective, let alone one that will meet the objective itself? Therefore we cannot escape the overall economic objectives which have been spoken about earlier in the debate.

I wish to discuss an aspect of this matter which I believe the Government can take charge of. I refer to a Press release which I made on Sunday which, however , seems to have received no coverage in the media. I believe that it makes an important point, one to which I drew the attention of the Government. I believe that the Government should tell building industry employers, the employers who are now likely to break the wages pause, that it will not reimburse such employers on government projects for wage increases granted outside the centralised wage fixing system. It should also call upon all State governments to do likewise. It would be tragic if the money allocated to job creation were to go towards meeting additional costs of materials and increased wages for those who already have jobs. The major stimulus to employment in the mini-Budget and in the last Budget of the Fraser Government involves the building and construction industries. Many building industry employers are likely to bow to the threats of renewed thuggery by the Builders Labourers Federation and only action by governments, such as that which I suggest, will cause them to think again. For them to do so will weaken their viability as a company and their employees will then realise that their jobs are at stake. I urge the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations to adopt that approach and ask him to comment on it at the end of this debate.
The Minister, in the second reading speech, as reported at page 817 of Hansard, stated:

This Government will adopt a two-fold approach to directly assisting the unemployed through action, first to create jobs and second to provide the unemployed with the training needed to fill the jobs which will be created through a sustained economic recovery.

One must ask: Why then abolish the Special Youth Employment Training Program? That was not mentioned at all in the second reading speech of the Minister. The Government has a complete misunderstanding of the objectives and results of that program. It was not a job creation program. It was designed to lift the level of skill of long term unemployed youth with an unsatisfactory school record who were not competitive in the market place even at a time that was more prosperous than is the present. We sought to lift their level of skill by providing them with work experience, by subsidising them in employment. These measures have the effect of abolishing that program, yet nothing adequate is substituted in its place. The surveys carried out by the Department for which the Minister is now responsible show, if recollection serves me accurately, that close to two-thirds of those who undertook the Special Youth Employment Training Program were still in the same job three months after the subsidy finished, which meant that they had gained employment. Others had gained employment elsewhere as a result of the skills that they had gained on the job. But the objective of the program was not the creation of jobs. It was to make people more competitive in the market place , regardless of the state of the economy.

The Government displays a serious misunderstanding of the position. It was displayed by its supporters when in opposition. Also, the present Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), when shadow Minister, displayed that misunderstanding time and again . Now there is talk of training to be gained, but how is it to be gained? There is some talk of a private employment training program, but we have not seen its details. I believe that in the end it will not be very different from the Special Youth Employment Training Program which is to be abolished by these measures. Again, one must ask the Government-I ask the Minister particularly to respond to the question-about mature age training. What will the Government do, through its so-called special relationship with the trade union movement, to bring about a recognition of the fact that many people left school too young, they did not have the literacy and numeracy necessary to obtain apprenticeships and they could not be trained, with the result that in times of recession they cannot obtain jobs? Mature age training is clearly required but the trade unions remain a major obstacle to its being achieved.

There is also a dilemma about the labour intensiveness of some of the programs mentioned in the Bill. At the Committee stage I will refer to some of the criteria outlined by the Minister in the second reading speech and will offer some very constructive comments in that regard. It seems to me that if wages increase, if the Minister cannot convince his State colleagues to administer this program in such a way as to place particular emphasis upon assisting unemployed youth, the prospect is that a desperate effort will be made to seek labour intensiveness in order to provide the 70,000 jobs projected. That will be self-defeating. It will defeat the objectives set out in the second reading speech. If wages go up, especially, there will be a temptation to find 70,000 jobs in the most labour-intensive areas, where no skill will be involved. Thus, people may be on a job for three months, six months or 12 months but in the end the program will be no better than the make-work programs which were epitomised by the Regional Employment Development program of the Whitlam Government. In fact, even Mr Kenneth Davidson, the economics editor of the Age, who is no admirer of the Opposition, speaks of the cruel illusion which this Bill represents to people who are seeking employment.

As I have said, at the Committee stage I will refer to the quite important aspect of the criteria that are to be adopted here, but I make the observation in passing that we are looking at a program which is little different from that proposed by the previous Government in the Budget which is still current. During this financial year we were looking at a wages pause program which had job creating benefits as great as any proposed in the Bill. The former Government proposed welfare housing, airport upgrading, the Australian Bicentennial Road Development Program and water projects, all of which were important for job creation. The present Government, in saying that its razor gang has removed these projects, is using mirrors to pretend that it has provided $300m for the creation of extra work. In fact, people who are concerned with the Brisbane Airport work and other such projects will have cause to wonder. I believe that in the end most of what is proposed will be nugatory and that all of it will represent a cruel deception and illusion to the unemployed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cunningham Mr B.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight I have the opportunity, once again, to follow the honourable member for Balaclava (Mr Macphee), as I did last week in a debate on industrial relations. Strangely enough, the Opposition shadow Minister has taken the view that he took last week: That the Opposition, had it been in government, would have introduced a similar Bill. That clearly shows that the shadow Minister may have been a lone wolf crying in the wilderness when the former Government had the opportunity to do something in this regard. The honourable member has proposed an amendment to the motion for the second reading . I do not believe that on the Government side we would have any difficulty with the first section of his amendment, which states:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) is of the opinion that the Government should acknowledge that permanent jobs will only be created when economic recovery occurs . . .

I am sure that had the shadow Minister been in the House just before the suspension of the sitting for dinner, when the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) spoke on this subject, he would have heard the Prime Minister say that very thing-that a job creation program has to be introduced immediately to help those who are unemployed but is not the sole answer in regard to creating jobs for the future. That will have to be done by way of prudent economic management, in which this Government has taken the first step by its announcements in the economic statement that is before the House.

The debate tonight shows the total lack of direction of the Liberal-National Party coalition in relation to economic matters. The Leader of the Opposition ( Mr Peacock) addressed this House for 45 minutes. He was followed by Opposition speakers who had little to offer in the way of constructive comment. The only constructive comment that I have heard tonight came from the honourable member for Balaclava and was made in the first section of his remarks. In fact, at Question Time today the Opposition had not even one question to ask the Treasurer (Mr Keating) in relation to the economic statement. That shows how bereft it is of ideas concerning anything that is going on.

The major issues to which this nation should direct its attention, as was expressed so clearly in the National Economic Summit Conference communique are those of unemployment and inflation. They must be tackled together. No longer can we have policies such as those of the previous Government, the present Opposition, which insisted that inflation be attacked first and ignored the unemployment situation. Fancy the Opposition coming into the House tonight and saying that it would have introduced policies similar to these had it been returned to government. There is no possible way that it would have been returned to government considering the type of approach it had been taking over the last seven years, during which time it created the most massive unemployment this country has ever seen. This Government has not been afraid to take action in this regard. Indeed, the very nature of the approach to be taken by the Government was signalled by the calling of the National Economic Summit Conference. For the last two hours or more we have been asked: When will the Government do this; when will the Government do that? It is only some 70-odd days since the election yet speaker after speaker has said that this Government has failed in its obligations and has dishonoured its promises. Let them give us a three-year period and see what we can and cannot do. At that stage Opposition members can stand before us and tell us what we have not done.

The major issues on which we said we would take action were unemployment and inflation, both at the same time. This economic statement clearly indicates that the Government intends to take action in those areas. The matters that the Opposition is talking about and the matters about which it says we have done nothing will be looked after as time goes along. We cannot do everything in the first 70 days of office. I do not know how the Opposition expects this Government to do in 70 days what the former Government could not do in seven years. We have already put many things in train in our first 70 days of office. The Government's economic statement has clearly been received by the community as a responsible approach. The very fact that this debate not only covers the economic statement but also the housing policy initiatives announced by the Minister for Housing and Construction (Mr Hurford), plus two major items of legislation, clearly shows the importance that this Government places on honouring its major promises to the Australian people.

Let me turn to the matters being debated. I refer firstly to the economic statement. I turn to the Treasurer's statement in relation to the improvement expected in the economic activity of the country. The Treasurer said that the fiscal stimulus implicit in the Commonwealth Budget for 1982-83 and the prospect for 1983-84 would show some improvement but not enough as far as this Government is concerned. He said that we can expect some improvement in the international economy; that we can expect a marked slowing in stock decumulation so that a greater proportion of increased demand will be met from additional production; and that we can expect improved prospects for farm production and exports. There is no doubt about that. We have gone through one of the worst droughts that this country has ever experienced, so we must expect that farm production and our exports in that sector will contribute to the national economy. It is like the bleating of lambs to hear members of the National Party claim that this Government is depriving the rural sector of any of the benefits and that its decisions will cost the rural sector more than anybody else in the community.

Right across the board, ever since the National Economic Summit Conference was first considered, it was clearly stated that all sectors of the community would be expected to contribute to the needs of the Australian economy at the present time. I do not doubt that the rural community is quite capable, regardless of the drought, of coping with the loss of some of those benefits which were put in place by the previous Government on behalf of the so-called rural community. I did not hear the Leader of the National Party (Mr Anthony) mention one word in his speech about the depreciation allowance for the storage of petroleum products. That was the greatest rort that any government ever introduced into this country. The previous Government provided a taxation depreciation allowance of 100 per cent on secondhand fuel tanks-a 100 per cent allowance on an asset that was 15 to 20 years old, that was dragged out of the back of a shed, put out in the front yard, repainted and declared as an asset of value. There was a 100 per cent allowance on that asset. That was the Opposition's idea for a fuel storage policy. The Opposition was bereft of policies. It had no policies. It had no idea how it would go ahead. These sorts of things have to be addressed by any responsible government.

The Treasurer spoke also about the pick-up in dwelling constructions. That was added to by the announcement by the Minister for Housing and Construction shortly after the Treasurer's speech. The Minister for Housing and Construction said that this Government has attempted to regenerate the housing and construction industry in this country. Its capacity had run down to its very bare minimum, something like 106,000 dwellings per year, when it is capable of achieving far more. Any responsible government that has a surplus of funds in the community that can be used by the public sector must be expected to stimulate the economy by assisting the housing industry.

The Treasurer also referred to 'the improved prospects for on-going moderation of income claims as the prices and incomes accord is implemented'. We have had speakers from the Opposition side tell us that we must continue the wage pause. Even the previous speaker alluded in his amendment to the fact that we need to continue the wage pause indefinitely. Common sense will tell anybody that since the wage pause was introduced the wage earners in this country have been asked, and are being asked, to accept a big burden at the present time as far as the economy is concerned. Any housewife who goes into a supermarket every day of the week knows that the prices of the ordinary products that she is buying are still increasing. There is no price surveillance at the present time. That is another policy initiative that this Government will introduce. The wage pause has cost the ordinary people of this country an enormous amount. They have lost the potential to spend money and consume goods. They are feeling the pinch of the wage pause.

Every other sector of the community needs to be prepared, when this Government puts forward logical proposals-as it has done in this economic statement-to share the burden fairly. We have not said to anybody that one particular sector should shoulder the whole burden yet the Leader of the National Party came into this House and tried to tell us that two-thirds of the savings have been borne by the rural sector. I represent a rural electorate. I represent it on behalf of the Australian Labor Party. The Opposition cannot say today that it still represents rural electorates because it does not have them all. On this side of the House we can represent rural people as well, if not better than, anybody on the other side of the House ever could. We will do a better job. If the trend in voting in this country continues we will find that my seat, as a rural seat, will not be the only rural seat that is held by the Labor Party. Many people sitting on the other side of the House representing rural seats will not be here after the next election.

Let us look at what the Opposition would have done had it had the opportunity. In the last five minutes of my speech I turn to some of the things that it could have done. We were looking at a projected Budget deficit of $9.6 billion. That was something that we were not informed of. Had the Opposition been honest with the public and revealed that, it might have been on this side of the House. The Opposition parties tried to stay in office by taking the country to an election when they thought they could win. They were told by the Australian people that they wanted nothing of them. The Australian people put the then Government out and put a responsible government in. That is why we are on this side of the House and that is why we have the opportunity to make these decisions.

I ask the Opposition what it would have done. It had two choices. It could have been totally irresponsible and gone for an enormous Budget deficit, which is probably what it would have done if it thought it could have won an election by doing so, or it could have reduced the figure by two possible means. The choice which would normally have been expected from honourable members on that side of the House when in government was an increase in taxes. They did it before but they increased them only for one sector of the community. We know that. They tried it in the past. We have seen them in action and the Australian people have made their judgment. Over the last seven years pay-as-you-earn taxpayers in this country have been slugged. In 1981 we saw an increase of 22 per cent in tax for pay-as-you-earn wage earners and a 17 per cent increase in 1982. Those increases were way above anything to do with the inflation rate. While the present Opposition parties were slugging the ordinary Australian people, they were putting through some 40-odd pieces of legislation in which tax concessions were made available to people in this country who were quite able to look after themselves. These people had capital investments; they owned land; they had their own businesses. They were quite capable of making decisions without the Australian Taxation Office helping them. But what did the Opposition parties do when in Government? They slugged the ordinary Australian working people and passed a stack of legislation aimed at giving tax concessions which would not show up in the Budget Papers. The economic statement which this responsible Treasurer has put into action clearly defines areas which, had things been allowed to continue, would have added to the Budget deficit to an enormous degree, and not just this year. We need to look a little further ahead. This economic statement tells the people of Australia that the action we are taking now will be responsible for putting the economy back in shape over the next two to three Budgets, and not just this one. That is the difference between sensible economic management-the approach taken by a Labor Government-and that taken by members on the opposition side of the House when they were in government. Often the Opposition, when in government, brought forward a piece of legislation that was designed to assist a sectional interest. There is no doubt about that. We can go through them all because there are plenty of examples to look at. One has been detailed in the economic statement, namely the petroleum storage matter, which is probably the worst example of the lot. I am glad to see that it was immediately eradicated. Everyone in the country knows that oil companies ran around and slapped their monikers on every oil tank they could find to make sure they got the concession rather than those who were supposed to get it. Honourable members on the opposition side of the House were looking after their friends. What they did not do was take a logical view of the future implications of their actions.

The economic statement that we are debating here tonight takes a logical view. It is clearly aimed not at what we do today. In addition, we have indicators on superannuation, housing and job creation. The greatest benefit that this country will receive will be in the future when we will be able to budget the economy of this country in such a way that we will not have to adjust the taxes of the pay- as-you-earn taxpayer every year in an attempt to make room in the economy for the sorts of things that the former Government put in the Budget last year. They would have cost us a fortune in 1984-85 and a lot more in 1985-86. The Treasurer has clearly outlined where those savings will occur. They will be over $400m this year, but will rise to well over $2,000m in future Budgets. If we can maintain this approach we will not only restore employment to this country, but also restore all sectors of the economy to a sound economic base. We will be returned as the Government with a good majority and half the Opposition will not be here.

As I said, this is not only the first opportunity we have had of debating the economy since the election, but also, in effect, Labor's judgment of everything the previous Government did prior to 5 March.

SPEECH.PARA: On that basis, let us say that this should be the last opportunity that Labor should have of debating in this chamber not the economic statement-I have not heard one of the back benchers debate it; all they have done is play on the theme of the $9.6 billion deficit, which I will speak about later-but other matters. Let us see what Labor's final response has been. From the great roar of rhetoric that we have had in this chamber, from outside and from the Press about the ills of the previous Government, we have had what one of my colleagues has described as a whimper for an answer-a $425m reduction in a deficit which has been floated at $9.6 billion. This is the answer.

TALK.START.PARA: —What would you have done?

—We have properly described what we would have done. If the honourable member had listened to the previous Treasurer and had been here to listen to his observations he could have been quite well informed. The answers are being given here and it is not our fault if the honourable member is too dense to listen. The situation is that we are to have a $427m saving in the proposed Budget of $9.6 billion. In mentioning that figure, which last Thursday represented the Government's total response, I mention also the sleight of hand that has operated in this regard. I refer to the additional expenditure that has already been allocated by the Labor Government. Trans Australia Airlines has been allocated $115m; Qantas Airways Ltd is to receive $60m; the Australian National Line has been allocated $90m; and $21m has been allocated for a referendum. None of these expenditures had been indicated prior to the election. In one swoop, the Government has chewed up $286m of what was proposed to be a $ 427m saving. That is great stuff.

SPEECH.PARA: That is not the only area in which there has been sleight of hand. The economic statement is significant for another sleight of hand and that is taking away the employment opportunities that were offered by the capital works program. I mention the Alice Springs to Darwin railway, the water resources program, the Brisbane Airport and all the others. This was the long term response of the great economic theorists on the Government benches. They do not want to learn. Even Blind Freddie could see the situation as far as the capital works program is concerned. It would have given not only job opportunities during the developing stage, but also opportunities of further employment later. Let us look at the airport situation. What have we had out of the statement itself? There will be an effective rise in air fares and in the prices of petrol. There will be a slowing down of this facet of tourism. Job opportunities will be missed because they are going out one door. The survival of the Australian economy will depend on capital assets which will encourage industries in their wake and make job opportunities. But what do we have? We have just done the Northern Territory out of 1,250 jobs in development alone. I am not sure of the figures for the other areas and their programs. We have yet to hear, for instance, what will happen with the Burdekin Dam. There are grave rumours that perhaps we will have to wait for the Budget to find out what will happen.

TALK.START.PARA: —It will get the chop.

—As the honourable member says, it is likely to get the chop. It will not only be the honourable member for the Northern Territory (Mr Reeves) who will have to suffer the embarrassment of going back to try to defend an impossible situation, but also the Labor members of Herbert (Mr Lindsay) and Leichhardt (Mr Gayler). It is rather significant that in this chamber those on the Government side are making meek noises about the necessity for a brucellosis eradication campaign which has received the great wipe in the economic statement . Prior to the election, Labor was making pleasant sounds about the help it would give to the Queensland sugar industry. In the statement there was not one word about an underwriting program, a loan program, or anything else designed to give jobs to people on the land and keep them in those cities and towns along the coast. Labor has to answer for a lot. I am sure that the Territorians will not forget such promises as were made by Labor in May when the Minister for Transport (Mr Peter Morris) assured the Territory Labor Leader, Bob Collins, that preparations for the construction of the Darwin to Alice Springs rail link were proceeding on schedule. What happened in last Thursday night's statement?
—He had no idea. He wasn't consulted.

—He was not consulted about that matter; he was consulted about other matters of national security, but not about that. It means effectively that the Northern Territory does not have the capacity to meet the required 40 per cent of the costs of construction. The economic statement states:

SPEECH.PARA: The Commonwealth assistance to the Northern Territory is very generous.

It proceeds to work out that assistance on a per capita basis.
