Where does the Northern Territory find itself in the light of the Minister's promise? It is right back to where it was.

It is significant that another phase of Labor policy, on the mining of uranium, is the thing that probably prevents the Territory from gathering income and revenue to be able to meet that 40 per cent. So, on all sides, development in the Northern Territory has been stymied. It has been cut in its tracks. I am sure that the Territorians will not forget the manner in which they have been treated in this regard. This also brings up the question of the power-house in Darwin, which is absolutely necessary to encourage industries-as was the railway . What is to happen to the airport development and all the other programs that were already in place there? What we have to do, by reading the newspapers, is to wait for the next episode somewhere along the line, perhaps in the Budget, to see what will happen in that regard.

Speakers in the debate from the Government side are very keen to try to deny the fact that one-third of the savings, one-third of the sacrifice, is to be borne by country people. Yet they have the gall to say here that they have some feeling for rural and country Australia. Let this be evidenced in what support they are giving back to the people whom they say they represent. I refer to income equalisation deposits and depreciation on certain assets. I inform the honourable member for McMillan (Mr Cunningham)-who has now fled the chamber-that the depreciation allowance on fuel containers was deliberately meant, at the time of the oil crisis, to ensure that there was on-farm storage, and it succeeded. Let us also look at air fares, and at the cost of fuel, water and such things in regard to where this great equality of sacrifice is being made. The equality of sacrifice is that one-third of the savings involved in this mini-Budget is being borne by 6 per cent of the population. Some equality! The Government is strong on hypocrisy but very weak on equality.

I am not ashamed to stand here to support the rural people of Australia, the only people who have any effect in regard to decentralisation. But I wonder whether the Labor Party is ashamed to go back to the people who put it in government to say what it has done in this economic package. On tonight's Nationwide program a great supporter of the Labor Party, Mr Barry Unsworth, really took the Government to task, particularly on the basis of the superannuation commitment. There was no superannuation commitment on the part of the Labor Party when it was in opposition and when it went to the polls. The great policies were in respect of there being no capital gains tax. Yet Labor's treatment of superannuation is just that. Someone might care to respond to the criticism of Mr Barry Unsworth, the Secretary of the New South Wales Trades and Labour Council, who has indicated that the manner in which the Government has attacked this aspect is nothing short of criminal and will have the same repercussions as the 25 per cent across the board tariff reductions of 1974. The left wing here would not agree with what he said, but one must expect that type of thing from uneducated people in that regard.

What has this presentation meant in respect of promises? We have been told about the $9.6 billion and other matters, but let us look at the cost in promises. I ask the Government: When the Labor Party went to the elections, how big was it on advertising the fact that all of its promises were qualified by the manner in which the deficit was then framed? I can show plenty of advertisements from my electorate concerning the election campaign which talked about tax cuts, rebates, the sales tax on retreaded tyres, devaluation, jobs, and the whole lot. I could not see one Labor advertisement that appeared in that election campaign saying that all this was qualified. There was no qualification in this regard whatsoever. In government, these people are to have a recovery by advertising it. It is the first advertisement-led recovery that I have seen. They are spending millions of dollars on advertising a Summit which is already in collapse. It is a great joke.

One local government member will be selected to be on the Economic Planning Advisory Council. I applaud the Government for that. But let us look at the composition of the remaining 16 members of the Council. The shadow Minister for small business will move an amendment in that connection. However, included in the membership is that great economic expert of Australia, the latter-found economic person who is concerned about the matter, the Prime Minister himself-an instant expert on the economy. Let us look at his track record as regards being on the EPAC-ACTU-Solo, right down the drain; travel; Bourke's store; and all the others. This is the great economic expert who is to preside over this Council, denying the people of Australia the normal budgetary considerations of being able to approach Ministers with their problems. What a great aspect of the economic package this is!

On the other hand, we find that local water programs are to benefit by $20m and local roads will benefit by $70m. There is to be a 30 per cent cost requirement from the project sponsors in regard to these work creation jobs, and this lies with the States under the legislation. If this 30 per cent is to be carried over and paid by local government, it must be recognised that with this aspect of funding local government has a commitment too. I warn the Government, if it feels that the creation of jobs and the extra money involved will be at no cost to local government, that this will not be so. If the Government feels that its contributions to local roads of $70m and to local water programs, in lieu of the bicentennial water program, are reasons not to meet its commitment in personal tax sharing in real values, it has another think coming. In fairness, we should realise that local government will be maintaining and carrying a large proportion of these job projects. Also, in some States there may not be proper consultation with the local governments on the conditions of the programs. I hope that the States and the Federal Government will ensure that local government is properly consulted in every way.

The whole aspect of the economic statement, the Summit and everything else was based around the wage situation throughout Australia. It is significant to realise that it was members of the Opposition, when they were in government, who introduced the wage pause of which the then Labor Opposition was highly critical . Yet the Economic Summit, for everything else it did, gave no firm direction on this vital aspect. I hope that the Government sees the necessity of keeping wages to a reasonable level.

TALK.START.PARA: —Seven years of government neglect have left Australians with a housing problem second only to unemployment in magnitude and social costs . And, like unemployment, Australia's housing problem will take years of government action to remedy. It is not by accident that unemployment and housing were two of the highly featured programs in last Thursday's economic statement, or that they are being debated together tonight. The two problems are closely linked and with courageous moves in the housing area this Government expects to be able to begin to grapple with the enormous burden of unemployment that we have inherited from the previous Government, as well as the enormous deficit we have also inherited. Expecting a $6 billion deficit, we were informed of a $9.6 billion deficit on taking over the reigns of government. As Kenneth Davidson said in the Age on 8 December 1982:

SPEECH.PARA: The blow out of the deficit from a 1.7 billion in August to $4 billion in December in a matter of three months is either a measure of massive economic collapse in a very short period or of some cynical work when the Budget papers were being prepared.

One wonders what his comments would have been had he known the real facts-a $9.6 billion deficit. I hope the electors of Bruce give some thought to that hidden $ 9.6 billion deficit when they go to the polls on Saturday. It was known at the time of the last election by the then Government, but unknown at the time to the Australian Labor Party. The Treasurer (Mr Keating) pointed out in his economic statement:
. . . even more reprehensibly, it--
The former Government-
concealed the extent of the fiscal imbalances which it was creating from the Australian people, and arranged for the Bills for its extravagance to be presented a year later, in 1983-84.

That was obviously done on the vote now, pay later, plan. Of course, the Opposition expected to be in government then and, had it been in government, probably would have reversed its promises, as it has done so often in the past. The people of Bruce should ponder this. As the Opposition predictably attacks our housing and employment initiatives, we should ask the Opposition to say what it would have done. What would it have done? What did it do over seven years for job creation and housing? In March 1983 the Housing Industry Association stated that in Victoria:
The deficiency between needs and supply is currently between 7,000 and 8,000 dwellings a year. The accumulated deficiency over the last four years is over 20 ,000 dwellings.

The Housing Industry Association estimates that the construction of 7,000 dwellings will employ an extra 3,500 to 4,000 persons on site and 2,000 to 2,500 off site contractors. The spin-off from this activity would create $35m to $40m worth of business in home furnishings and another 1,000 jobs in Victoria. The further spin-off from reactivating the housing industry-again I refer only to Victoria but the same activity will take place in every State and Territory-will be an extra $11,324 revenue in income tax, company tax and the savings on the welfare bill as more and more people are working. We will, as the Minister for Housing and Construction (Mr Hurford) said, see that housing plays a key role in our determination to get Australia moving. Increased housing activity is a crucial element of this recovery. Housing will play its role as a stimulus to economic recovery. We are aiming for an annual target rate of 130,000 to 135,000 house commencements in the second half of 1983-84. This will mean an increase of 22,000 over the 1982-83 figure and will create an extra 25,000 jobs.

We are dispensing with the ineffective schemes put in place by the previous Government. They were totally confusing. To assist moderate first home buyers we will introduce one simple scheme. Home buyers will be able to choose that mix of deposit assistance and interest subsidy that best meets their needs. We consulted the housing industry, housing finance institutions, housing consumer representatives and the State and Territory Housing Ministers before completing our plans. They were not thrust upon anybody; we had comprehensive dialogue about them. We are not introducing measures that will run into labour or material bottlenecks, or cost pressures. The package is desperately needed by the industry and by those without jobs.

Direct funding under the Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement will be increased to $500m in a tremendous boost to public housing. This 50 per cent increase will be the start of a joint Commonwealth-State task to give some justice to those in need of public housing. Public housing should be a secure option for low income people. Instead, after years of government neglect, it offers little hope. In 1980, 320,000 families and single pensioners were eligible, based on their incomes, for public housing but were forced to pay high rents in the private sector. High demand and short supply have caused rents to soar. Rents have increased in Melbourne by 12 per cent and in Sydney by 15 per cent. The average rent in Melbourne is $86 a week, and now represents 36 per cent of the minimum weekly adult wage of $238. The average rent in Sydney represents 48 per cent of the minimum weekly adult wage. The unemployed face a double hardship in unaffordable rents and discrimination by landlords and estate agents. Caravan parks, with high site rents and poor amenities, have become a way of life for thousands of Australian families. The 36,300 young unemployed who are not living at home are extremely vulnerable to homelessness and youth refuges are currently coping with only one third of the requests for emergency accommodation.

Under the conservative Government of 1975 to 1983 money for public housing through the Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement fell dramatically. Between 1974 -75 and 1982-83 there was a 64 per cent cut in real terms. In 1974-75 payments to the States totalled $385.4m. In 1983-83 they totalled $312.6m, a drop in real terms of $72.8m. It is vital that Australia's poorest housing consumers get the greatest benefit from Labor's policies. Equity should be the key objective of all our programs. The social consequences of artificially constructed environments, where all the elderly, all the single parents or all the disabled are housed together, are totally undesirable. Public housing can respond in a sensitive and innovative way to changing social needs.

Far from being a drain on national resources, expenditure on housing, both private and public, creates jobs. For every $100m spent on home buildings, more than 8,000 jobs are created. There is a high multiplier effect because most items used are made in Australia. Additional expenditure on housing has a rapid impact on creating work. The two problems causing the greatest misery in Australia today are unemployment and housing. The insecurity and poverty suffered by families paying expensive rents is causing family breakdowns. The personal effects of long term unemployment are untenable and the social costs of long term unemployment are horrific. I congratulate the Ministers involved in this statement on their initiatives in the interests of the Australian family and of the army of unemployed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Shipton Mr R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer firstly to the Economic Planning Advisory Council Bill before the House. It was foreshadowed in Australian Labor Party policy and agreed to at the National Economic Summit Conference. It is to be a statutory body comprising 17 members. It should be noted that over one-third of its members are to be Government representatives: Three Federal, three State and one local government. It will be top heavy with government representation. It is meant to be a body receiving views from the outside community, yet it will be bureaucratic by its very nature.

SPEECH.PARA: Whenever a body such as this is created it tends to be the start and the finish of the matter. EPAC will be the consultative body with government and will cut out consultation between all other community groups and the Government. The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) has said that EPAC will replace the traditional pre- Budget consultations. Labor is abandoning the wide ranging consultations and discussions of the previous Government. There will be less consultation with the community on Labor Budgets. The Economic Planning Advisory Council will have only a limited usefulness. How can a 17 member body replace the wide ranging groups previously consulted? How can the Prime Minister say 'The Government is keen to hear the views of groups and individuals in the community' if they are blocked off in this way? The Council will act as a filter and will stop community views reaching the Government. Under the previous Government these groups had direct access to Government in the Cabinet room.

The EPAC Bill ignores small businesses. There is no mention of small business in the Bill or in the second reading speech of the Treasurer (Mr Keating). There is no planned representation of small business on EPAC. It is essential that small business be represented on EPAC. I call on the Government to invite a small business representative or representatives to be members of EPAC. The charter of EPAC should refer to the importance of small business in the Australian economy. Even if the Government gives a commitment to small business, I am not sure that EPAC can be of assistance to the small business sector. However, in accepting the inevitability of its existence, EPAC must take into account the needs, difficulties and problems facing small business in Australia today.

The Bill provides for three members to be selected in consultation with business, compared with four in consultation with the trade unions. If EPAC is, as the Government states, to be represenative of a wide range of views, small business must be represented and included. Given that EPAC is stated ALP policy and received support at the Summit, the Opposition will not vote against the Bill. However, in the Committee stage we will move an amendment seeking that small business specifically be represented on EPAC.

The Government, in its EPAC Bill, and in its mini-Budget, fails to understand the nature and importance of the small business sector in the economy. Labor claims a new approach to small business-it talks of an action plan. The action in the mini-Budget is a direct attack on the small business sector. It will force it to contract. Labor forgets that growth and jobs can come only from a healthy and expanding private sector. Only the private sector can create wealth for the benefit of the total community. Only with encouragement of the dynamic small business sector with incentives to make profits and create wealth can growth and reinvestment come. Labor fails to recognise this.

This mini-Budget means upward pressure on interest rates. Labor fails to understand the problems and burdens facing small business through high interest rates. High interest rates stifle profits, stifle growth and stifle investment. The Government fails to understand the nature of investment and its relation to profits. Small investors in businesses will suffer from the abolition of tax concessions. The abolition of the dividend rebate will act as a deterrent to small investors and means that profits so necessary for growth will be taxed twice. This will discourage investment in small and medium companies.

The Government's mini-Budget has created a superannuation shambles. The Government will now tax retirement lump sums. It totally forgets that these amounts are often used to start new businesses, or invest in an existing business. In times when early retirement is being encouraged, it is important that those retiring have lump sums available to them to give them the option to invest in small or medium businesses if they wish to do so. These tax concession changes foreshadowed by the Government in its mini-Budget are a positive discouragement to investment in small business. The taxation of lump sums discriminates against the small business sector and against owners of small businesses. Bona fide redundancy payments paid to wage earners are exempt from the new tax but similar payments to owners and shareholders of small businesses are not. The proposed legislation specifically attacks small business. It taxes lump sums and other entitlements. It means that a bona fide redundancy payment to employees in private companies who are also shareholders, is taxable. Those employees of private companies being beneficiaries of share incentive schemes will be caught whether they be on the shop floor, or in middle management. It is a discouragement of share incentive schemes and the concept of workers having an ownership share in the company for which they work. It is a discrimination against the small private company in favour of the big and larger public company . That is the effect of the Government's proposals. Under the Government's plans an employee, given the opportunity to buy shares in a public company, can still get the retrenchment benefit, but not in a private company. So much for Labor's small business action plan. Labor's action against small business is the manifestation of the plan. Doubtless, this Government in its marauding of small business will next attack the small business sector by removing the $1,200 self- employed superannuation taxation deduction in the August Budget.

Labor's action plan against small business set out in the mini-Budget will hit and hurt small businesses in the country. The flow-on in rural Australia of the depreciation taxation changes will be enormous. At a time when the rural economy is starting to recover from the devastating effect of the drought, Labor strikes with this blow. Labor has no understanding of the special problems facing businesses in rural Australia. The increased Telecom Australia's charges are an added burden and farmers will also pay more for fuel. The mini-Budget is a straight-out attack on the prosperity of the dynamic small business sector. It is an action plan against small business. The facts speak for themselves.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, in Question Time on 17 May the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) was asked about the extra-curricula activities of the Chairman of the Ministerial Staff Advisory Panel, Mr W. P. Butler. In particular he was asked whether these activities included an involvement with a Mr Richard Farmer in the business of lobbyist. The Opposition was naturally concerned as to the huge advantage a person could obtain for himself or his associates in the business of lobbying the Government if, in the first instance, he had the opportunity to dispense the patronage of senior influential employment to ministerial staff. It would be vertical integration of the most profitable kind. The Prime Minister, whilst going to some lengths to recognise the association of Mr Butler and Mr Farmer and Mr Butler's role and power as Chairman of the Ministerial Staff Advisory Panel, first made another point quite clear when, to quote from Hansard, he said:

SPEECH.PARA: To my knowledge, Mr Butler has not been and is not a lobbyist.

As this was the substance of the Opposition question, one might think the matter can now rest. However, it certainly cannot and it would appear that the Prime Minister must be one of the few people in his Government whose knowledge on that subject is so deficient. The question now is, when does a lobbyist become a lobbyist-or, more importantly, when does a senior adviser to government become a lobbyist? The laws of contract quite clearly recognise the reality of the verbal agreement and it is my submission that a person becomes a lobbyist when he agrees to join in business with an established lobbyist, and others, to conduct such business. The fact that he in particular might not take a public position in that undertaking, and does not in fact see himself as a provider of the fodder for the business of lobbying, makes him no less a lobbyist; it just makes him a despicable lobbyist.
The undisputed and unchallenged facts relating to this intent are written in the Sydney Morning Herald of 18 May. The relevant section, taken from an article referring to the Combe affair, says:
Combe was told by a colleague-Mr Richard Farmer, the Canberra businessman and political adviser.
Mr Farmer worked on the Hawke campaign this year. He also worked on the Hayden campaign in 1980-with Combe.

Mr Farmer was interested because he and Combe had reached a very significant business decision. Along with Mr Bill Butler, Mr Farmer's business associate, and a former public servant, they were going into the lobbying business together .
A little further on, the article states:

Then Mr Farmer was told. Not just the excuse-but the real reason Mr Farmer and Mr Butler went to Combe's home. They told him they would talk outside, not inside. Their message was simple and chilling. The Hawke Government had cut Combe off. He was a leper. Nobody could go into business on this basis. Mr Farmer was not very happy about the events, but he could not do anything about it.

In the light of that unchallenged information the question before this Parliament is no longer whether Mr Butler is a lobbyist; in fact, that is irrelevant. Mr Butler entered a verbal contract with that intention-a contract he would have kept had not the circumstances of Mr Ivanov and Mr Combe interrupted that cosy decision. What is more, the stated and undisputed fact in this article, which claims that Mr Farmer and Mr Butler were told of Combe's circumstances, raises considerable doubts in my mind that the Prime Minister had no knowledge of the intention of Mr Butler and Mr Farmer to enter into partnership with Mr Combe as lobbyists. Consequently, his answer last week leaves a lot of questions un- answered. He is the leader of his Government and bears the responsibility for it. He is obliged to dismiss the Minister who briefed Mr Farmer and who knew of Butler's intention or accept the responsibility for this mess himself. Any attempt to retain Mr Butler in his present position can only signify the Prime Minister's intention to condone this kind of lobbying at the lowest level. Of all the circumstances that have arisen from this sorry affair, this is the question that has not been resolved. I sincerely hope the Government will address itself to the position of lobbyists who hold other positions of influence with the Government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Neil Mr L.R.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, we have heard a lot in this place lately about the conservation of wilderness, of trees that have been growing for more than 100 years. That is all very desirable but I would like to say a little about another kind of conservation which has a human element as well as a natural one, and which I think is also very important to our quality of life. I refer to the preservation, in a healthy and viable way, of significant old towns whose very existence is under threat because they are being by-passed by modern developments.

SPEECH.PARA: In particular I want to refer to the historic old South Australian railway town of Peterborough. The history of Peterborough goes back 106 years but the people who live there do not believe it will go on much longer unless something positive is done about securing its traditional employment base in our national railway system, which is steadily being withdrawn from it in the case of rationalisation of Australian National Railways.

In part, this process has to do with conversion to standard gauge, which is both inevitable and progressive. But it also has to do with an increasing emphasis on centralising ANR functions such as administration, supervision, maintenance and repairs to a greater extent in the Adelaide area. ANR currently employs 312 people at Peterborough, out of a population of 2,570. According to local authorities some 140 jobs have already gone during the past 18 months and Australian National has estimated that a further 30 per cent reduction in operational and mechanical staff could take place. Most of the houses formerly maintained for railways staff have been sold off.

Looked at this way the future seems to hold very little for this once flourishing town which used to be the headquarters for what was known as the Peterborough Division, which included the 212 miles of track built in the 1880 to bring the ore from Broken Hill to Port Pirie for smelting and shipping. In marked contrast to the present day, this line was then the only one in Australia that actually paid its own way. That early prosperity seems to have set the tone for the building of Peterborough as a place to last. Its elaborate Town Hall, for instance, is the biggest outside Adelaide and in its heyday saw many a cabaret ball of 2,000 or so guests.

The town has a more far-reaching claim to fame in that it is one of the only two places in the world where three different railway gauges meet-the original South Australian broad gauge, the narrow gauge of the Orroroo line and the standard gauge of the Transcontinental. Peterborough's importance in the railway system in the past has been partly due to this proliferation of gauges. It has maintained a bogey exchange service which enabled goods wagons to make the through journey without transhipment of freight. Now that the standard gauge line has been completed through to Adelaide this service is expected to be removed at any time. This will mean the loss of a further 84 jobs.

The situation facing Peterborough is not immediately disastrous. Australian National has shown itself flexible insofar as it is prepared to soften the blow by finding alternative work for those declared redundant until they choose to leave. Some will retire to live in the former railway houses they have bought. Others will leave, as many have. But what worries those who have the interests of the town at heart is that no matter how painless might be the operations that remove one after another of Peterborough's former functions, their removal is no less final. They are concerned with what will happen to an old established decentralised town that has grown to maturity with its own traditions and way of life developed over several generations of economic security and a pride in its own identity.

That is also my concern. If we accept the premise that decentralisation is a good and necessary aim in a vast country like this with most of the people crowded into coastal cities, ultimately we will have to do something about it. To start from scratch and establish planned new towns is a highly expensive business, as has been proved in other places. Surely it would be a much more gainful policy in economic, social and cultural terms for communities such as this to be sustained by a bit of compromise here and there until, by a joint process of self-help and regional planning, together with any necessary assistance, they can find a new role. For instance, some will say that Peterborough has all the ingredients, including the know-how, for a world-scale working steam locomotive museum with plenty of assorted track for tourist trips. But things like that do not happen overnight. Just for now, perhaps the goal set by the Fraser Government for Australian National to become self-supporting by 1988-89 is not so vitally urgent an end in these tough times that it justifies all the means necessary to achieve it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Braithwaite Mr R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I want to draw the attention of the House to a significant anniversary that will take place on 11 June.
—Happy birthday!

—It is a little early for that; I will take those congratulations in December. It is the fiftieth anniversary of the Australian Jaycees organisation which was formed in Perth on 11 June 1933. I think this House ought to pay proper tribute to the work that that association has done for Australian youth over the years. In fact it has been estimated that some 150,000 Australians have benefited from the training of the Jaycees movement. Many communities throughout Australia have benefited from the service that this organisation has provided.

SPEECH.PARA: There have been many significant events over those 50 years. The first world congress of Jaycees ever held in Australia was held in Melbourne in 1952. At that congress the official Jaycees creed was adopted. The creed reads:
We believe that faith in God gives meaning and purpose to human life
That brotherhood of man transcends the sovereignty of nations
That economic justice can be best won by free men through free enterprise
That governments should be of laws rather than of men
That earth's great treasure lies in human personality
That service to humanity is the best work of life.

The Jaycees movement has made that pledge and given to the Australian community those very fine ideals. Some of the other significant events, in keeping with the creed, have involved the participation of members in social issues. In fact, at a time when the environment was never discussed in State or Federal parliaments the Jaycees in 1970 adopted the project 'My Country's Keeper'. That was followed in 1974 by an international project entitled 'Man and His Environment'. Those projects have influenced the social feelings of many Australians. Also the 'Road Courtesy is Catching' project was adopted in the late 1950s. We have only to see the number of road deaths today to realise how important that project was then and how important it continues to be.

From 1981 onwards the Jaycees have been involved with the project 'Pride in Our Nation'. This is an attempt to bring to the Australian people the realisation that it is a privilege to be an Australian. That has been a very important project. In fact, a project that goes hand in glove with this is one designed to ensure that Australia Day is held on 26 January and not on the weekend closest to that date. I fully support that view. In 1961, in conjunction with the Australian Chamber of Manufactures, the Jaycees adopted the logo and the theme ' Australian made'. This continues to be an aspect of Australian trade and commerce. 'Youth speaks for Australia' is a youth training program which has been adopted Australia-wide by all chambers in Australia. This project is aimed at improving public speaking and presentation by youth. In addition to this, the Jaycees themselves have a Geoff M. King oratory contest which again is Australia -wide and which is named after a man who was prominent in spreading the organisation throughout Queensland in the early 1950s. In 1965-66 the Jaycees helped in the Government's initiative of conversion to decimal currency.

They have spread the hand of goodwill and friendship throughout the world. This is the part they play in the international Jaycees movement. Some 600,000 young people throughout the world join together to form this wonderful organisation. They have helped to promote clubs which offer the same opportunities in neighbouring nations, such as Indonesia, Papua New Guinea and Hong Kong. I am sure that they have done their share in spreading the hand of friendship. Three Australians have acted as world presidents in those 50 years. They are Mr John Rundle, an architect from South Australia, Mr Les Perrott, from Victoria who was the first world president, and Mr Royce Pepin. Many other Australians have acted in executive positions. In 1976 the organisation admitted women to their ranks and membership. I am sure that the women will play a significant part in the future of Australia as far as training is concerned.

On 8 June the Australian Postal Commission will recognise the Jaycees with the issue of a postage stamp. It is important to realise that Jaycees is not a service club. However, in providing a service to the community it trains its members to take their place in leadership roles in local government, State government and Federal government.

TALK.START.PARA: —On the afternoon of 10 May three questions were asked in this chamber-the first by the honourable member for Warringah (Mr MacKellar), the second by the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Peacock) and the third by the right honourable member for New England (Mr Sinclair). It is my view that the Opposition set out to raise the name of David Combe in order to embarrass the Government. It was prepared to ruin the reputation of a man to score a cheap political point. The disgusting role played by the Leader of the Opposition in this affair is what I wish to raise tonight.

SPEECH.PARA: The Leader of the Opposition engineered this attack. It is my view that the Leader of the Opposition organised this attack on David Combe to cover up some of his own business dealings. Late in January 1983 a meeting took place in Melbourne, at the home of a Mr L. Matherson in South Yarra. In attendance were the Soviet Ambassador, Dr Soudarikov, a Mr Dashevski, a trade representative from the Russian Embassy, and Mr Laurie Matherson of the import-export company called Commercial Bureau. At the time this company was the major company dealing in Australian-Soviet trade. The fourth person present was the Leader of the Opposition, who at that time was the Minister for Industry and Commerce.

It is interesting to note that before the meeting could take place the now Leader of the Opposition sought the assurance of the other three that details discussed at the meeting were to be secret and not to be disclosed to the then Prime Minister, Malcolm Fraser. This request is, to say the least, strange. What did Mr Matherson and the now Opposition Leader have to discuss with the Embassy representatives that could not be 'repeated' to the then Prime Minister, Mr Fraser? Did they discuss trade between the two countries? Were ways to by-pass the trade embargo discussed? Did the present Leader of the Opposition offer to make things easier for Mr Matherson's company in its trade dealings with the Soviet Union? Was the subject of the usual hefty commission discussed? Or was Mr Peacock involved in discussing matters which could be conceived as a threat to Australia's national security? This is what the Opposition has been saying about other people.

These questions must be answered. I ask the Government to investigate the issues I have raised here tonight. I put to the Government that these issues could be considered under the terms of reference for the Hope Royal Commission on Security and Intelligence Agencies. A person who sets out deliberately to destroy the career of another in order to save his own miserable skin has no place leading a political party in this country, in my view.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Groom The Hon R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise tonight a very serious breach of promise by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), the Minister for Transport (Mr Peter Morris) and the Minister for Aviation (Mr Beazley). This matter relates to the upgrading of the Wynyard Airport in north-west Tasmania. The Prime Minister made so much of alleged broken promises by the previous Government. He told the nation he would be a man of his word, that he would fulfil his promises and that his word would be his bond. Yet within a few short weeks of gaining office he has dragged the political credibility of national leaders to an all time low.

SPEECH.PARA: Before the recent election the then Leader of the Opposition, Mr Hawke, and his spokesman on transport, Mr Morris, gave a solemn undertaking that an Australian Labor Party government would proceed with the upgrading of the Wynyard Airport, which was agreed to by the Fraser Government and was then under way. The promises made by Mr Hawke and Mr Morris are reported in the Advocate and the Examiner of Saturday, 26 February 1983, and are there for all to see. It was a clear promise without any qualifications about the deficit or the dam. This was no vague promise about interest rates or unemployment, it was a clear promise to civic leaders and all the people of a regional community that a specific local project was in no way at risk, that it would certainly proceed 'as a matter of priority' under an Australian Labor Party government.

History has now shown that the people of north-west Tasmania were hoodwinked by men who were deliberately dishonest or did not care whether they spoke the truth . We are now told by the Minister for Aviation that Wynyard Airport will not be upgraded and hundreds of jobs will be lost. It saddens me that local politicians -in particular the resident Labor senator, Senator Tate, and the Australian Labor Party candidate for Braddon, Mr Lance Fee-were party to this false promise and used it for their own political advantage. Now the promise has been callously broken with no apology, no excuse and no explanation for the deception . It is the most disgraceful act of political dishonesty I have witnessed in my years in politics.

I know that local people, including those living in the far north-west and on the west coast, feel let down by Senator Tate. He had advance knowledge that this promise was likely to be broken, yet he failed to persuade Hawke or Beazley to keep his word--

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member should refer to members of the House by the names of their electorates. He is well aware of that.
—He failed to persuade the relevant Ministers and the Prime Minister to keep their promise. Senator Tate failed the people of the north-west coast and the people of the west coast.
—I rise on a point of order. I was actually in Wynyard and I know that Senator Tate was not invited to the meeting there on the airport.
—Order! There is no point of order.

—Senator Tate has attacked me personally in a desperate attempt to take the heat off himself. He has to realise that the ball is now right in his court. His political future could well depend on whether he can convince the Prime Minister to reverse his decision and proceed with the upgrading of the Wynyard Airport to medium jet standard. He has already lost a lot of credibility over this issue and I hope for his sake that he can convince the Government that it is wrong and thus regain some credibility. The Prime Minister does not care about the workers. He does not care about the jobs involved. He does not care about any individual except Bob Hawke. We have seen what he did to Mr Combe. He cut his throat.
—I rise on a point of order. The honourable member is continuing to refer to honourable members by name, which is incorrect procedure.
—Yes, I notice that. The honourable member should refer to the 'Prime Minister'.

—I apologise, Mr Speaker. The Prime Minister cut Mr Combe's throat. This act of political dishonesty proves that the Prime Minister is not a man of honour, not a man who can be trusted. I am sorry that Senator Tate pretends to defend the Prime Minister and support local people. I only wish that he had the intestinal fortitude to speak out against this insult to the people of Tasmania and acknowledge that a promise has been broken. It is a pity that he does not take the same tack as has been taken by local labor members of the House of Assembly who, in a statement released today, said that the issue is about the value of commitments given to the region by the new Government. They went on to say:

SPEECH.PARA: For north west residents, the credibility of the Government is at stake.

What an indictment of the new Prime Minister and the new Government, out of the mouths of good Labor Party members who have served the local area very well indeed. Two are former Ministers. One is a former Speaker of the State House in Tasmania. They have attacked the Prime Minister. The Prime Minister has accused many on this side of the House of telling lies. Now the boomerang has struck a deserving target. This is a very important project. It is disgraceful that the Government has taken away funding for it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Simmons Mr D.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to take a few minutes of the time of the House tonight to refer to a rather interesting and significant event that took place in my electorate last Sunday. I refer to the mini economic summit which occurred in Bathurst. It was an interesting idea and was conducted largely under the auspices of the State member for Bathurst, Mr Mick Clough, with my assistance as the Federal member for Calare and also that of the Mayor of Bathurst, Alderman Max Hanrahan. We decided to try to capture in a miniature sense the spirit of consensus which was so apparent at the April National Economic Summit Conference. We saw this as a small step towards achieving national reconciliation, reconstruction and recovery on a micro scale.

SPEECH.PARA: The important aspect of the mini economic summit was that invitations were sent out to a wide cross section of the Bathurst community and the response was rather good, considering that the meeting was held on a Sunday when all sorts of other interesting events, such as football matches and social events, take place in a country community. Invitations were accepted by more than 60 people, including representatives of the Chamber of Commerce, trade unions, industry groups, pensioners, local financial institutions, social workers and other interested members of the local community. The event was covered not only by the local and regional media but also, interestingly, was picked up by the Australian Broadcasting Commission in its State news bulletin that night. I thought that recognised the importance of this significant event in my electorate. Syndicate groups were formed to consider very important issues affecting rural affairs, minerals and energy, urban and regional development, local government, education, emergency services, community affairs and a few other categories of activity as well. The syndicate groups will be reporting to an executive committee, made up of the State member, Mr Clough, myself as the Federal member, the Mayor of Bathurst, Alderman Hanrahan, representatives of the Chamber of Commerce and representatives of the unions. We believe that the exercise was highly successful-so much so that we intend to duplicate it on 5 June in Lithgow, which is in the eastern end of my electorate. I recommend that the exercise be repeated throughout Australia because I believe that only good can come out of such events.

We recognised, as did the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) in April, that there is in the Australian people a tremendous amount of good will. Unfortunately, a large amount of that has been alienated in recent times, particularly during the last seven miserable years of conservative government in this country. We see this event as an ideal way of involving the local community and promoting trust in putting forward local ideas concerning how we might go about, on a micro level, getting our economy moving again. I also see it as an ideal opportunity to obtain local committee input to plans that will be made in the near future to take advantage of the Community Employment Program announced by the Treasurer ( Mr Keating) and the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations (Mr Willis) . Local input will be important in making the best use of community employment funds in my electorate and will certainly be very welcome to the participants in the mini economic summit.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Burr Mr M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I feel sorry for the honourable member for Braddon (Mr Groom) and his constituents in that the Federal Government is not proceeding with the upgrading of the Wynyard Airport, but I remind the honourable member and the House that in my electorate the Labor Government has welshed on promises made during the election campaign concerning three projects. I refer particularly to the Warner Creek dam project, which has been estimated to cost $ 11m, the Craigbourne dam project, which was estimated to cost $6m and the upgrading of the St Helens port, which was estimated to cost $4m.

SPEECH.PARA: As occurred in the electorate of Braddon with the upgrading of the Wynyard Airport, during the election campaign the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin) and other spokesmen for the Australian Labor Party came to Tasmania and gave wholehearted promises that they would embark on these projects if they were elected to government. However, now that they are in government they are welshing on their promises. They have refused to give any guarantee that they will honour the commitments they gave to the people of Tasmania. Quite frankly, I believe that not only my constituents but also those in other electorates in Tasmania have no reason at all to trust this Government when it gives promises with a view to winning votes but, once having attained office, it backtracks and welshes on the promises it has given. This House, with my constituents and other people in Australia, has every right to condemn the Government for breaking promises as it has.

The Fraser Government had entered into long term negotiations with local and other authorities in Tasmania concerning the funding of these projects. Commitments had been given by that Government and local authorities had every right to believe that had it been re-elected the projects would have been proceeded with. The present Prime Minister and other spokesmen for the Labor Party came to Tasmania and said, 'We will fund these projects if elected,' withouth having the faintest idea of what they were all about. The people in Tasmania had every right to expect that if Labor were elected to government these projects would be proceeded with but now that has happened, the present Government says, 'It is a different ball game. We will not go ahead with them now. We will go ahead with these projects only if the Tasmanian Government refuses to go ahead with the Gordon below Franklin hydro-electric scheme'. I believe that that amounts to welshing on promises given during an election campaign. It represents political expediency at its worst. This House should condemn the Government for backing down on its promises, for deceiving the people of Tasmania. I believe that the Parliament has a right to demand from this Government a better go for the Tasmanian people.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member for Braddon (Mr Groom) was good enough to inform me that he intended to raise the question of Wynyard Airport in the adjournment debate tonight. I do not think he did his case much good judging by the way in which he raised it. On this question of whether undertakings have been given on this particular matter it is pertinent to look at the statements made by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) during the last week of the election campaign on this and many other matters. As I have had occasion to remark before in this House, the first point that ought to be noted about this matter is this: The Prime Minister had the honesty, unprecedented virtually in the rough and tumble of Australian electoral politics, to point out before the date of the election, when rumours started to extend about the nature and the size of the deficit that this country faced, that if the financial difficulties were as massive as seemed to be the case then obviously the programs that were being put forward by the Government would have to be reviewed to ensure that real priorities were adhered to. He said that before the election and it was on that basis that he went to the polls. Unlike the performances of the previous Prime Minister, he levelled with the electorate. It is in that light that the remarks made by the honourable member for Braddon ought to be viewed. They ought to be viewed in another light as well. When honourable members come into this place to make a serious case for projects in their electorates, they must do a great deal better than handing around abuse, particularly if the Premier of the State wants to raise that same matter with the Prime Minister at a later stage.
—This project was under way. You have broken a promise.
—Order! The honourable member for Braddon will cease interjecting. He has asked a series of questions. They are being answered and he should cease his incessant interjections.

—The honourable member will have to do a great deal better than come into this place with a string of abuse, without argument, on the basis of a promise which the Prime Minister indicated, in the course of the election campaign, would need to be reviewed.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member must understand one thing about airports. The airports program is not principally a job creation program. Projects are included in the program when there is a requirement for the proposed works, when they meet local needs and when they are of such priority that their completion is essential ahead of many other important expenditure proposals before the Government. The test of priority has had to be applied most stringently in the Government's review of the unprecedented Budget deficit projected for 1983-84 that had been inherited from the previous Government. The Government is taking positive initiatives to create jobs in Tasmania. During 1983-84 Tasmania will receive an allocation of $7.5m for employment creation projects. This is in addition to the State's share of $2.8m of the $100m remaining from the wage pause program. The State will also benefit from the $50m which has been provided internally for employment creation projects to be administered directly by Federal Government departments. Those are the schemes that provide employment. When we consider the construction of airports, we have to look at the requirements of the particular airport. The fact of the matter is that the traffic does not justify an extension of Wynyard airport--
Opposition members interjecting--

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The Minister will resume his seat. I have requested honourable members to cease interjecting. They are continuing. I can conclude only that the lateness of the hour gives them the incentive to do that. I ask that they desist. I call the Minister for Aviation.

—The Opposition, as I said, will have to do a great deal better on this matter if it wants to be taken seriously. On the question of Wynyard Airport, there is not the demand for it to be developed at this stage. It is only a few miles from another airport that is in the process of being upgraded. It may well be that an argument can be made and sustained that Wynyard ought to have had priority ahead of Devonport. But that is all over because the development took place at Devonport first.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member for Braddon chose in this regard to raise in this House certain matters related to Senator Tate. Senator Tate, as I understand it, has raised questions in relation to delays that took place in the preparation of submissions on Wynyard Airport, the blame for which he was prepared to lay at the-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The Minister's time has expired. There being no other Minister seeking the floor, the Minister for Aviation may continue.

—As I said, I understand that in the past Senator Tate has raised the question of the delays in the preparation of a case for Wynyard Airport. He has pointed out at different times that certain of the local representatives have in fact argued in the past against Wynyard and other airports in the area proceeding under the local ownership program.
—That is wrong. It is quite false.

—The honourable member can take that up at a later stage. But the fact of the matter is that, whatever the reason delays did occurr. In the circumstances that have arisen, when there are many airports claiming considerable priority, in areas that are far less well served than the north and north west of Tasmania, they must be incorporated within the program. In those circumstances, the justification for Wynyard does not stand at the moment.
—You broke a promise.

—If the honourable member has some views that he believes ought to be considered by the Government then he has the obligation to present that case in this House. The honourable member did his case, his State and his seat an enormous disservice by the absurd way in which he chose to raise this problem in this House. It is becoming fairly typical of the way in which the Opposition uses up its time in the adjournment debate. Very little that is constructive emerges from Opposition members, and this is another case in point.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Tate has played an entirely honourable role in this regard. He has been a very effective advocate for the situation of Wynyard Airport over a considerable period. He has regarded it most anxiously. The difficulty that has arisen, of course, is precisely the point that I raised earlier. We have to establish the priority and that priority must be based upon the real needs of the airlines industry as well as the needs of the local population. The simple fact of the matter is-

TALK.START.PARA: —You made a promise.
—I have already dealt with that question.
—You have not.

—The simple fact of the matter is that, unlike other Commonwealth projects, the airports program is subject to cost recovery from the airlines industry. If we undertake unnecessary developments at any particular time they will have a significant impact upon the travelling public and upon the airlines industry. This is not a circumstance that we take lightly in the Department of Aviation. I have already pointed out to the honourable member why a review has been undertaken of a wide range of capital works projects and the fact that the Prime Minister indicated that this might be necessary in the course of the election campaign.
—He did not.
—He did so in the course of the election campaign.
—You are prevaricating again. You are being evasive. You are misleading the House.
—Order! The honourable member for Denison compounds his previous offences. I call the Minister for Aviation.

—The honourable member used to be known in this place as the mouth from the south. Because of recent revelations in this House he is now known as the motorist of the Molonglo. If he keeps this up by the time this Parliament rises he will be known as motor-mouth. He has always operated in this place in the same way. The honourable member for Braddon expressed his case and all I can say is that it is a very sorry day for Tasmania when, in these circumstances, the only people it has for its advocates are the people who have been performing in this way.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Everingham The Hon D.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Trade, upon notice, on 3 May 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What factors are considered in determining whether meat products imported into Australia are unfairly competing with Australian meat products.

(2) Other than the ban on all new contracts for imports from the Argentine from 8 April to 29 June 1982, what restrictions or categories thereof have been placed by Australia on meat imports in the last 10 years.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The question of whether meat products imported into Australia are unfairly competing with Australian domestic production depends on whether and to what extent such imports are dumped or subsidised by the exporting country and, if so , whether, as a result, material injury is caused or threatened to the Australian industry.

In the case of formal complaints by Australian producers that imported meat is unfairly competing with domestic product, investigations are made by the Australian Bureau of Customs under the Customs Tariff (Anti-Dumping) Act 1975. Where it can be substantiated that the imported product is being dumped or being exported with the assistance of subsidies and as a result is causing or threatens to cause material injury to a domestic industry Australia can impose duties on the imported product equivalent to the established margin of dumping or subsidisation. As an alternative to anti-dumping or countervailing duties exporters may give an undertaking in relation to exports of the product.

(2) Apart from the occasion mentioned by the honourable member there have been no restrictions on meat imports into Australia over the past ten years. Imports are of course subject to quarantine regulations and to any customs duty that is applicable.

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Neither CSIRO nor the Bureau of Animal Health has organised a scheme for ' on-farm' diagnosis of foot-and-mouth disease viruses using tests such as the ELISA tests.

(2) The Government is yet to make decisions on the ASTEC report. When these decisions are known CSIRO will be able to consider development of appropriate research programs at ANAHL. The Organisation is aware that ASTEC has noted that 'safe diagnosis carried out ''on-farm'' using relatively simple procedures may be possible in the future, and the development and acceptance of such techniques should be promoted' but that 'no single diagnostic test is completely reliable, and dependence upon serology alone for the initial identification of an exotic animal virus would be unwise'.
